ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:08
still investigating

simon
2016-04-07 14:08
shouldn't we have packages to install all requirements?

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:09
@simon: that was my original proposal (see dev-env PRs 47 and 48, https://github.com/openblockchain/obc-dev-env/pull/47)

simon
2016-04-07 14:09
oh that is great

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:10
but it was felt at the time that the indirection to packages was too confusing for developers to understand how to tweak the catalog over the raw vagrant machinations

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:10
so, PR 49 was derived from that effort which stripped out the PPA proposal

simon
2016-04-07 14:10
i don't understand

jyellick
2016-04-07 14:11
Yes, I think the packages generally make everyone's life easier, except for those who want to go a nonstandard path. If you don't want your env to be x86_64 Ubuntu, then having to reverse engineer the packages is perhaps a daunting step.

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:11
well, I put out PR 47/48 but the PPA portion was rejected in review

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:11
thats the short summary

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:12
so, then I backed that out and resubmitted as PR 49

simon
2016-04-07 14:12
what's the problem with prebuilt packages?

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:13
the argument was that the extra level of indirection (needing to edit/submit PPA stuff) vs just editing vagrant files like setup.sh was more onerous

simon
2016-04-07 14:13
jyellick: packages for rocksdb, etc? other systems have packages already

jyellick
2016-04-07 14:14
Moving the compilation step to be only in the baseimage construction eliminates 90% of the pain. The additional ease that came from building the packages was deemed not enough because of the additional indirection. I'm not sure I'm entirely sold by that argument, but, at least we got that 90% with the much improved new baseimage stuff.

simon
2016-04-07 14:15
not everybody wants to or can use vagrant

simon
2016-04-07 14:15
especially for deployments

jyellick
2016-04-07 14:16
For those who do not want to use Ubuntu, or x86_64 architecture, then they would need to re-roll those packages for their platform. Simply doing the 'make' is arguably easier.

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:16
obviously I am a proponent of packaging or I wouldnt have submitted the proposal, but I do see both sides

jyellick
2016-04-07 14:17
Yes, I definitely liked the PPA approach, and supported its merge. But I understand the opposition.

simon
2016-04-07 14:18
how is that even an either/or?

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:18
one thing I learned through those particular PRs was that the launchpad build system isnt the most easy to use and I could foresee some challenges getting people comfortable with maintaining packages there

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:18
its probably at least partly a familiarity thing for me: i am much more well versed maintaining packages in http://build.opensuse.org

simon
2016-04-07 14:20
so what about using this?

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:20
if we move towards packaging, that would be my recommendation

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:20
(it supports ubuntu and other distros, despite the suse affiliation)

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:21
one thing to note, PPA methodology does not mitigate the notion of baseimage: i think the best architecture would encompass both

simon
2016-04-07 14:22
i absolutely agree

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:22
it has to do with repeatability: baseimage captures repeatability in a manner more natural than raw package repos

jyellick
2016-04-07 14:22
I think if it were possible to easily build the packages locally, and not depend on the PPA, then it would be fine. But, that's starting to introduce additional complexity, and more permutations to dev environments. For the mainline case, I think the big feature for Vagrant is that everyone's dev environment is exactly the same, so tracking down problems is much easier. Once some people are rolling their own packages, some are pulling from a PPA, you lose a little of the benefit of Vagrant. Still, it would be nice for those who want to setup a dev env on their system without all the compilation could simply pull those packages from a repo. Adding a small script to do so I think would receive much less pushback.

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:22
so the ideal (to me) would be all stuff are packages, baseimage captures the set of packages for a stable environment

simon
2016-04-07 14:23
jyellick: oh it is

ethertyper
2016-04-07 14:24
has joined #fabric-dev-env

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:30
@jyellick: well said, one of the things that might make the model work is if the stuff that isnt in the distro were perhaps maintained as part of the hyperledger project

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:31
e.g. /thirdparty/rocksdb

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:31
and if it were simple to say “cd ./thirdparty/rocksdb; make package”, that might mitigate the concern

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:32
that would then be similar to what we have already adopted on the baseimage front…that is, some person/group is in charge of curating the officially hosted binaries, but anyone can build local ala your USE_LOCAL_BASEIMAGE type approach

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:33
would need some thought, obviously, but..

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:33
anyway, like you said: 90% of my pain went away just not having to wait for the stuff to be compiled each iteration :wink:

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:34
actually, probably better as a sep repo (e.g. hyperledger/thirdparty.git)

simon
2016-04-07 14:35

simon
2016-04-07 14:35
what software packages are we even talking about?

simon
2016-04-07 14:35

simon
2016-04-07 14:35
docker?

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:35

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:36
golang, rocksdb, grpc, and nodejs, primarily

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:36
of those, golang and nodejs are already binary distributions, but not .deb packages

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:37
rocksdb and protobuf are just raw dl+compile, so those are the primary targets

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:38
i think docker is already consumed as a package

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:39
that happens here: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/devenv/setup.sh#L45

jyellick
2016-04-07 14:39
Yes, Docker comes in from the official Docker repos

jyellick
2016-04-07 14:39
(And in fact comes in during the `vagrant up` not `baseimage` stage, so that we can pick a storage backend)

simon
2016-04-07 14:49
wuh, nodejs?

chetsky
2016-04-07 14:50
has joined #fabric-dev-env

shemnon
2016-04-07 14:50
has joined #fabric-dev-env

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:52
@simon: I am not sure what consumes that: i suspect it might be three primary parts: 1) the website stuff that was being developed at one time, 2) some of the REST clients I have seen are written in javascript, and 3) there was some preliminary support for JS based chaincode added to the fabric

simon
2016-04-07 14:52
ah i see

simon
2016-04-07 14:55
so why can't we just use rocksdb and grpc packages?

simon
2016-04-07 14:55
and go as well?

simon
2016-04-07 14:55
all in debian packages

simon
2016-04-07 14:55
ah, in debian testing

simon
2016-04-07 14:55
but still

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:56
generally for two reasons

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:57
1) they tend to be old, and 2) we cant control the specific version we want

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:58
for instance, both golang 1.6 and protobufs 3 are cutting edge, not exactly likely to be in trusty

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:58
i agree that we should strive to consume distro packages whenever at all possible, however

ghaskins
2016-04-07 14:58
let it be upstream’s headache :wink:

simon
2016-04-07 15:08
obviously for deployment everything has to be packaged anyways

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:08
My opinion has no weight in the vote, but I feel that, it is -important- that it be possible to set up and run OBC, *without* Vagrant/Docker.

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:09
I feel it is *very very very* important.

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:09
as in: it's a deal-breaker for me, based upon my experiences as an admin.

simon
2016-04-07 15:10
yea, i only did that vagrant thing once, and then installed it on my bare system

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:15
(Digging into my past) here's another reason why packages are a deal-breaker.

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:15
Let's imagine a financial institution. Say, MSEG (don't know what the acronym stands for).

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:16
Well, let's not use that name; instead, the example I know of, which is a company named ... champ.

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:16
"Champ" as in a dog's name.

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:16
they have sysadmins

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:16
those syadmins (the ops group) has rules about what has to be on a box. Networking, Virus, security, backup, shared FS, etc.

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:17
This has resulted in 6week lag-times after a box is delivered with OS running, to when apps can be installed.

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:17
When a certain company comes in and says "we have this cloud mgmt solution that will deploy our app-server onto VM base images that we create, so you can deploy your apps and our patches and such automatically", it helps NOTHING

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:18
b/c the ops folks -still- need to customize that image.

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:18
And since this mgmt solution wants to stamp a NEW image (from their own known base) each time, the ops folks have to go SECOND

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:18
but the ops folks want to go FIRST, b/c then they can do things teh way they're used to -- which probably doesn't involve automation.

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:19
what I'm saying is, in many places (like Champ, Inc), distributing a vagrant image isn't a good answer

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:19
each time that vagrant image changes, the ops folks have to reinstall their customizations

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:19
ok, done.

simon
2016-04-07 15:20
i hope everybody agrees that vagrant is not at all considered to be a solution for deployment

ghaskins
2016-04-07 15:20
I look at the current reliance on it as purely a function of project maturity, not an architectural goal

simon
2016-04-07 15:21
then let's talk about the architectural goal :simple_smile:

ghaskins
2016-04-07 15:21
that said, in its current design at least, I think docker is considered part of the deployment environment

ghaskins
2016-04-07 15:22
vagrant is just a convenience for development

simon
2016-04-07 15:22
yes

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:49
whoa ... "vagrant is just a convenience for development"? Really? holy cow.

simon
2016-04-07 15:49
that's how i understood it

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:49
"Let's do it the completely wrong, more-complicated way, b/c it's a convenience for development; we -want- to screw up everybody who isn't doint it PRECISELY the way we want it done".

chetsky
2016-04-07 15:50
"Inconcievable"

georglink
2016-04-07 15:50
has joined #fabric-dev-env

ghaskins
2016-04-07 16:43
I don’t have any problem with vagrant per se: in the devops meme, its a way to create a normalized, repeatable, environment that is conducive to change-management

ghaskins
2016-04-07 16:43
some are annoyed at the weight of firing up a VM, I suppose, but it should be noted that not using a normalized mechanism has its own challenges as well

ghaskins
2016-04-07 16:44
in the ideal world, the logic that goes into supporting vagrant would be more generally consumable for people that dont want to use it, and we are marching in that direction

ghaskins
2016-04-07 16:45
the fact that it isn’t quite there is simply a matter of priorities/maturity

simon
2016-04-07 16:46
yes!

simon
2016-04-07 16:46
e.g. if vagrant used packages built

simon
2016-04-07 16:46
then vagrant works, and the packages are usable outside as well

ghaskins
2016-04-07 16:51
right, that was the “ideal” i mentioned above

ghaskins
2016-04-07 16:53

chetsky

kletkeman
2016-04-07 17:13
Hmmm ... I am just now spinning up my first fresh fabric from hyperledger and noticed this weird behavior change ... the vagrant file previously expected a trailing "/" on GOPATH but that fails now, even though the leading slash has always been there ... the difference being the style of concatenation presumably. I wonder if this is peculiar to Windows systems? This worked in my older vagrantfile: HOST_GOPATH = ENV['GOPATH'] config.vm.synced_folder "#{HOST_GOPATH}/src/github.com/openblockchain/obc-peer", ... This fails in the current vagrantfile: HOST_GOPATH = ENV['GOPATH'] HOST_OBC_PEER_DIR = HOST_GOPATH + "/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric" if not Dir.exists?(HOST_OBC_PEER_DIR) abort("hyperledger directory '" + HOST_OBC_PEER_DIR + "' does not exist") end

kletkeman
2016-04-07 17:14
my gopath being: $ set | grep GOPATH GOPATH='V:\OPENCHAINDEV\OBCPEER\'

kletkeman
2016-04-07 17:14
perhaps I always had it wrong

ghaskins
2016-04-07 17:14

ghaskins
2016-04-07 17:15

ghaskins

2016-04-07 17:20

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:07
@ghaskins still there?

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:07
I can explain about "all wrong" if you'd like

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:07
yep

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:07
uh ... can you do voice?

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:07
maybe easier?

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:07
not right this second, maybe in a bit

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:08
i re-read though, i might have misunderstood you

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:08
ok

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:08
oh, ok

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:08
i thought you were saying vagrant = wrong, but I think maybe you meant the impl was wrong?

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:08
all I really mean is, there are strong reasons for thinking that "images" are "the new hotness, same as teh old hotness"

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:08
because it was vagrant specific without considering non vagrant?

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:08
whereas, "building images b y installing DEBs" is a perfectly fine thing

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:09
oh, ok, thats not where I thought you were going

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:09
no, the particular thing I find objectionable, is using -scripts- to build stuff on images

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:09
there's a long history of trying to make that work

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:09
it's fraught with problems. Whereas, installing piles of native packages to build images, works a treat

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:10
yeah, i think we need to go there eventually

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:10
though I actually like the combo of packages + baseimage because it solves a different problem

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:10
this isn't my reason (b/c I belived this long, long ago) bu: http://techblog.netflix.com/2013/03/ami-creation-with-aminator.html

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:10
that is: distro freeze

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:10
well, I'm fine with there being a base image from a distro

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:11
but what I DO NOT want, is to take that base image, and run scripts to build software, as a way of building the image on which I'll do dev.

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:11
that way lies the death of a thousand InstallShield packages.

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:11
do you object to JIT building or is it the imperative nature of scripts?

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:11
imperative nature of scripts

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:11
for instance, are you fine if instead of scripts it was a declarative engine, like puppet

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:11
?

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:11
puppet runs scripts

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:12
right?

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:12
ok, so .... have you ever read the Debian policy manual about DEBs?

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:12
sort of, but its an declarative language on top

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:12
they lay out careful rules

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:12
the preinst/posting scripts are required to behave in constrained ways

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:12
i am not advocating puppet either per se, just tryign to understand what your issue is

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:12
and they have methods for doing what would otherwise be imperative

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:13
e.g., suppose you have /etc/modules, which is supposd to list all the kernel modules to load

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:13
and multiple packages want to install kernel modules to be loaded

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:13
in RPMs, I've seen 'em (back in the day) each edit the file

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:13
yeah: recipe for disaster

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:13
in Debian (since forever) they've had /etc/modules.d

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:14
and each package drops a file in that dir

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:14
and -then- runs a script, that concats the files, to produce the actual file that is used to load

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:14
same story with /etc/apt/sources.list.d

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:14
the general method is to enusre that anything that is -imperative- is also idempotent

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:14
i agree that this is good, but I am not seeing how that relates to an aversion to scripting

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:14
scripts are never idempotent

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:14
they break in interesting ways

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:15
ok, but that means you shouldnt be against declarative, as that is idempotent

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:15
truly declarative, sure. But "configure ; make" isn't declarative

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:15
but that isnt what puppet does

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:15
-some- use of cfengine can be declarative

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:16
oh, I thought you meant to use puppet to do the build of the vagrant image from sources

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:16
sure, if puppet is used to do very declarative things, with careful idempotence, sure

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:16
no no, i mean to install packages at vagrant-up

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:16
Oh also, I strongly object to cases where the actions are really a -sequence- (instead of a list of actions with prereqs that get sorted into a topological order)

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:16
oh, sure -- puppet doing dpkg -i is fine fine fine

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:17
ok, then we are on the same page

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:17
right, so bash is imperative and would model a sequence

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:17
right. Ditto Ant

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:17
ever used that?

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:17
I used to rail against ant

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:17
puppet is declarative, so you could just say “this is the package inventory” and it will reconcile current state with desired state

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:17
yeah, that's fine

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:18
it would have more value to someone like @bcbrock who is running his own environment

bcbrock
2016-04-07 19:18
has joined #fabric-dev-env

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:18
for the vagrant dev-env, the declarative script would still more or less need to install each package each time

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:18
yeah, I'm cool with that. just want -packages-

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:19
but for someone maintaining their own environment, it would only reconcile their current state with the required state

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:19
ok, we are in agreement i think

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:19
to others point, we do need to make the package generation mechanism approachable

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:19
right now, the launchpad setup leaves some things to be desired

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:20
I got it to work, but only out of sheer will and past experience

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:23
Hmm .... I've never worked with launchpad. I'd be happy with just generating packages on a build-server, and serving them from some web-server (setting up APT distro archives is a walk in the park).

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:24
It's not trivial to generate DEB source-packages. But I'd be OK with "check install".

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:24
to generate the DEBs

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:24
I just don't want to have some non-reproducible mechanism that requires fricken' images

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:25
or, more precisely, I'm happy if the unwashed use images. I ain't gonna. Never seen a good use for images in a dev environment

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:29
you def do not want to be hand-building the packages, especially with some of the hosted options out there like http://build.opensuse.org

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:29
they do a ton of stuff that is a complete PITA for the hand-built model

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:29
like, cleanroom build, multi-arch support, and transitive rebuilds

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:29
oh, I agree COMPLETELY. But if it's a choice between hand-building+hosting, or scripting, I'll take hand-building

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:29
cleanroom build!

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:29
yes!

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:29
gotcha, and agree

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:30
yes, that used to be _so_ nasty to do by hand, at least with RPMs

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:30
basically, the hosted environments set up a ephemeral environment that is barebones each build, so if you dont list your deps properly you find out right away

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:31
-yes-!

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:31
that is what I want

chetsky
2016-04-07 19:31
no "inadvertently, something got built the wrong way"

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:32
right

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:32
the transitive rebuild thing is super cool, too

ghaskins
2016-04-07 19:32
if you dep on X Y and Z, and one of those gets rebuilt, your package gets scheduled to rebuild after it finishes

kletkeman
2016-04-15 19:34
OOPS ... please ignore this message ... I had one vestigial OPENCHAIN command line reference ... sigh

kletkeman
2016-04-15 19:58
: I have a new question, and this one is not the result of a brain fart (I hope) ... I am running the peer and my contract in sandbox mode and deploy and query both seem to work, except I'm getting no body in the response. So I can't see the name returned from the deploy (which should be mycc) and I can't see the query results coming back from the query. But it does show them in the debug log for the peer ... 19:56:22.555 [rest] processChaincodeInvokeOrQuery -> INFO 13e Successfuly queried chaincode: {"version":"3.0.5","nickname":"TEST001","activeAssets":{}} 19:56:22.555 [rest] ProcessChaincode -> INFO 13f REST sucessfully query chaincode: {"jsonrpc":"2.0","result":{"status":"OK","message":"{\"version\":\"3.0.5\",\"nickname\":\"TEST001\",\"activeAssets\":{}}"},"id":null}

kletkeman
2016-04-15 20:06
: Answered: If you have an "id", you can see the response. If not, you never get the response. The peer code must be conflating the normal response from any rest message with the asynch callback and thus without the id it simply does not send anything at all. I note this as a probable bug because the postman scripts we were sent that play with example02 also do not use ids and thus should not work.

ajlopez
2016-04-15 22:06
has joined #fabric-dev-env

nathonline
2016-04-17 18:11

cbf
2016-04-17 20:04
has joined #fabric-dev-env

mark.moir
2016-04-17 22:28
has joined #fabric-dev-env

sheehan
2016-04-18 02:26
Hi - there have been requests to remove the `-o peer` flag when building the peer as it’s causing confusion for two reasons 1) The documentation does not always refer to the binary as `peer` 2) People naturally use `go build` without the flag and end up with a binary named `fabric` that does not match the instructions in most documentation. I posted a proposal at https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/issues/1131 which I have already discussed with @binhn. Post any questions/comments/ideas in this issue. Thanks.

ghaskins
2016-04-18 12:49
vagrant runs these, as should your homegrown setup

ghaskins
2016-04-18 13:28
the ordering doesn’t matter, though you should call both technically

ghaskins
2016-04-18 13:28
I need to find a way to unify the versioning such that one source (e.g. fabric.git/version.txt) governs all the logic

ghaskins
2016-04-18 13:29
right now, you’ll have to explicitly request the version you want (right now “0.0.9”)

ghaskins
2016-04-18 13:29

ghaskins

you want the one in ./scripts/provision/docker.sh, not ./devenv/baseimage

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-04-18 13:41

jacksonlim
2016-04-19 08:27
Folks, I tried running "peer peer" and got a permission error: "[db] CreateDB -> ERRO 00b Error calling os.MkdirAll for directory path [/var/hyperledger/production/db]: mkdir /var/hyperledger: permission denied". Do I need to change the program? Or is there any work-around? Thanks for any suggestions.

jacksonlim
2016-04-19 09:19
Solved. I got around the problem by "sudo passwd root" to get root access, then changing permission of "/var" using "chmod 777 /var" to allow access by vagrant.

simon
2016-04-19 09:51
the packer scripts to build the docker image don't set the environment variables properly

simon
2016-04-19 09:52
`scripts/common/setup.sh` writes the env vars to `/etc/profile.d/goroot.sh`, which is not read for non-login shells

simon
2016-04-19 09:52
how is this working for anybody?

shiva
2016-04-19 10:28
has joined #fabric-dev-env

simon
2016-04-19 12:46
i finally managed to build a docker image that works

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:47
@simon: read that comment I referenced yesterday

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:47
the env vars are processed at provisioning time

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:48
ideally I could have done that at baseimage creation, but packer lacked the ability to express certain docker operations

simon
2016-04-19 12:48
yes

simon
2016-04-19 12:48
like env vars

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:48
precisely

simon
2016-04-19 12:48
so when do i use the provisioning stuff?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:48
its roughly 1:1 with when you would do a vagrant destroy/up

simon
2016-04-19 12:49
so vagrant up runs the provisioning?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:50
yes

simon
2016-04-19 12:50
this is quite obscure

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:50
not really, you always needed an environment, and there has always been a link between what the fabric needs in your environment

simon
2016-04-19 12:51
sure

simon
2016-04-19 12:52
this provisioning script is a nasty hack

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:52
if you use the prescribed method, you don’t even need to think about it…if you don’t, you get to keep both pieces when it breaks

simon
2016-04-19 12:53
yea

simon
2016-04-19 12:53
that's not how we should set it up tho

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:53
but I understand the sentiment

simon
2016-04-19 12:53
or do we expect people to run deployments in vagrant?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:53
open to suggestion on improvement

simon
2016-04-19 12:54
i'd have one Dockerfile which uses the devenv scripts to build the right image

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:54
no, we don’t, but you have to consider the entire picture….we were always vagrant dependent (at least since I joined)….there were some things broken that were fixed with those changes, while introducing some other unpleasantries

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:55
so you can just consider the new unpleasantries, but the entire picture of things that were also fixed

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:55
and formulate a plan to advance things further

simon
2016-04-19 12:55
yea i haven't used vagrant except once to see that it works

simon
2016-04-19 12:56
at minimum, we should have a README describing how images get created

simon
2016-04-19 12:56
does vagrant use packer?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:56
i think we do have at least that

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:56
yes

simon
2016-04-19 12:56
inside vagrant?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:56
you can, but I dont

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:57
I typically run packer directly in OSX

simon
2016-04-19 12:57
so when i go to devenv and say "vagrant up", how does packer get involved?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:57
bottom line, I fully agree that we shouldnt assume vagrant, and fully agree there is some awkwardness introduced recently

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:58
but just consider we did push the ball forward in a few dimensions that shouldnt be overlooked, and there is clearly more work to be done

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:58
packer is only used to create the baseimages that are in vagrant/docker hosted servers

simon
2016-04-19 12:58
aha

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:59
when you do “cd devenv/baseimage; make"

simon
2016-04-19 12:59
so that vagrant base image is used for vagrant up?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:59
yes

simon
2016-04-19 12:59
ah i see

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:59
same for Docker

simon
2016-04-19 12:59
right

simon
2016-04-19 12:59
i'm wondering whether we should use a Dockerfile, instead of packer

ghaskins
2016-04-19 12:59
we used packer to unify the baseimage so they are the same (functionally)

simon
2016-04-19 13:00
dockerfile just calling the same scripts

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:00
yeah, I had been wondering that too

simon
2016-04-19 13:00
like the packer config does right now

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:00
was thinking the same

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:00
it would at least solve the envvar issue

simon
2016-04-19 13:00
yes

simon
2016-04-19 13:00
and everybody can just go and say docker build

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:00
thing is, the bigger problem is the version coupling and that has nothing to do with packer

simon
2016-04-19 13:01
what version coupling?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:01
well, for repeatability we dont want to just assume you always pull :latest

simon
2016-04-19 13:01
right

simon
2016-04-19 13:01
i was wondering that

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:01
so there is a tight coupling of versions where the vagrant/devenv/whatever pulls a specific docker image

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:02
that is what drove the provision/docker.sh more than anything

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:02
the alternative is that every Dockerfile had a :0.0.9 tag in it

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:02
but that looked really ugly

simon
2016-04-19 13:02
or that we push a latest to the docker registry?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:03
it also turns out that it is quite convenient to be able to augment the docker base at provisioning time (for instance, I need a JRE for my work)

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:03
pushing :latest to the docker registry is precisely what I think we need to avoid

simon
2016-04-19 13:03
why?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:04
because you create a situation where the environment is not repeatable

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:04
take sha X today, and sha X tomorrow, and they might have a different docker image

simon
2016-04-19 13:04
because somebody pushed a new image?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:04
right

simon
2016-04-19 13:04
ah yes

simon
2016-04-19 13:04
so then we should tie down the image version

simon
2016-04-19 13:05
because clearly you do want to use a different image :simple_smile:

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:05
heh, yes, thats what docker.sh does

simon
2016-04-19 13:05
so the core.yml should carry a docker image tag

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:05
the images in dockerhub are versioned, the script pulls the specific one it wants

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:05
yes, you can do that but note there are dozens of places today that have their own dockerfiles

simon
2016-04-19 13:06
yes

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:06
so its not exactly trivial

simon
2016-04-19 13:06
that is unfortunate anyways

simon
2016-04-19 13:06
i don't like that the dockerfiles live in yaml

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:06
and the common.sh provisioning thing is quite convenient (IMO)

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:06
the envvar thing is just a hack to deal with limitations of packer, i agree

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:06
that could go away

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:06
but I would hate to lose the common.sh provisioning

simon
2016-04-19 13:07
but you could as well maintain your own base image with jre, based on a specific version of the obc base image?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:07
you could, but by that argument you could also put everything in baseimage for vagrant too

simon
2016-04-19 13:07
i don't quite get the whole run-a-script-to-modify-a-docker-image... that seems to be counter to the docker idea?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:08
well, the progression of things was:

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:08
we used to do everything at “provisioning” including building third party software that wasnt in ubuntu/trusty in the right version

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:08
that was painful for a variety of reasons

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:08
we could go completely opposite, put everything in baseimage and just use it (vagrant and docker)

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:09
but that has its own limitations as you then need to spin new base images for even the smallest iterative change

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:09
so, the solution currently employed is a hybrid: the expensive-to-build-and-not-packaged-in-ubuntu stuff is in baseimage, other stuff gets added at provisioning

simon
2016-04-19 13:09
now i get why i didn't find the docs on provision

simon
2016-04-19 13:10
because they're not in the README.md

simon
2016-04-19 13:10
but in docs/dev-env

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:10
so, with the mindset of the hybrid model, I tried to unify vagrant/docker so they are sourced from the same basic process

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:11
with the idea that other environments (such as travis or your custom setup) could also consume ./scripts/provision in a similar manner

simon
2016-04-19 13:12
oh well

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:12
its not perfect, though I would argue its better than the original “do everything inline” model for a variety of reasons

simon
2016-04-19 13:12
remember the times when you could build a full netbsd image using `sh build.sh`?

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:13
heh, was never a netbsd user but I appreciate the sentiment

simon
2016-04-19 13:13
all you need is a reasonable shell, and a compiler - not even sure about make

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:14
well, to be fair, it would be kind of like that if you used vagrant :wink:

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:14
brew install vagrant virtualbox; vagrant up

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:20
anyway, back to your original point about dockerfiles in yaml: cleaning that up would improve things

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:21
regardless of whether we need docker.sh or not

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:22
I would argue that the tight versioning is critically important, and I would vote to retain some kind of common.sh type thing if at all possible….envvars can go if we can solve the packer-induced problem

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:22
so keep those things in mind in whatever proposal you might have

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:23
one way to solve the first is if there was some central definition of “FROM” somewhere

simon
2016-04-19 13:26
yes

simon
2016-04-19 13:27
that's what i suggested

simon
2016-04-19 13:27
have that tag in core.yml

simon
2016-04-19 13:27
and you could build an image with JRE, and override that tag

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:27
yep, so have “0.0.9” as a tag in core.yaml, and the subordinate processes should pull that in

simon
2016-04-19 13:27
i'd put the whole string there

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:27
subordinate processes that build Dockefiles I mean

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:28
i see, thats fine too

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:28
if you do it as a version number, though, we can probably consume it outside of docker

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:28
meaning vagrant/travis/etc could read core.yaml

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:29
maybe that becomes less important, not sure

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:29
have to think about it more

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:29
certainly keeping vagrant/docker in sync makes sense though

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:29
so that right there could be enough to justify it

simon
2016-04-19 13:34
oh hilarious, i just wanted to do a vagrant up on a virtual machine here - vagrant version too low

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:36
yeah, i cant remember the min version, but I had to brew update a few of my machines before I could work with obc

simon
2016-04-19 13:44
yea, that doesn't work in many settings

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:46
well, bottom line is the only supported config right now is a recent version of vagrant/virtualbox

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:46
others may work, and other environments are certainly needed going forward

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:46
but that is where it is today

kletkeman
2016-04-19 13:49
@ghaskins: @simon: As a Windows user, and without the obvious long backgrounds you each have in working with these tools, I'd just like to add my thought that vagrant has been a joy to use. Knowing that the environment is identical to those used on the project itself has allowed me to concentrate only on what I was working with and not how. The changeover to the new script in hyperledger caused me a moment's glitch, but I was back up and running not long after. I do almost nothing in the native Windows environment. I use the "FORWARD_DOCKER_PORTS='true' vagrant reload --provision" command a lot when I am experimenting with folder mapping etc ... a very handy environment. I do the vagrant up variant whenever I feel I have corrupted my database or want a full refresh.

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:52
@kletkeman: thats good feedback, thanks, and that is certainly the promise/idea of vagrant…the biggest niggle in the overall process is I agree vagrant is not a deployment solution so we need to consider those requirements too

ghaskins
2016-04-19 13:54
The people that are opting to create a devenv outside of vagrant are probably just causing themselves unnecessary pain, but I understand where they are coming from and the bottom line is we need to consider non-vagrant for production so why not make non-vagrant for dev as easy as possible while we are at it

kletkeman
2016-04-19 13:55
yes, of course ... I did read the whole thread, but was struck by the fact that a lot of people work directly on Linux and Mac and so might not realize how important vagrant is to the minority on Windows ... that struck me especially hard when the script was adjusted for hyperledger to not run on Windows ... your version fixed that, but it just goes to show that Windows is uncommon ...

kletkeman
2016-04-19 13:57
by the way, IMO the advantages of vagrant (total refresh in moments) pretty much outweigh that feeling of just working on the native OS ... but maybe I'd change my tune if I ever got a Mac ... who knows ...

arnaud
2016-04-19 18:14
Let me add my voice to what @kletkeman said. I'm on Windows too (although with cygwin :-) and always thought it was nice to know we all had the same set up.

arnaud
2016-04-19 18:15
but of course I'm not against making it easier for people to do without vagrant if they prefer

sheehan
2016-04-19 21:58
I have a PR that moves `main.go` and `core.yaml` under the peer folder. See https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/pull/1165. This allows us to run `go build` without the need for the `-o peer` flag. I’m sure this will impact some people so let me know if you have any questions.

cbf
2016-04-19 22:54
@arnaud: @kletkeman I don’t think that because some are making it easier for those on linux to run natively means that the vagrant dev env will be deprecated. I think some are just looking for something with less overhead. Certainly, anything real will be run without Vagrant, so we definitely need both…

cbf
2016-04-19 22:55
of course, this is open source and the rule of thumb is: you have an itch, scratch it - if the vagrant build is important, make this known (as you have done) but also offer to help maintain to ensure it’s longevity

arnaud
2016-04-19 23:27
@cbf: fair enough

binhn
2016-04-20 14:03
with the Latest commit 488d266 issue #1131 — moving main.go to fabric/peer. You may encounter the problem in vagrant: ```vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.0.9-2457c97:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric$ cd peer/ -bash: cd: peer/: Not a directory``` It seems vagrant caches the `peer` exe file. The solution is to run: ```vagrant halt vagrant up ```

2016-04-21 16:03

sheehan

sheehan
2016-04-21 16:15

ghaskins
2016-04-22 13:55

bcbrock
2016-04-22 13:55
Docker doesn’t know about arch

bcbrock
2016-04-22 13:55
You can pull an x86 image to power and docker will try to run it

ghaskins
2016-04-22 13:55
that is my understanding as well, and the handling of it is a bit adhoc it seems

ghaskins
2016-04-22 13:56
for instance, “ubuntu/trusty64” is x86, and “s390/ubuntu” is s390

simon
2016-04-22 13:57

ghaskins

jasmeet
2016-04-25 10:11

jasmeet
2016-04-25 10:12
default: SSH auth method: private key Timed out while waiting for the machine to boot. This means that Vagrant was unable to communicate with the guest machine within the configured ("config.vm.boot_timeout" value) time period. If you look above, you should be able to see the error(s) that Vagrant had when attempting to connect to the machine. These errors are usually good hints as to what may be wrong. If you're using a custom box, make sure that networking is properly working and you're able to connect to the machine. It is a common problem that networking isn't setup properly in these boxes. Verify that authentication configurations are also setup properly, as well. If the box appears to be booting properly, you may want to increase the timeout ("config.vm.boot_timeout") value. Whats the command to increase the timeout ("config.vm.boot_timeout") value.

jasmeet
2016-04-25 10:52
@cbf: @ghaskins @muralisr Please guide !!

nits7sid
2016-04-26 13:04
how do I set up development network with 8 peers?

tuand
2016-04-26 13:06
you can extend what's in devnet-setup . Alternatively, take a look at the docker-compose files in either ./bddtests or ./consensus/docker-compose-files

tuand
2016-04-26 13:08

kurtz
2016-05-03 14:15
Are there any instructions on how to run a fabric peer as a docker container, outside of the vagrant dev environment? I'm able to run the peer but I'm having issues starting contract containers.

simon
2016-05-03 14:17
you need to allow docker containers contacting the docker daemon

kurtz
2016-05-03 14:18
Yes, I have that step down. Specifically, the contract container fails on the entry command. It seems like GOROOT & GOPATH are not set as environment variables. GOROOT/bin and GOPATH/bin are also not appended to the PATH environment variable.

kurtz
2016-05-03 14:19
I guess I can modify the core.yaml to set these, not sure if anyone else has already done the dirty work.

kurtz
2016-05-03 14:21
Also in case anyone else is trying to do this as well, I had to manually pull openblockchain/baseimage:0.0.9 and tag it to latest... Seems like the devenv setup takes care of that.

jyellick
2016-05-03 14:34
@kurtz: Sorry for the pain. FYI, the rationale for not pushing the latest tag, is so that people on older versions of the dev env and code don't get their environment broken when a new image is pushed. If you're interested in documenting your discoveries and submitting a PR for it, I'm sure others would find it helpful.

ghaskins
2016-05-03 14:43
@kurtz: the current mechanism uses the script in ./scripts/provision/docker.sh to do all that you mentioned above

ghaskins
2016-05-03 14:43
im trying to formulate a design that makes this less error prone

ghaskins
2016-05-03 14:44
one thing we could do is to try to coalesce all the fragmented Dockerfile definitions spread around in the yaml to perhaps be references to a Dockerfile and/or YAML key

ghaskins
2016-05-03 14:45
then that one definition could do the dirty work (pull 0.0.9, set the env, run common.sh, etc)

ghaskins
2016-05-03 14:45
but one problem is how to deal with relative paths in different environments

ghaskins
2016-05-03 14:45
have to step out, bbiab

kurtz
2016-05-03 14:50
Ahhh OK, I see what you're doing now, I didn't really understand it at first. Thanks for the script reference.

kurtz
2016-05-03 15:04
Just curious, where can I find the openblockchain/baseimage 0.0.9 Dockerfile?

jyellick
2016-05-03 15:37
@kurtz: You may want to wait on @ghaskins as he is the expert here, but you can take a look at `http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/devenv/baseimage`, there is a `packer.json` and a `README.md` there. In a nutshell, packer is used to build both the vagrant baseimage, and the docker baseimage, in an attempt to keep those images in lockstep.

jyellick
2016-05-03 19:10
@arnaud: Not sure if you had things working before, but my money would be on some sort of interaction between the Windows filesystem and VirtualBox, as the source tree is actually backed by your OS's filesystem. If you've had this working before, it may not be relevant, but what filesystem are you using to store your development root? In particular, if it is an older filesystem which does not support many file attributes (say, fat32)then I think this could cause problems. What do the permissions look like for the other elements in the tree? (Also in the same boat as @sheehan here, just guessing.)

arnaud
2016-05-03 19:28
@jyellick: that's the weird thing, I've been using this set up for weeks without problems

arnaud
2016-05-03 19:29
I have no idea what changed between yesterday and today!

arnaud
2016-05-03 19:30
although I say "without problems" but I have had some mode changes that I didn't quite understand before

arnaud
2016-05-03 19:30
but nothing like that

arnaud
2016-05-03 19:31
it was more like some files ended up with the exec bit on

arnaud
2016-05-03 19:33
interestingly I can't change the access rights I get on the peer exec file within vagrant or my windows shell (cygwin actually)

arnaud
2016-05-03 19:33
the only way to change it is to use the windows desktop explorer and go change the access rights through security property tab

arnaud
2016-05-03 19:33
if I change it I can then run the program without problems

arnaud
2016-05-03 19:34
this is beyond my level of understanding I have to admit

arnaud
2016-05-03 19:35
but for what it's worth it's an NTFS filesystem

arnaud
2016-05-03 19:37

arnaud

jyellick
2016-05-03 19:40
Hmmm, yeah, sounds like you're on the right track, I think I have seen some Vagrant bugs around what user VirtualBox ends up executing as, interacting with certain Windows security policies, good luck!

2016-05-03 21:56

ghaskins
2016-05-03 21:58

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-05-03 21:59

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-05-03 22:01

ghaskins
2016-05-03 22:02
so im speculating that your docker is out of date

ghaskins
2016-05-03 22:02
that _should_ have added ‘java’ to the $PATH within the container if it was run

ghaskins
2016-05-03 22:03

bcbrock
2016-05-03 22:03
I was thinking about your rhetorical question - why not just git clone && go build. Why do we need Docker anyway? Why not just run chaincodes as processes with assigned ports. It would make things so mush easier and faster.

ghaskins
2016-05-03 22:04

ghaskins
2016-05-03 22:04

ghaskins
2016-05-03 22:05
but neither here nor there, there are lots of ways to solve this problem

ghaskins
2016-05-03 22:05
if the goal is to eliminate docker, there are plenty of options

arnaud
2016-05-04 18:18

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:18

ghaskins

ghaskins

2016-05-04 18:20

@ghaskins My experience is that when rocksdb is installed “correctly” you don’t even need the CGO_FLAGS

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:52

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:52

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:52
or are you saying you can get rid of all of them?

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:53
what I did was get rid of the need for -L/-I, but the others are still present

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:53
(getting rid of all would be most welcome)

bcbrock
2016-05-04 18:53
There is no CGO_* in my env. I just type “go build” and it works

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:53
nice!

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:54
what are you using to manage the deps like snappy?

bcbrock
2016-05-04 18:54
Probably because all of the compression libs are also installed correectly, it knows where to find them

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:54
i see, i suppose its possible that once I did the ldconfig stuff that was also the case but never tried it

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:55
anyway, long story short, you shouldnt be impacted by the decision

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:55
the ones that would be impacted are those installing rocksdb in a custom path

bcbrock
2016-05-04 18:55
I only learned by accident

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:55
are you sure its not set in your env?

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:56
(thats how we did in within vagrant for instance)

bcbrock
2016-05-04 18:57
I’m 99% sure

bcbrock
2016-05-04 18:57

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:57
cool, ill look into it

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:57
it might be that whats there is superfluous, i never tried

bcbrock
2016-05-04 18:58
That was my story, I realized one day I was not defining that stuff and it was working

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:59
nice when things work in your favor

ghaskins
2016-05-04 18:59
speaking of, a slightly related story is behind why we set the CGO_CFLAGS=“ "

bcbrock
2016-05-04 19:00
This Ubuntu system does define LD_LIBARY_PATH to point to where the compression libs are stored

bcbrock
2016-05-04 19:00
I don’t think I am doing that explicitly

ghaskins
2016-05-04 19:00
generally, thats a good thing

ghaskins
2016-05-04 19:00
if you _dont_ set it, it turns on CGO compiler optimizations

ghaskins
2016-05-04 19:00
(at the expense of a slower build)

bcbrock
2016-05-04 19:01
Actually I am doing it but it is redundant

ghaskins
2016-05-04 19:02
during some refactoring, we found the build was suddenly slower..root caused it to the notion that “CGO_CFLAGS=-I…” had the side effect of disabling optimizations

ghaskins
2016-05-04 19:02
so when we cleaned that up, suddenly the build was 2x slower

bcbrock
2016-05-09 19:21
@ghaskins - Thank you for including the arch in the tag

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:23
@bcbrock: of course! does that satisfy your concern in that regard?

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:24
theres probably more work to be done on the baseimage side to make it more friendly to actually building different $arch, but at least the consumer side supports it now

bcbrock
2016-05-09 19:24
Since you asked - I have a concern but have not had time to research it - who/what is repsonsible for maintaining these images? Does it require “packer” (Again, haven’t looked into it)

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:25
well, who/what I can’t answer. I am certainly willing to help in whatever way I can. As far as “require packer”, the short answer is “it does today” but I am seriously contemplating decoupling the packer engine from the docker baseimage

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:26
i still think the notion of having the different base images derive from a single source of truth is important, but the vast majority of that happens because of the scripts in ./devenv/baseimage/scripts and has little to do with packer

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:27
and packer might be limiting us in several dimensions w.r.t $arch

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:28
its probably still fine to leave it for vagrant generation, and there are some nice things we could build on in the future such as AMI or Azure images

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:28
but as far as docker, its value is limited

bcbrock
2016-05-09 19:28
@bsmita is one of the IBM’ers who will be managing POWER; Mentioning her here for reference

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:29
ok, cool

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:29
I know @vpaprots is working on Z as well

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:30
right now, i am thinking the simplest path forward is to gut the docker specific parts from packer.json and just go with a Dockerfile that calls the scripts

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:30
that _should_ compile on whatever native architecture supports the basics of docker/git/gcc, etc

ghaskins
2016-05-09 19:30
which I would imagine should give us the coverage we need

ghaskins
2016-05-10 18:32
@bcbrock @bsmita @vpaprots FYI: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/compare/master...ghaskins:multi-arch-support-preview

ghaskins
2016-05-10 18:33
in this branch, any of the makefile targets that depend on baseimage will now dynamically build the base image if its not found on dockerhub, as I mentioned in the other thread

ghaskins
2016-05-10 18:33
this means dockerhub is merely an optimization now, instead of gating the critical path

ghaskins
2016-05-10 18:34
that said, there is still some work to do for supporting non-x86

ghaskins
2016-05-10 18:34
for one thing, https://github.com/ghaskins/hyperledger-fabric/blob/multi-arch-support-preview/baseimage/Makefile#L8

ghaskins
2016-05-10 18:35
and https://github.com/ghaskins/hyperledger-fabric/blob/multi-arch-support-preview/baseimage/scripts/common/setup.sh#L56

ghaskins
2016-05-10 18:35
comments welcome

bcbrock
2016-05-10 19:21
@ghaskins I’m using your Makefile now. There is a redundancy in Go testing I think. You require the peer image to run the unit tests, but the unit tests also recreate the peer image.

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:22
yeah, i am torn on what to do about that

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:22
i have the dep b/c I spin up a peer to satisfy the peer test

bcbrock
2016-05-10 19:22
Why do you need to run teh peer in Docker?

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:22
to clarify, i spin up a peer via docker

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:23
technically, I dont specifically require it but it seemed like a neat way a) ensure that the peer ran in a clean-room and b) that it left no garbage laying around (such as in /var), and to a lesser extent c) interfere with other activity on the system

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:23
but the (c) is not entirely true since I had to map 30303

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:23
but I figure that is something that could be cleaned up eventually

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:24
the seeming double-dep is annoying, I agree, but I looked at the cost and it was like 28s of overhead

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:24
so I figured, its not a big deal

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:25
(I havent tested to see if that accelerates the later test that happens as part of the unit-test…if it does, that 28s is amortized later)

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:25
but even if it doesnt, it didnt seem like a huge deal for the isolation gained

bcbrock
2016-05-10 19:26
It’s in the eye of the beholder :simple_smile:

bcbrock
2016-05-10 19:26
Hence my gripe

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:26
I suppose thats true

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:27
i am fine with a patch that launches the peer directly as long as it cleans up after

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:27
i think the problem isnt docker per se as much as how we specifically build the docker image

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:27
but I know how you feel about docker in general :wink:

bcbrock
2016-05-10 19:29
I hope to be Docker free by Friday

bcbrock
2016-05-10 19:30
Should I expect source dependencies to work inthis Makefile? If I modify a .go file and say make unit-test will everything get rebuilt

bcbrock
2016-05-10 19:30
?

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:35
I _think_ so, based on two things

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:35
#1) unit tests do not rely on go-build afaik

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:36
#2) building the binaries was switched to using PHONY+go-build per our conversation, essentially delegating prerequisite freshness to go-tool

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:36
the thing that generally wont work magically is if you switch your git HEAD

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:37
for that, I still recommend a clean+rebuild cycle

bcbrock
2016-05-10 19:37
I see, OK

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:37
the detection for when images need to be rebuilt is very coarse, so its best to just explicitly clean it

ghaskins
2016-05-10 19:38
of course, images generally dont need to be rebuilt often…but problem is you’d have to keep track of when they do unless you just use the more draconian policy of “move HEAD?, clean"

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:16
@bcbrock: one thing I wanted to mention about the docker-based peer: note that I think the majority of the 28s is coming from the go-build of the peer itself

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:16
and note that as it stands right now, switching the deps for unit-test from peer-image to peer is still going to take ~28s

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:17
we might be able to improve this with go-install (since I think it caches object files), but also note that we might be able to make similar improvements on the docker side

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:18
long story short, i don’t think its docker per se, but rather the methods we are using to build things

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:19
You mean rebuilding the peer from scratch from within Docker?

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:19
(The 28s)

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:19
yes, i think that is what happens (I havent looked actually, i am speculating)

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:19
i do know the go-build takes in that same range of time

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:20
every time we invoke it, regardless of prerequisite updates, as I dont think go-build does object caching

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:20
I think it does try to do something smart; It has a -a flag to force recmopilation of unchanged packages

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:21
i guess the question is, why is it always ~28s?

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:21
perhaps that is the quickest it can ascertain state

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:21
i assumed it was rebuilding everyting

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:21
everything

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:22
I never timed it before; Trying now...

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:23
22s, 17s for “go build"

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:23
47 s for “go build -a"

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:23
ok, interesting

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:24
but if anything, thats bad news for your issue with the unit-test deps :wink:

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:24
17s might be the minimum penalty

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:24
what are you seeing for the peer-image target time?

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:24
We need to do our own dependncy checking in the Makefile

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:25
we _can_ but its not trivial nor cheap

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:25
but that would solve the problem, yes

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:25
Hard to belieg it woudl take 17 seconds

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:25
i cant argue with that

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:25
you are probably right, i will look into it

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:26
i think my concern was that I would likely have to incur the penalties of something like $(shell find . -name “*.go”) for all targets

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:26
but if that runs sufficently fast, who cares

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:27
0.5 seconds

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:27
Once it has the directoruy cached

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:28
Not fair - writing to /dev/null. Maybe 2 or 3 seconds

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:29
ok, it seems like its plausible

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:33
I just said make clean; make peer-image. I’m surprised that it is doing so much work

bcbrock
2016-05-10 22:33
Reinstalling all packages ()into a container I assume)

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:33
no, it shouldnt need to install packages

cbf
2016-05-10 22:33
@ghaskins: I was looking at what it would take to do a build only if some source file changed

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:33
i think the meat of it is that its building the peer

cbf
2016-05-10 22:33
right now, it doesn’t do that

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:34
@cbf yeah, it doesnt directly…its possibly using go-tool object caching, TBD

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:34
we decided on the first pass it was best to let the go-tool figure it out, but I think we could certainly experiment with being more intelligent about it

cbf
2016-05-10 22:34
yep understood

cbf
2016-05-10 22:35
but we should definitely look to continuously improve

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:35
its certainly fairly easy to use things like $(shell find ..) to build a list of pre-requisites and then we can drop the PHONY: peer

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:36
the risk is whether we can get it “right”…normally pretty easy for things like C++ but go is a little different being partially managed

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:36
but certainly a good idea in general to try

cbf
2016-05-10 22:36
yes, I was researching that earlier

cbf
2016-05-10 22:36
looking for some precendent

cbf
2016-05-10 22:36
precedent

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:43
not that I exhaustively looked, but go seems to be in this weird limbo in that regard

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:43
the go-tooling was clearly not designed to replace something like make, yet it seems almost all projects rely solely on it

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:44
i think if you had a pure go codebase, perhaps its not too bad to treat it that way

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:44
but once you have things like docker, protobufs, etc, it gets awkward fast

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:45
so, its the long way of saying, we are likely in relatively uncharted waters

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:48
but I suspect this will be rapidly changing even among pure go environments…things like go-generate are pseudo build hooks, but its not very well thought out

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:49
and there are some niche libraries that try to improve on go-generate, but they had their own limitations

ghaskins
2016-05-10 22:49
but long story short, I do not think we are alone in this pain

cbf
2016-05-10 22:56
+1

bcbrock
2016-05-10 23:04
@ghaskins I think the ‘clean’ target is too agressive; It should not remove .baseimage_dummy

bcbrock
2016-05-10 23:04
That’s what’s causing everything to be rebuilt I think

ghaskins
2016-05-10 23:05
my concern is that any changes to the definition of the baseimage (such as in ./scripts/provision/common.sh) would not be picked up

ghaskins
2016-05-10 23:05
maybe that should be dist-clean level?

ghaskins
2016-05-10 23:06
i suppose we could add its prerequisites and let make do its thing

bcbrock
2016-05-10 23:06
To me it is a rare event to rebuild the base docker, but I wipe out the blockchain database before every test. So I would prefer a different type of clean for the docker image

ghaskins
2016-05-10 23:07
e.g. baseimage: ./devenv/baseimage/* ./scripts/provision/*

bcbrock
2016-05-10 23:07
OK,

ghaskins
2016-05-10 23:08
i have no problem with hooking baseimage to the dist-clean level, though I still think cleaning the base image is advised when moving HEAD

ghaskins
2016-05-10 23:08
at least until we can find a bullet proof way to detect when it really does need to be rebuilt

ghaskins
2016-05-10 23:08
perhaps the above is it

bcbrock
2016-05-10 23:11

cbf
2016-05-10 23:12

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:00
@simon: we rebranded the docker image to the HL, I suspect you still have obc branded in your cache

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:00
run “docker images” and post it to me in a DM

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:12
@simon: in short, run “docker images”…if you have “openblockchain/baseimage” your cache is stale

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:13
i advise people to run “make clean peer” any time they adjust HEAD, it will make sure you system is kept up to date

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:13
for now anyway, until we make the prerequisite detection more intelligent

simon
2016-05-11 12:16
my docker images is miles long

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:17
grep for openblockchain and hyperledger

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:17
my guess is you have the former but not the latter

simon
2016-05-11 12:17
yea possible

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:17
if so, “make clean peer” will rebuild it for you

simon
2016-05-11 12:17
why clean peer?

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:18
i was just about to say: “make clean baseimage” is the shortest path

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:18
but I figured you wanted the peer built too (the clean will nuke the peer binary)

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:18
peer is a superset of baseimage, since it depends on it

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:19
im sorry, its “base-image” with a dash

ghaskins
2016-05-11 12:20
note that I do not attempt to docker rmi the openblockchain/* stuff, you can do that at will after the cache is rebuilt

2016-05-11 12:51

2016-05-11 20:30

ghaskins
2016-05-11 20:47
thats expected

ghaskins
2016-05-11 20:48
its basically that go-test does an oppotunistic grab of all source without knowing whether it has any test code, and then makes that report when it doesnt find any

ghaskins
2016-05-11 20:48
the only ones you need to worry about are the explicit FAILs

2016-05-11 21:26

2016-05-12 17:51

ghaskins
2016-05-12 17:52
