vpaprots
2016-05-12 17:52
probably update the baseimage to 0.0.10?

ghaskins
2016-05-12 17:52
@vpaprots: oh i see, yes

ghaskins
2016-05-12 17:52
that would be good

sheehan
2016-05-12 17:52
@vpaprots: does the PORTABLE=1 flag not make it compatible with all platforms?

ghaskins
2016-05-12 17:53
if you are pulling a newer version of rocks specifically for s390, but the other platforms could use it too, i am fine with it being left non-conditional

ghaskins
2016-05-12 17:53
as far as I know, PORTABLE=1 only affects the compiler optimizations for a given ARCH

ghaskins
2016-05-12 17:53
nothing to do with cross-arch compat

vpaprots
2016-05-12 17:53
I thought PORTABLE meant something about the binary not hardcoding absolute PATHs.. but hadnt really looked

ghaskins
2016-05-12 17:54
@vpaprots: it minimally affected gcc optimizations on x86, not sure about other things like paths and alt-arch

ghaskins
2016-05-12 17:55
we had a problem in the early days where I compiled it on my Xeon mac, and gcc enabled some intel feature as a result that wasnt universal

ghaskins
2016-05-12 17:55
so, the object code didnt run on all processors after that

vpaprots
2016-05-12 17:55
ah.. I just blindly copied the option.. It made me think about 'relocatable code' since that is something compiler people worry about..

ghaskins
2016-05-12 17:56
so the PORTABLE flag just turns that off so it generates least-common-denominator instrinsics

vpaprots
2016-05-12 17:56
problems, nails and hammers ...

vpaprots
2016-05-12 17:58
A different sorta question, @sheehan maybe a hint from you...

vpaprots
2016-05-12 17:59
@vpaprots uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/vpaprots/F18CYJQ03/-.txt

vpaprots
2016-05-12 18:00
That tarballs the entire GOPATH!

vpaprots
2016-05-12 18:00
I happen to have entire golang compiler in there, since I am patching that too.. yikes, build takes forever

vpaprots
2016-05-12 18:00
would be nice to copy only whats needed...

bcbrock
2016-05-12 18:01
For example on POWER, PORTABLE=1 means it only uses POWER7 instructions. PORTABLE=0 means that if you compile on POWER8, the binary *may* only run on POWER8

sheehan
2016-05-12 18:03
@vpaprots: believe there’s an open issue. Let me see if I can find it

vpaprots
2016-05-12 18:04
was that to pick up vendoring folder? not sure where it usually gets downloaded too..

vpaprots
2016-05-12 18:05
i.e. presumably we just need vendoring deps + hyperledger fabric folder for peer docker container to run..

sheehan
2016-05-12 18:09
@muralisr: See comment from @vpaprots about pulling in the entire GOPATH. Is there an issue for that? Can’t find it

sheehan
2016-05-12 18:10
I think early on that was done to pick up potential deps. Now that 1.6 is available, chaincode writers should use vendoring for their deps

ghaskins
2016-05-12 18:32
yeah, im thinking of a couple of different ways we can exploit whats there now

ghaskins
2016-05-12 18:33
1 would be doing something like git ls-files on fabric and only pulling that in

ghaskins
2016-05-12 18:33
another would be we could have the makefile prepare an image with baseimage+fabric so the image already has the code and doesnt need it at deploy time

ghaskins
2016-05-12 18:34
which ultimately we probably want some form of, we want to minimize the amount of work that has to be done in the fast path eventually

bcbrock
2016-05-12 18:36
Referring back to the baseimage 0.0.10 discussion (?), ‘busywork’ requires the Ubuntu packages “tcl”, “tclx” and “tcllib”. “tcllib” is an issue depending on the Ubuntu version, it has different names in different versions. Also, unfortunately “tcllib” needs to be built from source on Z.

vpaprots
2016-05-12 20:29
Re rocksdb 4.5.1 https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/commits/master/build_tools/build_detect_platform vs https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/commits/v4.5.1/build_tools/build_detect_platform

vpaprots
2016-05-12 20:30
seems like Gong delivered his fix less then a month later and the fix did not make it into 4.5.1.. oh well, I will just keep the sed in the build for a bit longer...

simon
2016-05-13 12:25
@ghaskins: i'm looking at how to change Makefile to use actual dependencies instead of dummy targets

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:25
that would be awesome, thanks

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:27
i was also trying to see if something could be done with prereqs…like if .baseimage-dummy depended on ./scripts/provision/* or something like that

simon
2016-05-13 12:27
so one thing is that `go install -v` will only print something if the sources change

simon
2016-05-13 12:27
maybe we should transition to `go install` instead of `go build`

simon
2016-05-13 12:28
that implies using the go install path, instead of `../peer/peer`

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:28
yeah, i was thinking that too, it offers to be faster

simon
2016-05-13 12:28
way faster

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:28
on that front, another thing we could think about doing is for the peer-image/ca-image targets, right now we inject the full $GOPATH and then build the peer

simon
2016-05-13 12:28
now building the peer image - can't we just copy in the binary and the configs?

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:28
yes!

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:28
thats where I was just going with that

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:29
rather than pull in the full source and do a build, we should just go-install the binary and inject that

simon
2016-05-13 12:29
and configs

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:29
right

simon
2016-05-13 12:29
however...

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:29
does the code read the full .yaml tree at runtime?

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:30
or just core.yaml?

simon
2016-05-13 12:30
yea that needs to be cleaned up as well

simon
2016-05-13 12:30
but will deploy work?

simon
2016-05-13 12:30
i.e. do we need the full source in the peer image?

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:31
technically the chaincode needs a subset

simon
2016-05-13 12:31
yea but that's silly in the first place that we need to distribute the chaincode

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:31
at least the shim, possibly some other stuff like PB

simon
2016-05-13 12:31
defeats the purpose of deploying code

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:31
not sure what you mean

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:32
anyway, i am not against the fabric code being injected, its the go-build _every_ time that kills us

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:33
so, the biggest win would be, still copy $GOPATH, but inject a peer/ca binary built from go-install

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:33
I think if we move the business of creating the peer/ca images out from the unit tests and into the makefile, we can optimize this fairly easily

simon
2016-05-13 12:33
okay, given that there is some peace on the consensus front, i can look into tooling

simon
2016-05-13 12:34
where i have a personal need (make takes 1h on my laptop)

simon
2016-05-13 12:34
and i've been doing tooling for other large projects for a long time

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:34
that would be awesome, thanks

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:34
is the 1h after a clean?

simon
2016-05-13 12:34
yes

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:34
is that building the baseimage too?

simon
2016-05-13 12:35
yes

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:35
i mean the :unknown-0.0.9 thing

simon
2016-05-13 12:35
no

simon
2016-05-13 12:35
that gets fetched

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:35
oh wow, thats an awfully long time for not building the base

simon
2016-05-13 12:35
i know

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:35
any idea where the bulk is spent?

simon
2016-05-13 12:35
slow CPU :simple_smile:

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:35
ah

simon
2016-05-13 12:36
so first thing that is odd is that REST deploy doesn't ship the source

simon
2016-05-13 12:36
so you can only deploy code that is either available at the peer you're sending the deploy to

simon
2016-05-13 12:36
or which the peer can fetch

simon
2016-05-13 12:36
does that make sense at all?

simon
2016-05-13 12:37
for now we can just copy the current codebase in

simon
2016-05-13 12:37
but it doesn't seem right

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:37
well, theres two things going on here I think

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:37
#1, we need some substrate to support the chaincode…minimally shim and protobuf, probably others

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:37
we solve this with a heavy hand and just copy the entire $GOPATH

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:38
#2, the deploy method currently only supports accessible URL or local fs path

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:38
often times local-fs path and $GOPATH overlap, but they dont technically need to per se

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:39
one of the things I was trying to tackle with chaintool would be chaincode packaging

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:39
e.g. bundle it up and send it in with the deploy payload

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:39
that would get rid of the #2 stuff, but we still need to think about the ABI that the chaincode needs to compile

ghaskins
2016-05-13 12:40
i have to get kids to school, bbiab

simon
2016-05-13 12:41
so why do we even ship the code and don't ship binaries? probably because we want to support a heterogeneous network

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:24
It's also likely more space efficient to send code, but most importantly it's that certain use cases will require code attestation

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:25
But heterogeneity is a good point too

simon
2016-05-13 13:26
code attestation vs binary attestation...

simon
2016-05-13 13:26
independent, the code should be sent, and not be expected to be present

simon
2016-05-13 13:26
and probably the code should be self-contained and use vendored dependencies

simon
2016-05-13 13:27
or different nodes may fetch different code (dependencies)

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:27
Assuming you can product deterministic binaries I suppose you have a point

simon
2016-05-13 13:27
i.e. the build must happen on a dockerized go build that cannot access the internet

simon
2016-05-13 13:27
i think shipping a multi-binary is better

simon
2016-05-13 13:28
maybe @garisingh has an opinion

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:28
has joined #fabric-dev-env

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:35
i think a production environment will not want to allow fetching

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:35
this is what I was going for with the “platforms” concept in chaintool

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:35
@simon @ghaskins - you guys are hitting the nail on the head here in terms of issues of "code / binary" attestation when it comes to chaincode. The question is a bit easier if you are only concerned about the peer / environment you manage, but more complicated if you want to know what everyone else is actually running

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:36
e.g. platform: { “org.hyperledger.chaincode.golang”, 1 } meant a certain ABI in terms of available libraries, etc

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:36
anything not part of the platform could be added to the bundle shipped with the app

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:37
see this: https://github.com/ghaskins/chaintool#chaintool-package

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:38
the idea was that we have some properties here, like the chaincode sha and platform designation

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:38
the source-bundle + sha provides the source attestation and the platform defines the compatiblity

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:39
I liken the chaintool platform concept like java 1.6, vs 1.7 vs 1.8

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:39
it denotes compatibility with the environment the code will run in

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:40
I had a few ideas: 1) Have a trusted Docker registry as part of the network. So rather than compiling code and building images on the fly, actually require that there be a signed Docker image deployed to a secure trusted registry. We can likely leverage a lot of the existing enrollment crypto / certs as part of this or create some new material that's part of the network 2) Require that the Docker daemon be in "content trust" mode or at least set that flag when starting containers 3) For things like the SHIM code, we should actually move to a model where we used shared libraries (prebuilt) rather than compiling it in from source.

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:40
if we move to other languages like Java, we can do better - e.g. signed JARs, etc

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:41
i dont think you need a specific language to do that, I captured signatures in the CAR concept which is language neutral

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:41
we should also have a very minimal base chaincode container image - e.g. no compiler. etc

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:41
so you could have signed golang code too, for instance

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:41
true

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:41
but I would leverage the language specific ways under the covers where possible

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:41
i havent implemented the digitial signatures feature in chaintool yet, but the metadata is already there

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:42
chaincode base image should be basically as close to just having the chaincode executable as possible

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:42
id be wary to base the chaincode itself on docker, its too big and too external I think

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:43
i am fine if the platform concept is in docker, though

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:43
sure

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:43
for instance platform: { “org.hyperledger.chaincode.golang”, 1 } could be a docker container with specific versions of the shim/protobuf libraries

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:43
there are many different levels of attestation that we can try to provide

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:43
and the network can agree how strict they want to be

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:44
but its the source itself that is the first-class item on the chain

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:46
regarding your minimal chaincode environment, yes

simon
2016-05-13 13:46
if the source is the first-class item, then the compiler needs to be a defined version as well, no?

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:47
and assuming we stick with the source-based deployment (I think we should), it might even be the kind of thing where you would want two (related) containers

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:47
one for build, one for runtime

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:47
agreed - trusted, common build container would be the way to go IMHO

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:47
build would be a superset of runtime with the compilers, etc neeeded

simon
2016-05-13 13:47
why is this better than binary?

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:48
running native binary rather than in Docker?

simon
2016-05-13 13:48
no, putting the binary into the chain instead of the source

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:48
ah - I think we should be allowed to put the binary there as well. again - could be network policy

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:48
size, heterogeneity, and ability/ease to attest are the three leading arguments I can think of

garisingh
2016-05-13 13:49
easy to hash and sign any binary though as well as source

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:49
if you can produce something like an llvm binary deterministically, than some of that falls away, but I suspect it would still be quite a bit larger than source

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:49
and still harder to review, even if the binary is deterministic

simon
2016-05-13 13:50
well this all points towards not using arbitrary code

simon
2016-05-13 13:50
and instead using a limited (scripting) language

simon
2016-05-13 13:50
but that train has left the station long ago

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:50
bingo, but then you are back to implicit source deployment again

simon
2016-05-13 13:51
yea, then your peer version is the point

simon
2016-05-13 13:51
in any case... my question was: why doesn't REST `deploy` take the source?

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:52
my take is, HL is a framework, people may take that framework and restrict/augment the available platforms that can be supported in their own network

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:52
oh right, back to that

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:52
so, im tryign to add that, heh

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:52
i think its a good idea

simon
2016-05-13 13:52
i think it should be the whole source

simon
2016-05-13 13:52
and be built in a container that has no network access

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:52
yes!

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:52
on both counts

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:52
https://github.com/ghaskins/chaintool#typical-workflow

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:53
i was going for [source] -> chaintool package -> [.car] -> deploy -> build in an isolated container

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:53
via the rest payload, though the peer support is not in place yet

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:53
but fully agree

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:54
in that model, the dev uses the “build” subcommand to test their code, but the “package” command just packages the source, and the peer re-runs the build in an isolated container

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:55
(right now, we allow go-get to pull in deps though, but thats a maturity thing

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:55
until we can define what the platform abi is and lock it down

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:56
so, in that example02 example below, the payload is 2315 bytes that would be (probably base64 encoded) within the REST parameters

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:56
(though you can also use the current url/fs-path model too if desired

ghaskins
2016-05-13 13:57
bbiab

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:19
Hey @ghaskins - I’m reviewing PR 1440 and wanted to ask a few questions. Mainly about "move ./devenv/baseimage to ./baseimage to reflect that it encompases more than the development environment” It seems like the base image is trying to be four things 1. Vagrant dev env 2. Chaincode dev env 3. Chaincode production env 4. Peer production env Am I totally off base or is that the direction?

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:19
not sure about the distinction between 2&3, but otherwise i think thats right

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:20
i guess you could say vagrant, chaincode env, fabric (peer, ca, etc)

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:20
2 is me working on writing a chaincode. 3 is how the chaincode is deployed once the peer is in production

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:21
It seems for 1 and 2 people want Ubuntu where as for 3 and 4, people want Alpine or something small

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:21
ok, i see where you are going with it

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:22
i see a difference in chaincode-compilation vs chaincode-execution, for sure

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:22
today, i dont know if anyone uses docker for developing chaincode, per se, but I can see how that might be useful eventually

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:23
so I’m trying to work out how we support both. seems like it may be two different images

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:24
And once we have Java chaincode, there may be a third image

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:24
i think you are right to point out that at some point, certain docker envs will want/need to be lightweight as possible

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:24
will probably take more work to get to the point that it can be non ubuntu, but I think we can get there eventually

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:26
are you thinking non-ubuntu for the baseimage everywhere?

vpaprots
2016-05-13 18:30
@sheehan: what do you think constitutes chaincode dev environment? In my mind, it would be some sort of IDE, that can deploy to the network?

vpaprots
2016-05-13 18:30
I think thats what Ethereum is doing with Solidity?

vpaprots
2016-05-13 18:31
i.e. for java shim, maybe an eclipse PDE..

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:31
If I’m working on a complex chaincode and it’s failing, I may wish to actually run the docker container that was deployed. I’ve seen others do this to debug. At this point, they’re looking for tools like vi, vim, nano, etc. in the container

vpaprots
2016-05-13 18:32
hmm. good point, debugging the contract is a thing now too..

vpaprots
2016-05-13 18:33
thats kinda scary actually... how do you recover from a bug that you found when contract was in production, executing.. since blockchain only allows append.. another contract I guess...

vpaprots
2016-05-13 18:33
that has to have access to the same world state..

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:37
that’s being worked on as part of the “upgrade” concept

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:38
@ghaskins: so my point is that the baseimage still seems tied to dev, thus maybe why it should live in the devenv folder? In production I may still wish to deploy chaincode using the golang:1.6 image.

vpaprots
2016-05-13 18:38
some sort of way to redeploy same contract (i.e. different executable under same name?)

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:40
@vpaprots: The issue is at https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/issues/1133. @muralisr may have more details written down somewhere else or a public branch

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:40
@sheehan: i see your point

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:41
ultimately its not a huge deal, i can see both arguments

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:41
(today it isnt just dev-env, but perhaps eventually it will be)

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:41
we can leave it under dev-env if you prefer

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:42
i guess what bothered me about leaving it is it seemed wrong to have the new auto provisioner reach into ./devenv/.. to do its work

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:42
but its not a huge deal

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:44
on the image side point, I do wonder how much that will matter given that docker is pretty good about storage efficiency

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:44
e.g. whether the image is 50M or 500M, it will scale by the delta of each chaincode, not the 50/500

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:45
it will impact the inital download, though

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:46
agreed on size. I think it’s more a perspective of less stuff = better because there’s less complexity/risk in my container?

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:46
yes, that is certainly true

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:47
you might need go, jvm, chaintool, whatever to build it, but once its built, none of that stuff should matter much

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:47
you just want the bare minimum so that "docker run -it chaincode-image chaincode-binary” can do its thing

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:47
I need to understand the new auto provisioner. Is this in your PR?

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:48
yeah, last patch

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:48
basically, it just says “if I cant find the baseimage with docker-pull, build it"

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:48
i wanted to un-gate people from dockerhub publication

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:49
particularly important for multi-arch, but could be used, for instance, for someone testing baseimage changes

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:50
even within an $arch that is supported

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:50
it throws a big WARNING to the log when this happens, though

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:50
I see. but in production, if I changed the chaincode docker file in core.yaml to something other than the base image, that would never run, correct?

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:50
correct, this only happens via the makefile plumbing

vpaprots
2016-05-13 18:50
in 'C-speak', you want to statically link all your libraries into your executable, so you can move it anywhere.. not sure yet what that means in GO, but once compiled.. not sure you need much of an OS anyway

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:51
if you say “make” with a target that needs a baseimage, and the baseimage cannot be found, it will try to compile it locally

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:51
@vpaprots: yah, for go that is probably largely true…there might be some ABI linkage to some .sos (rocksdb comes to mind)

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:51
that makes sense. It still seems like a dev mode thing to me. Not sure I understand "bothered me about leaving it is it seemed wrong to have the new auto provisioner reach into ./devenv/.. to do its work"

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:52
@sheehan: what I meant was this part:

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:52
https://github.com/ghaskins/hyperledger-fabric/blob/multi-arch-substrate-v1/scripts/provision/docker.sh#L64

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:53
it seemed “wrong” for the docker auto-provisioner to reach into ./devenv/baseimage to do the make (I equate “devenv” with vagrant)

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:53
but like I said, its a minor niggle

sheehan
2016-05-13 18:54

ghaskins
2016-05-13 18:59

ghaskins
2016-05-13 19:00
ill let you finish the review as is, but that should get fixed before merging

bcbrock
2016-05-16 22:40
- Here is a worthwhile puzzle (in my opinion) whose solution may streamline the development environment. Is there a way to set up Docker-compose networks that will not require the hyperledger-fabric image to *ever* be rebuilt as the peer and membersrvc are updated during develoment? I’m thinking, can we use Docker volumes to simply mount a common GOPATH into the container instead of rebuilding the GOPATH?

ghaskins
2016-05-16 22:40
cool, where did you put them?

bcbrock
2016-05-16 22:41
I didn’t put them in yet

ghaskins
2016-05-16 22:42
ok…right now we have scripts/provision/common.sh….if you put them there they will get installed under vagrant/travis/docker….it sounds like for this it would be ideal to exclude docker

ghaskins
2016-05-16 22:42
i had split out a provision/hosts.sh at one point but the PR was dropped…that would have been a closer approximation to what you want

ghaskins
2016-05-16 22:42
with the intention that only host-specific things go in there, and then vagrant/travis/etc call hosts (which calls common)

ghaskins
2016-05-16 22:43
we’ll still need to sort out $arch/$distro specific things but that would get you closer

bcbrock
2016-05-16 22:45
Are you saying you want me to add hosts.sh?

bcbrock
2016-05-16 22:48
Left to my own devices I would add the apt-get in setup.sh

vpaprots
2016-05-16 22:50
with apt-get and yum, I am hoping we can contain the issues to just $distro, rather then $arch/$distro.. though in many cases the distro repo dont have the packages needed..

vpaprots
2016-05-16 22:51
in my mind its better to put an if ($arch) in that case, so that the enviroment is as close across arches as possible

vpaprots
2016-05-16 22:51
(i.e. if ($arch=390) build tcl...)

bcbrock
2016-05-16 22:55
@vpaprots: have you and @ghaskins discussed how/where to add $arch?

vpaprots
2016-05-16 23:01
not in exacting detail.. in my mind setup.sh we have for vagrant could be apropriated for deb-based installs.. and the setupLinuxOne.sh for RHEL/rpm based installs

bcbrock
2016-05-17 22:03
@ghaskins I agree we don’t need Tcl in Docker. apt-get in the vagrant environment is smart enough to do the right thing when I ask for “tcl tclx tcllib”. I propose to add them in setup.sh, and if they later want to run these tests from Travis they can easily add that dependendency.

ghaskins
2016-05-17 23:35
@bcbrock: I am fine with that, but let me ask you this: would anyone want/need to run busywork/tcl aside from within vagrant? This would include travis or custom dev-envs, etc

ghaskins
2016-05-17 23:36
if not, setup.sh is fine for now

ghaskins
2016-05-17 23:37
but if so, I suggest 1) add ./scripts/provision/host.sh which calls common.sh, 2) update setup.sh + .travis.yml to s/common.sh/host.sh, and 3) do the apt-get installs in host.sh

bcbrock
2016-05-17 23:38
I don’t see travis.yaml calling common.sh

ghaskins
2016-05-17 23:38
I eventually want to start moving most of the apt-get type stuff out of setup.sh (e.g. docker-compose) there, this seems like a good excuse to get it started

ghaskins
2016-05-17 23:38
hmm, right that was in the PR that never got merged

ghaskins

ghaskins

bcbrock

ghaskins

ghaskins

2016-05-18 13:09

jzhang
2016-05-18 13:51

ghaskins
2016-05-18 13:55
It works like gdb.... That is, it starts up without the code running

ghaskins
2016-05-18 13:55
Hit "c" to continue

ghaskins
2016-05-18 13:56
They do that so you have a chance to set break points

jzhang
2016-05-18 13:58
ah ok, did look for a command like that to get the program going, couldn’t find that in “help”, trying that now

jzhang
2016-05-18 14:00
(actually i missed that in help: continue (alias: c) --------- Run until breakpoint or program termination.)

jzhang
2016-05-18 14:01
working now, thanks @ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-05-18 14:24
Rule of thumb: if your debugger has a prompt, your program is paused

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:31
on a related topic, I looked into removing the :bootclasspath but it really hurt performance

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:31
not sure what to do

bcbrock
2016-05-18 19:31
What is HIP?

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:31
Hyperledger Inclusion Proposal

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:31
i thought thats what you filed for busywork, i might be confused

bcbrock
2016-05-18 19:32
Right, that was so long ago….

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:32
heh

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:33
an ugly wart of clojure is its startup time is atrocious. For most things like long running server applications, thats not much of an issue, but it impacts command-line apps in the worst way

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:33
:bootclasspath supposedly is only supported in java 1.8, but it does seem to make a performance difference even when I target 1.7 ABI

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:34
(because thats what trusty provides by default)

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:34
so with, its like 2 seconds to start, without its over 3.5

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:34
but with, ibm-jre blows up

bcbrock
2016-05-18 19:34
Java considered harmful

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:34
not sure what to do

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:35
haha, java the language, for sure

bcbrock
2016-05-18 19:35
I have to admit I don’t know what :bootclasspath means

bcbrock
2016-05-18 19:35
buut 2 vs. 3,5 doesn’t sound *that* bad

ghaskins
2016-05-18 19:36
im no expert, but its something to do with optimizing how the system injests CP items at JVM startup

ghaskins
2016-05-19 11:39
does anyone understand why we remap port 5000 to 3000 in vagrant?

ghaskins
2016-05-19 11:40
I ask because those of us developing clients are then left with the dilemma of picking a sensible default targeting either native or vagrant…if theres a good reason for the remap then so be it…but if not, it seems it would make more sense to set them the same.

2016-05-19 14:05

ghaskins
2016-05-19 14:06
perhaps there was a reason that is not apparent

ghaskins
2016-05-19 17:44

ghaskins
2016-05-19 17:45

2016-05-19 17:53

sheehan
2016-05-19 17:53

ghaskins
2016-05-19 17:56

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-05-24 20:56
it sounds like you might have a peer already running?

ghaskins
2016-05-24 20:57
no, but there is a bug in the make unit-test that may leave the peer running from a previous session

ghaskins
2016-05-24 20:57
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/issues/1534

ghaskins
2016-05-24 20:57
check “docker ps"

ghaskins
2016-05-24 20:57
if one is still running, you can docker kill it

ghaskins
2016-05-24 20:58
i plan on fixing 1534 ASAP

sheehan
2016-05-24 20:58
ok, my unit tests failed previously due to that obcpbft race condition

ghaskins
2016-05-24 20:58
ok, that makes sense

ghaskins
2016-05-24 20:59
i think what I will do for 1534 is move the logic out of the unit-test target into a script, and just have “make unit-test” call the script. That way I should be able to register an error handler in bash and have the docker cleaned up even if the test fails

ghaskins
2016-05-24 20:59
but for now, docker ps/kill is the workaround

sheehan
2016-05-24 21:00

ghaskins
2016-05-24 21:00
good question, im not sure

ghaskins
2016-05-24 21:00
let me look into that

sheehan
2016-05-24 21:07
so I think `rm` stops and removes where as `kill` sends a kill signal and removes? And maybe `rm -f` is the same as `kill`?

sheehan
2016-05-24 21:08
lol, even the docker devs agree it’s confusing https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/6533

2016-06-09 13:58

simon
2016-06-10 16:04
i thought `make all` now was rebuilding peer image etc when required - doesn't seem it does?

ghaskins
2016-06-10 16:09
well, it is supposed to _only_ build it if its needed…are you saying you think it is needed and its failing to recognize this?

ghaskins
2016-06-10 16:09
or are you just seeing it FAD?

simon
2016-06-10 16:21
it doesn't rebuild

simon
2016-06-10 16:21
because there is just a dummy file - how would it know to rebuild?

ghaskins
2016-06-10 16:23
can you describe the problem in more detail?

ghaskins
2016-06-10 16:24
the dummy file is predicated on things like the source files

ghaskins
2016-06-10 16:24
so, if a source file changes, for instance, the dummy prerequisite is deemed stale and the target should rebuild

simon
2016-06-10 16:24
is that latest master?

ghaskins
2016-06-10 16:24
if you are seeing that not be the case, i would want to know

ghaskins
2016-06-10 16:24
yes

simon
2016-06-10 16:25
ah, i may be a bit below - i thought i rebased

simon
2016-06-10 16:25
sorry

ghaskins
2016-06-10 16:26
see the “build/image/*/.dummy stuff starting here: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/Makefile#L140

ghaskins
2016-06-10 16:26
in particular: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/Makefile#L154

gabelev
2016-06-10 19:04

zuowang
2016-06-14 11:51
has joined #fabric-dev-env

webdaford
2016-06-14 19:28
webdaford [3:20 PM] ...a quick note to announce the availability of a collection of Ansible playbooks that provision, configure and launch instances of the Hyperledger Fabric using Consul, Docker, Docker Swarm and Docker Compose. The easy to read and understand playbooks can be configured to launch an arbitrarily sized instance of the Fabric on an arbitrary set of previously un-configured computers. Ansible will take care of provisioning the machines appropriately, and then will automatically generate a configuration file for Docker Compose to launch the Fabric instance on Docker Swarm, all triggered with a single command. Dan Ford Keoja LLC https://github.com/keoja/hyperledger-ansible

2016-06-14 22:00

jyellick
2016-06-20 18:06
@muralisr: Do you know why this was somehow triggered by 1877? I have poured through my changeset multiple times and just cannot find what might be the cause

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:08
I dont know either @jyellick …. let me check one thing … @ramesh, which test fails after the PR#1877 merge please ?

jyellick
2016-06-20 18:09
My best guess is that my changes affected the length of time that tests were running, and therefore pushed two tests into running concurrently that didn't used to, but I even tried with `go test -parallel 1` and I still see the failure (though not when running the package tests independently)

ramesh
2016-06-20 18:11
Unit tests are failing. FAIL: TestExecuteDeploySysChaincode

ramesh
2016-06-20 18:11
https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-github-verify-x86_64/245/console

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:13
ok @ramesh. So #1926 should at least alleviate...

ramesh
2016-06-20 18:17
yes.. All unit tests passed in 1926

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:17
right

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:18
@jyellick: I was thinking “parallel” too but couldn’t go beyond that :slightly_smiling_face:

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:18
I wondered if something else beside “parallel” is at work here

jyellick
2016-06-20 18:20
@muralisr: Well, at least you seem as unsure as I am. I like to know how I break things so that I can avoid them in the future... but I guess I may have to let this one go.

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:26
@muralisr: is your suspicion that there is concurrency within the UT framework itself that is breaking things? or is it that subsequent runs are persisting state?

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:26
er, previous runs persisting state affecting subsequent runs, I should say, heh

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:27
the reason I ask is I had a patch that run the UTs in a docker instance that would offer some degree of environmental isolation that could be of interest

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:27
but it wouldnt have any impact if the problem is intra-test inteference

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:29
@ghaskins: the former is the obvious first choice for an explanation ? It doesn’t quite explain the “why now”. If nothing has changed, it presumes we were always running concurrent but didn’t know it and now we are breaking due to timing

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:30
yeah, could just be the type/nr of tests affect how go-tests schedules concurrency or something

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:31
i didnt think we had any parallel stuff enabled in go-test however IIUC so I am confused how that is even the case

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:31
same here

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:31
perhaps the problem isnt concurrent execution but resource cleanup

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:36
That would be surprising…. all the chaincode tests use /tmpdb and reuse that freely without explicitly tmpdb cleanup.

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:36
only “theory” that fits is chaincode UT and “system_chaincode” UT are running into each other

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:37
now that I moved system_chaincode to a different DB, they no longer do

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:37
fits the facts but Sherlock won’t like it :slightly_smiling_face:

jyellick
2016-06-20 18:38
@ghaskins: By default, go runs unit tests in parallel with the number of available CPUs: ``` -parallel n Allow parallel execution of test functions that call t.Parallel. The value of this flag is the maximum number of tests to run simultaneously; by default, it is set to the value of GOMAXPROCS. Note that -parallel only applies within a single test binary. The 'go test' command may run tests for different packages in parallel as well, according to the setting of the -p flag (see 'go help build'). ... -p n the number of programs, such as build commands or test binaries, that can be run in parallel. The default is the number of CPUs available, except on darwin/arm which defaults to 1. ```

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:39
right that also fits the observations in https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/issues/1921

muralisr
2016-06-20 18:39
2 CPUs works, 4 CPUs show errors

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:42
@jyellick: understood, but the language is a bit confusing as there are places where it implies that tests have to explicitly opt-in with t.Parallel(), which I dont think we have any that do

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:42
it could be that we do in fact have some that opt-in, or it could be that I misinterpreted the doc

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:43
but I was under the distinct impression that today, we dont parallelize the tests

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:43
i guess further study is needed

jyellick
2016-06-20 18:48
@ghaskins: Within a single package, I think you must opt into parallelism, but when executing tests across multiple packages, I believe they are parallelized via `-p`

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:49
@jyellick: thats possible

ghaskins
2016-06-20 18:50
certainly 1921 is evidence to the contrary of my understanding

sheehan
2016-06-20 19:55
I can confirm that when I modify `goUnitTests.sh` changing `go test -cover -timeout=20m $PKGS` to `go test -cover -p 1 -timeout=20m $PKGS` that the tests pass on my laptop

ghaskins
2016-06-20 19:57
ah, well, that cinches it

sheehan
2016-06-20 19:57
also it feels like the tests take longer, but I didn’t actually measure

ghaskins
2016-06-20 19:58
this makes sense in a way: i wrote a patch which tried to run go-test per package and parallelize them with the gnu parallel tool

ghaskins
2016-06-20 19:58
but it ran slower, probably because the tests were already parallel so all I did was add overhead

ghaskins
2016-06-20 19:59
(the thought at the time is I would run each instance in its own container so they wouldnt interfere with one another

ghaskins
2016-06-20 19:59
it all worked, but was appreciably slower, so I abandoned it

ghaskins
2016-06-20 20:00
speaking of parallelization, i wonder if theres a way we can have vagrant scale up the nr of vcpus based on system its on

ghaskins
2016-06-20 20:00
I have a 4c/8t Xeon MacPro that could probably handle more than 2c vcpus

2016-07-05 14:28
is it possible to add dynamically new attributes to an existing attribute certificate?

cbf
2016-07-12 17:32
@novusopt: I don’t believe so @jonathanlevi might know better

jonathanlevi
2016-07-12 17:44
@novusopt: Nope. Usually certificates are kind of 'final' after issuance...

jonathanlevi
2016-07-12 17:44
Is there a use-case that you are trying to address?

jonathanlevi
2016-07-12 17:45
It might be easier to request a cert with a new list of attr (unless you are trying to reuse the 'attestation')

somii1.01
2016-07-21 11:34
Hello all

somii1.01
2016-07-21 11:35
i am finding some difficulties in seeting up node.js api using swagger for chaincode

somii1.01
2016-07-21 11:35
can anyone please help me out with these steps

somii1.01
2016-07-21 11:36
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/docs/API/CoreAPI.md#nodejs-application

cbf
2016-07-21 13:00
@somii1.01: just reviewed that, and I think I may see your problem… can you be a bit more specific as to what problem you are observing?

somii1.01
2016-07-21 14:15
Thanks @cbf

cbf
2016-07-21 16:35
@somii1.01: I have created a helper to get you swaggerized … I need to add some documentation but you can try it out if you’d like. I would welcome the feedback. I’ll contribute it to Hyperledger soon as I get it mostly finished

cbf
2016-07-21 16:35
https://github.com/christo4ferris/fabric-swagger

cbf
2016-07-21 16:36
basically, you need to start a peer process and then run the ‘runme.sh’ script. It will install what you need and launch a web server and open a browser window to Swagger UI. Then enter ‘rest_api.json’ and hit ‘Explore’ button

cbruguera
2016-07-21 16:43
Hey @cbf ! Does this take care of the CORS?

cbf
2016-07-21 17:28
it runs with CORS, yes

cbruguera
2016-07-21 17:28
Cool!

cbf
2016-07-21 17:29
fetch the latest, I just fixed a bug

cbruguera
2016-07-21 17:29
Thanks

cbruguera
2016-07-21 17:30
This needs swagger service installed and running locally, right?

cbf
2016-07-21 18:40
@cbruguera: no, it installs it and any dependencies for you

cbf
2016-07-21 18:42
I wrote this so that if you aren’t actually developing the fabric but maybe just running the docker images, that you can still interact with the node via swagger

cbruguera
2016-07-21 19:58
Sounds good, has it been tested on Windows?

cbf
2016-07-22 00:41
@arnaud tested on Windoze and there was a tweak needed which I have pushed to my repo

cbf
2016-07-22 00:41
should work

cbf
2016-07-22 00:42
the one gotcha is that the peer will probably need to run on another port because of conflict with UPnP (5000) which means that the rest_api.json needs to reflect the appropriate port number

nhrishi
2016-08-05 15:12
Hi, I'm trying to login as a client on the network (built using docker compose) with below command but getting "existing " message. Any idea what is wrong.

nhrishi
2016-08-05 15:12
user@HBADBC01:/usr/local/go/src/github.com/chaincode_example02$ sudo docker run --name test_client1 --rm -it -e CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=unix:///var/run/docker.sock -e CORE_PEER_ID=vp100 -e CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.5:7051 -e CORE_PEER_ADDRESSAUTODETECT=true -e CORE_LOGGING_LEVEL=DEBUG -e CORE_PEER_PKI_TLS_ENABLED=true -e CORE_PEER_PKI_TLS_ROOTCERT_FILE=/var/hyperledger/production/.membersrvc/tlsca.cert -e CORE_PEER_PKI_TLS_SERVERHOSTOVERRIDE=tlsca -e CORE_PEER_PKI_ECA_PADDR=172.17.0.2:7054 -e CORE_PEER_PKI_TCA_PADDR=172.17.0.2:7054 -e CORE_PEER_PKI_TLSCA_PADDR=172.17.0.2:7054 -e CORE_SECURITY_ENABLED=true -e CORE_SECURITY_PRIVACY=true fabric-refdata-peer peer network login jim -p 6avZQLwcUe9b 15:08:57.751 [logging] LoggingInit -> DEBU 001 Setting default logging level to DEBUG for command 'network' 15:08:57.751 [networkCmd] networkLogin -> INFO 002 CLI client login... 15:08:57.751 [networkCmd] networkLogin -> INFO 003 Local data store for client loginToken: /var/hyperledger/production/client/ 15:08:57.751 [networkCmd] networkLogin -> INFO 004 Logging in user 'jim' on CLI interface... 15:08:57.753 [networkCmd] networkLogin -> INFO 005 Storing login token for user 'jim'. 15:08:57.753 [networkCmd] networkLogin -> INFO 006 Login successful for user 'jim'. 15:08:57.753 [main] main -> INFO 007 Exiting.....

garisingh
2016-08-05 20:55
@nhrishi: you basically just used Docker to run the CLI "login" command which literally just runs the login function and exits

garisingh
2016-08-05 20:55
you would normally run `login` first and then run other CLI commands

garisingh
2016-08-05 20:58
`login` basically communicates with membership services and obtains / downloads your enrollment data (it stores it in a folder which in this case would be in your container). For what you ran to be meaningful, you should mount a volume which you use as the fabric directory which is where the enrollment material would be stored. You could them keep attaching that volume to various containers as you execute CLI commands

alexho
2016-08-07 15:49
has joined #fabric-dev-env

nhrishi
2016-08-08 06:26
@garisingh: Thanks !! it makes sense now.

troyronda
2016-08-09 15:34
has joined #fabric-dev-env

yacovm

simon

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:51
@simon: we dont, thats what I was saying

simon
2016-08-17 12:51
ah yes

simon
2016-08-17 12:51

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:51
before we had a makefile, the script was manually driven

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:51
after I wrote the makefile, I didnt have a chance to tackle the script, so the makefile just invokes the script, but that should go away

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:52
(ideally)

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:53
honestly, i dont have a problem with the .proto files being dispersed per se….we should be able to handle that intelligently with the build

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:53
(for one thing, having them dispersed is a more natural namespacing)

simon
2016-08-17 12:53
yes

simon
2016-08-17 12:53
but then we don't need to compile them centrally

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:53
the fact that some are dispersed and some arent is a bit sloppy I suppose

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:54
well, yes and no

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:54
for a traditional language/environment thats probably true…id have them be compiled with the compilation unit

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:54
golang is kind of weird

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:55
since the top level build just does something like “go build foo” and then the transitive dependencies via go imports cause the build to meander all over your tree

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:55
so there isnt really a non-central build, ever

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:56
but do that point, perhaps we say “well the build is centrally oriented, so the protos should be too"

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:56
just someone will have to come up with a more distinguished name for ./consensus/pbft/messages.proto :wink:

simon
2016-08-17 12:56
i think in `proto/` should be the stuff that defines the network/storage API that is supposed to be fixed

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:56
thats fine with me

simon
2016-08-17 12:57
the stuff you could use to write your own implementation of everything

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:57
just someone needs to clean up the ones floating around like consensus

simon
2016-08-17 12:57
well, that's really internal to this specific implementation of consensus

simon
2016-08-17 12:57
of pbft

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:57
heh, understood

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:57
but now you are arguing both sides

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:57

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:58

simon
2016-08-17 12:58

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:58

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:58
i took that as “all protos"

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:58
but you were classifying certain types

simon
2016-08-17 12:59
i expect there to be a protocol/storage definition, implying that other parties can do their own compatible implementations

ghaskins
2016-08-17 12:59
heres my 2 cents: i have no strong opinion on whether the current distribution of .proto files is correct/ideal

simon
2016-08-17 12:59
if that's not the goal, fine

simon
2016-08-17 13:00
the "recompile proto files" makefile should be in `proto/` though

simon
2016-08-17 13:00
at least that's what i would do

simon
2016-08-17 13:00
`cd proto; make`

simon
2016-08-17 13:00
or is it protos?

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:00
i think that any mechanism that is going to dynamically recompile protos should be expressed as a standard make directive, like %.pb.go: %.proto\n\tprotoc $^

simon
2016-08-17 13:00
but that's not part of the normal build

simon
2016-08-17 13:00
recompiling them is a rare event

simon
2016-08-17 13:00
when you change a proto definition

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:01
right, so we want the make deps to incorporate that

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:01
we could try to move a makefile down into protos, but I am not sure that captures it properly since there are other proto files

simon
2016-08-17 13:02
that's my point

simon
2016-08-17 13:02
why is there even a script?

simon
2016-08-17 13:02
what's the goal

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:02
its legacy, it needs to go

simon
2016-08-17 13:02
or makefile target

simon
2016-08-17 13:02
same thing

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:03
what should happen is that something like “peer” depends on build/protos/foo.pb.go

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:03
and then walk it backwards

simon
2016-08-17 13:03
but why?

simon
2016-08-17 13:03
we're committing the protoc outputs

simon
2016-08-17 13:03
so we don't have to compile it during build

yacovm
2016-08-17 13:03
no we're not

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:03
thats the goal: to get rid of commited artifacts

simon
2016-08-17 13:03
oh!

simon
2016-08-17 13:03
i didn't know

yacovm
2016-08-17 13:03
i mean

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:03
heh, np

yacovm
2016-08-17 13:03
we are at the moment

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:04
@yacovm: have the JIRA id handy?

simon
2016-08-17 13:04
somebody said that it is better that way because then developers do not need protobufs installed locally

yacovm
2016-08-17 13:04
yeah 1 sec

yacovm
2016-08-17 13:05
i think 108, 109

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:05
@simon: i have said that, more specifically I am torn because that is a nice side effect

yacovm
2016-08-17 13:05
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-108 https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-109

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:05
but it also has its own set of problems

simon
2016-08-17 13:05
like what?

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:05
well, we’ve had a few bugs recently because devs were allowing the proto and pb.go to get out of sync

simon
2016-08-17 13:06
why bugs?

simon
2016-08-17 13:06
isn't the pb.go the authoritative then?

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:07
or more specifically, i think they committed a .pb.go that was built with an out of spec compiler

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:07
(related to the fact that proto3 was alpha/beta)

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:07
which i understand would be the case if they dynamically built it too, but the difference is, now their out of spec environment was corrupting everyone

simon
2016-08-17 13:08
well same the other way around

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:08
since proto3 is now finalized, theres less risk of this happening (in either case) but committing the files is generally the way most projects are run

simon
2016-08-17 13:08
or maybe not the same way

simon
2016-08-17 13:09
i don't know

simon
2016-08-17 13:09
yes, committing makes sense

simon
2016-08-17 13:09
because then you can do a go get

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:09
if we _dont_ want to dynamically build them, we should at least add a jenkins check to ensure that the user didnt commit a .proto without updating the artifacts

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:09
so, one of the two needs to happen

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:10
either remove the artifacts and build dynamically, or check that they are synchronized

simon
2016-08-17 13:10
honestly, i think this is receiving too much attention

simon
2016-08-17 13:10
there are so many other things that are way more pressing

simon
2016-08-17 13:10
like, using this terrible viper + yaml

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:10
heh, why do you think I left it with the script ?

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:10
:wink:

simon
2016-08-17 13:10
or how it is essentially impossible to install + run this monster

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:11
yeah, thats what I have been looking at

simon
2016-08-17 13:11
there needs to be a script (or any other executable) that the user can call, and everything works

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:12
This isnt done, but since we are on the subject

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:12
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1MaBVoY0s2QVvA75ehKSFohvE6RNIzJD4PhPMKB9aFtA/edit?usp=sharing

simon
2016-08-17 13:12
at least for demo and local dev purposes

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:12
not done, nor even fully baked with what is there, but while we are discussing it

simon
2016-08-17 13:13
i think viper needs to go

simon
2016-08-17 13:13
and yaml

simon
2016-08-17 13:13
it may be easy for development

simon
2016-08-17 13:13
but not for the users

simon
2016-08-17 13:13
also, many configs need to come from the blockchain, and not from a config file that can be changed on the fly

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:13
I have no strong opinion on viper or yaml, but I do think we need to have a retooling of what constututes “the config” and how that maps into the docker stuff

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:14
and I suspect at least part of the way to get there is to reconsider viper

simon
2016-08-17 13:14
the problem with viper is that you can misspell a key, and nobody ever tells you

simon
2016-08-17 13:14
maximum user unfriendly

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:14
for one, I think we need the notion of “-c config” as a command line option _before_ the config is loaded

simon
2016-08-17 13:14
sure

simon
2016-08-17 13:15
but the config really only would specify log levels and some ports/addresses, no?

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:15
my understanding is there is a chicken/egg scenario in the current program-opts parsing that might make this difficult

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:16
at this point, I have no strong opinion of what should be in there, but one of my main goals is to allow something like a version: to be specified and have that related to what images the docker engine consumes

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:17
for instance, if we had hyperledger/fabric-peer:v1.0.0 and hyperledger/fabric-membersrvc:v1.0.0 in dockerhub, then the different components should all be using the same version

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:18
right now, its completely undefined…chaincode tries to run “baseimage:latest” which is arbitrary

simon
2016-08-17 13:18
ah i see

simon
2016-08-17 13:18
probably that shouldn't be in the config, but sort of hard coded somewhere in the source?

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:18
what I would like to see is the suite of images (peer, membersrvc, ccenv, etc) to be tagged with the same version

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:19
yeah, i thought of that, and that is an option

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:19
but I am thinking someone somewhere might want to reconfigure it

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:19
maybe here is a compromise

simon
2016-08-17 13:19
oh you want everything be dockerized?

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:19
not per se, but what I do want to address is that the current system implies it _is_ dockerized but its not fully baked

simon
2016-08-17 13:19
yes

simon
2016-08-17 13:20
i don't understand why we have docker containers at all

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:20
so, i am not advocating that everything needs to be docker, but what I am saying is the docker stuff we have should work

simon
2016-08-17 13:20
why not just build and run a binary

simon
2016-08-17 13:20
suddenly, much less complexity

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:20
well, the docker stuff is interesting, for instance I am working on top of kubernetes/openshift

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:20
and I would like fabric to be hosted there too

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:21
not sure, in some ways it reduces complexity, but point taken

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:21
but bottom line: we have an implied docker support, but its broken

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:21
and I aim to fix that (as well as making it conducive to building things like fabric-peer.rpm

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:21
right now, we cant do either

simon
2016-08-17 13:22
oh i mean docker to run chaincode

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:31
ah, well, that is another matter

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:31
i would love to see LXC instead, minimally

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:31
but that is a different conversation

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:32
thats a runtime thing though..compilation wise, I dont think docker is a terrible idea

ghaskins
2016-08-17 13:32
in fact, it works out nicely in many respects

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:30
@ghaskins: we actually build docker containers for the BMX service and get everything working fine. we don't use the fabric images because they are not conducive to actually running a service

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:30
we run a Docker Swarm with overlay networking today

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:31
actually 2 swarms - one for peers / CAs and one for chaincode

ghaskins
2016-08-17 14:31
@garisingh: i dont think its far away from working, but I cant imagine you are just blindly consuming whats in dockerhub

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:31
nope

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:31
we build them ourselves

ghaskins
2016-08-17 14:31
for one thing, the peer tries to reference “baseimage:latest” to build chaincode

ghaskins
2016-08-17 14:31
which only exists if you either run the build, or modify the yaml

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:31
also - we run with TLS, etc and all that sucks in fabric today

ghaskins
2016-08-17 14:32
but I would like to to talk to you about what you are doing as I want to do similar in kubernetes

ghaskins
2016-08-17 14:32
I assume you have your own pipeline / repository that is pushing the artifacts, including baseimage?

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:32
kubernetes and even the new Docker Swarm mode add complexities because they are really based on scaling a set of containers together as a service.

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:33
Yep

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:33
And actually we are now making them "mostly" public

ghaskins
2016-08-17 14:33
understood, though right now I dont care about the scaling aspects

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:33
we add one more layer internally for our certs

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:33
happy to set up some time to chat

ghaskins
2016-08-17 14:33
peer is probably a better target for kubernetes petsets than it is for replica scaling anyway

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:33
yes

ghaskins
2016-08-17 14:33
but right now, i would be happy with single ca/peer

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:34
we actually even have a nice picture now too :wink:

ghaskins
2016-08-17 14:34
oh nice

ghaskins
2016-08-17 14:34
anyway, regardless the stuff we push to dockerhub is broken and I want to fix that

ghaskins
2016-08-17 14:34
i think we need strong versioning, for one

garisingh
2016-08-17 14:35

ghaskins

garisingh

ghaskins

yacovm
2016-08-17 14:44
hey, i'm working on the https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-109 issue, and when you do a "make" from scratch it needs to "install" "protoc"., from the issue: ``` The disadvantage is that this requires developers to use Vagrant (it's hard not to already) or requires that they install and use the correct version of protobuf as defined in the Vagrant setup script. ``` protoc can be either downloaded as prepared binaries or downloaded the source and then compiled but the compilation (from experience) takes ages. If I include prepared binares, or have the makefile download them- that's kind of platform dependant: https://github.com/google/protobuf/releases What can be (or is best to be) done?

sheehan
2016-08-17 15:07
@yacovm: yes would be great to see someone tackle 108. Feel free to grab it.

garisingh
2016-08-17 15:08
make sure you assign it to yourself - you should be able to?

sheehan
2016-08-17 15:09
yeah, looks like people can do that now

yacovm
2016-08-17 15:09
I've already made all the needed changes for the code to migrate to V3

sheehan
2016-08-17 15:09
nice!

yacovm
2016-08-17 15:09
it's compiling but i need to somehow support the devenv now, it's tricky

yacovm
2016-08-17 15:09
and i don't know how to continue (see my comment ~ 3 comments above)

yacovm
2016-08-17 15:10
and Gari, I assigned to myself

garisingh
2016-08-17 15:12
minimally I think you need to make sure that it works with the Vagrant environment and I'd go with platform binaries for that (rather than compiling from source on startup). I'll assume at some point as we move forward with the new architecture / projects we'll want to add support for working in the native environments?

sheehan
2016-08-17 15:13
yes, agree would rather use binaries as compiling is painful

garisingh
2016-08-17 15:14
I'm happy to help / test for running code natively on OSX as well. I do that already anyway so I always modify things to work

garisingh
2016-08-17 15:15
the other (maybe not so clever) option is to use Docker to build / compile on various platforms? Since we require Docker anyway. You could imagine having a Docker image which basically mounts the src dir as a volume and outputs platform binaries

garisingh
2016-08-17 15:15
not uncommon these days

garisingh
2016-08-17 15:16
platform binaries for the fabric and ca that is

garisingh
2016-08-17 15:17
my 2.5 cents

matanyahu
2016-08-27 15:35
In the meantime, I would like to submit a comment to the deployment manual. I am not familiar with a way to propose changes so I will write it here. In http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev-setup/devenv/ the following is written with regards to the host: "Note that your Host should not run within a VM. If you attempt this, the VM within your Host may fail to boot with a message indicating that VT-x is not available.". That may imply that only physical hosts are accepted for this deployment. However, I managed to deploy it on an Ubuntu VM hosted on ESXi 6.0 with hardware virtualization activated through advanced settings ("vhv.enable='true'") which is a common option used to create nested virtualization environment with VMware software.

matanyahu
2016-08-27 15:40
I will post it to #documentation

garisingh
2016-08-28 20:09
yeah - odd indeed. the error comes from the bzip2 package (which is of course used by Docker). But a quick hex dump of the the `go path.tar.bz2` files shows that the first 2 bytes are `BZ` which is what the bzip2 package checks for before throwing that error. I don't know. Not going to waste too much time on it. I can work around it for now

harrijk
2016-08-29 15:17
Perhaps this has already been discussed, but during the build of the base image, the url to acquire gmock-1.7.0.zip results in a "file not found" error. If you look at the contents of the downloaded gmock-1.7.0.zip file you'll see a html doc that essentially says "<p>The requested URL <code>/files/gmock-1.7.0.zip</code> was not found on this server. "

ghaskins
2016-08-29 19:01
@yacovm one of the unsolved mysteries in master right now is a phenomenon I have seen such as captured in this log at 16:13:39

ghaskins
2016-08-29 19:01
https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-verify-x86_64/673/console

ghaskins
2016-08-29 19:01
that is, for reasons that are unclear, your patch causes a vendor .proto to be compiled

ghaskins
2016-08-29 19:01
could you take a look at that?

ghaskins
2016-08-29 19:02
sometimes it results in a failure at that point, some times things make it past, either way, it looks like something is wrong

yacovm
2016-08-29 19:21

yacovm
2016-08-29 19:24

yacovm

yacovm

ghaskins
2016-08-29 19:59

ghaskins
2016-09-03 16:53

ghaskins
2016-09-03 16:54
note, the image missing on dockerhub is FAD, but that should have been built for you locally before the src-image was compiled

ghaskins
2016-09-03 16:54
i speculate that the problem is you have an old ./build laying around

ghaskins
2016-09-03 16:55
hmm, actually yes I bet this is exactly whats wrong.

ghaskins
2016-09-03 16:55
a beer at the next hackathon says you have a ./build directory present before trying to do the vagrant up…the fix would be to “make clean” or manually delete it before running vagrant up

ghaskins
2016-09-03 16:55
but please confirm its there before blowing it away

garisingh
2016-09-03 18:56
how have we made this so complex for people? seems like new folks are having a lot of trouble. I was able to wade through things and was pretty easily able to get the whole build process running natively (i.e. no VirtualBox) on Ubuntu 16.04 (I actually did this on 3 different hosts)

garisingh
2016-09-03 18:57
(because I refuse to use VirtualBox) :wink:

matanyahu
2016-09-03 18:58
@garisingh : I am interested how your deployment topology looks like and what was your approach to deployment process. I will soon have to make architectural decisions for a PoC and I am torn apart between various pre-existing choices (Bluemix, devenv) and DIY.

garisingh
2016-09-03 19:02
@matanyahu - for me, it is pretty simple. I actually (occasionally) contribute code to the fabric so in that case I run my build environment straight on Ubuntu 16.04 on my host system. For building chaincode, I simply pull the Docker images and use Docker Compose to get a local peer and member services up and running. I also deploy my chaincode and apps to Bluemix (btw - I actually own development of the Bluemix service so it would be sad if I didn't use it myself)

ghaskins
2016-09-03 19:27
@matanyahu: I think my theory was wrong. I just looked in devenv/setup.sh and we do in fact call "make clean"

ghaskins
2016-09-03 19:28
This should have fixed the issue I was concerned with

ghaskins
2016-09-03 19:28
So, not sure what's going on with your setup yet

lenh
2016-09-17 18:51
has joined #fabric-dev-env

lenh
2016-09-17 18:52
Hi, anyone around?

lenh
2016-09-19 07:28
Hoping someone can assist - has anyone got a setup where they are running the docker images inside a Vagrant VM?

ashishkel
2016-09-19 11:40
@lenh I have docker images inside and outside vagrant.. both seems to be working fine.

ashishkel
2016-09-19 11:40
are you facing any issues?

lenh
2016-09-19 13:06
@ashishkel - I'm trying to get a setup going where I can have one Vagrant managed VM that automatically launches the various docker containers exposing ports, with Host OS to Container file system sync - the purpose being so that we can then use another VM to dev REST API calls with.

lenh
2016-09-19 13:08
But I'm really stuck - all the official docs either use pure Vagrant or Docker - I guess I'm going to have to have some kind of custom Vagrantfile config but not sure how to do it - found a few tutorials but they all show rather simple use cases...

yacovm
2016-09-19 14:31
hmm, @lenh why not add some startup scripts to the `devenv/setup.sh` that startup these docker containers and add iptable rules for port forwarding or something?

lenh
2016-09-19 20:18
@yacovm @ashishkel Tried to get the core Fabric up in vagrant by cloning the Gerrit repo as per the docs - no luck at all - the VM boots but when it runs the provisioning script it bombs - being doing this since we launched our project on Friday last... I built my own wily64 based VM and then provisioned docker, docker-compose, installed go etc and got the Fabric and Memberservices running all ok - but the way docker handles networking / ports is totally foreign to me atm. So although I could see the container messages on the console I am lost as to how those services should be exposed to the host VM and then out to "world" via vagrant port forwarding (I did however get this done by coping aspects of the Vagrantfile from the core Gerrit repo). At the end of the day I guess I need to get some kind of Vagrantfile going that boots a VM (for chaincode development) with the docker containers running and exposed in such a fashion that this VM is accessible via a locally running hosts file DNS entry (i,e. that it appears to be a live node) - when this is working we'll then be able to load another (existing) VM image that we do webdev with to code REST API calls with - I think :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-09-19 20:22

ghaskins

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-09-19 21:22

cbf
2016-09-20 18:59
@lenh the node sdk is the preferred approach

cbf
2016-09-20 19:00
other SDKs are emerging and will be available down the road

cbf
2016-09-20 19:00
to get an enviroment set up

cbf
2016-09-20 19:01
you can set up a development environment per these directions: http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev-setup/devenv/

cbf
2016-09-20 19:01
but that really is for those developing fabric

cbf
2016-09-20 19:01
probably more than you need

cbf
2016-09-20 19:01
the http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Chaincode-setup/ setup is a lot simpler

cbf
2016-09-20 19:02
a number of optional approaches you can take

cbf
2016-09-20 19:02
simplest is to use docker-compose to run a peer network

cbf
2016-09-20 19:02
now, we are just in the process of publishing an SDK image that you can use to write a client and interact with the network

cbf
2016-09-20 19:03
I have a version of that in my personal GH https://github.com/christo4ferris/node_sdk/blob/master/node-sdk-self-contained.md

lenh
2016-09-20 19:07
@cbf thanks a mill for the pointers - much appreciated... So the REST API via Swagger is a thing of the past?

cbf
2016-09-20 19:08
well, it is there now but not getting any love;-)

cbf
2016-09-20 19:08
if you are just playing with swagger UI then go ahead, it is a quick and dirty client

cbf
2016-09-20 19:09
just don’t invest in it. make sense?

lenh
2016-09-20 19:12
Ok understood - no point in that then - means we need to change our thinking in terms of the webapp side away from our current framework to a node based approach

lenh

cbf
2016-09-20 19:13
webapp use the node sdk

lenh
2016-09-20 19:13

cbf
2016-09-20 19:13
it handles all the grpc comms

cbf
2016-09-20 19:13
there’s a webapp sample

cbf
2016-09-20 19:14
I am also pushing to have more samples

lenh
2016-09-20 19:15

lenh
2016-09-20 19:16

cbf

cbf

cbf
2016-09-20 19:21

lenh
2016-09-20 19:21

cbf
2016-09-20 19:22

``` // This is a compile-time assertion to ensure that this generated file // is compatible with the proto package it is being compiled against. // A compilation error at this line likely means your copy of the // proto package needs to be updated. const _ = proto1.ProtoPackageIsVersion2 // please upgrade the proto package ```

I'm unraveling all the vagrant stuff to partition the dependencies and refactor for lowest common denominator, exceptions and understanding.

lenh
2016-09-22 19:38
@ghaskins FINALLY - got the Vagrant devenv up and running on Win10. Posting steps/info here in case it helps someone else somewhere along the line... 1. Downgraded Vbox to 5.0.* and Vagrant to 1.8.4 2. Manually downloaded the latest Vbox image from here -> https://atlas.hashicorp.com/hyperledger/boxes/fabric-baseimage/versions/0.1.0/providers/virtualbox.box and renamed to virtualbox.box 3. In /devenv -> vagrant box add hyperledger/fabric-baseimage file://C:/path/to/file/virtualbox.box - then created metadata_url file in C:\Users\[name]\.vagrant.d\boxes\hyperledger-VAGRANTSLASH-fabric-baseimage and also renamed the "0" dir to 0.1.0 4. Vagrant up At this point it correctly imports the latest 0.1.0 vbox image but provisioning still fails... 5. vagrant ssh 6. rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/* 7. sudo apt-get clean 8. sudo apt-get autoclean 9. In devenv/setup.sh and in scripts/provision/common.sh, docker.sh and host.sh replaced every instance of apt-get update -qq with apt-get update -o Acquire::http::No-Cache=True 10. exit and vagrant up --provision 11. wait a while, when above drops back to bash cmd line vagrant ssh and eVoila' the correct MOTD comes up...

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:40
note that 0.1.0 is still not officially supported, but thats great you got it to work

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:41
the image itself is ok, but the fabric.git code needs this merged first: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1141/

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:41
otherwise, i am not sure what you might find

lenh
2016-09-22 19:41
taken me long enough :disappointed:

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:41
whats in master was designed to work with v0.0.11

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:42
im not sure why you need all these steps though, its very odd

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:42
is there anyone else running vagrant on windows in general?

lenh
2016-09-22 19:42

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:43
(thats a question to the channel

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:43
the biggest issue is that there is a bunch of stuff in 0.1.0 that the mainline provisioner will try to install

lenh
2016-09-22 19:43
the prov script is set to exit on error and for some reason apt-get update would inconsistently fail - what eventually did it was steps 6 through 9

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:43
(0.1.0 is kind of v0.0.11 baseimage + mainline provisioner, all baked together

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:44
so if you use 0.1.0 with mainline provisioner, there may be a collision, but it seems to have worked

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:44
you are just the first to try :wink:

lenh
2016-09-22 19:44
yeah i see - peer is already built etc

ghaskins

ghaskins

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:45
but the others

ghaskins
2016-09-22 19:45
i have a feeling its largely sorted out by the fact that the apt-gets are no-ops if its already installed

lenh
2016-09-22 19:46
so bottom line - nothing to do with this project and everything to do with apt-get, the sources etc etc - this was the only way I could get apt-get update to go through - even tried my local repo but no joy

ghaskins
2016-09-22 20:19
ok, thats good news

ghaskins
2016-09-22 20:20
if you got there, the provisioning is basically done, its just running the standard build for you at this point

ghaskins
2016-09-22 20:20
in fact, i have a patch in queue that takes the auto-build out of the provisioning path

ghaskins
2016-09-22 20:20
it means that the provisioning process from vagrant up to ssh is like 90s

ghaskins
2016-09-22 20:21
(of course, most people still have to go then kick off a build

ghaskins
2016-09-22 20:21
but I wanted to decouple the provisioning success from the building success, and also give people a chance to build what they actually need instead of assuming

ghaskins
2016-09-22 20:22
one thing though, i think at least the javaenv image does some apt-gets

ghaskins
2016-09-22 20:22
so if that is problematic in your environment, it might still bite you

2016-09-22 20:22
it's already done the java stuff i think

yacovm
2016-09-22 22:54
@ghaskins , now when I look at the commits - there were 2 of them related to protoc- 1 that you cherry picked, and another one with something in the comment saying about actual merging. I don't want to mess with it at the moment, I think it's best to delay it until the branch is ready to be merged to the master. (also, last time my dynamic compilation thing caused problems so I'm not too delighted to try something like that again at this time) Having said that- I figured that if you fool protoc by overriding the protoc-gen-go binary location, you control the outputted version of the pb.go files, so that's what i did and this is how I patched my commits branched out of the convergence branch....

lenh
2016-09-23 12:52
@ghaskins - Install on Win10 seems to be working flawlessly now: Clean Win10 environment: 1. Installed Virtualbox 5.1.6 and Vagrant 1.8.5 2. Cloned Gerrit repo exactly as per docs 3. $ cd fabric 4. $ git fetch http://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/fabric refs/changes/41/1141/2 && git checkout FETCH_HEAD 5. $ cd fabric/devenv 6. $ vagrant up 7. $ vagrant ssh - correct / expected MOTD 8. $ peer - expected help / available commands

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:54

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:54

lenh
2016-09-23 12:55
yup - that's it...

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:56

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:56
so good riddance, heh

lenh
2016-09-23 12:57
