ghaskins
2016-09-23 15:19
the difference between 0.0.11 and 0.1.0 is at provisioning time, so in theory once its provisioned, they should be compatible

ghaskins
2016-09-23 15:19
personally, i wouldnt do it with a reclone, id just switch branches

ghaskins
2016-09-23 15:19
you should be able to do “git checkout -b v0.6 origin/v0.6

ghaskins
2016-09-23 15:20
then (from within vagrant): cd $GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric && make clean peer

ghaskins
2016-09-23 15:21
there is a way to check out a specific branch at clone time, but I dont know the syntax off the top of my head as I never do that

matanyahu
2016-09-23 15:35
ok, thanks

matanyahu
2016-09-23 19:19
What does an extension --peer-chaincodedev mean in peer node start operation? What defaults does it take? What would be an alternative?

matanyahu
2016-09-23 19:23
would it be docker-compose with a custom yaml file?

silliman
2016-09-23 19:42
@matanyahu Without the --peer-chaincodedev option, when you deploy a chaincode, it will be deployed in its own Docker container. With the --peer-chaincodedev option, you can execute chaincode on the same host where your peer is running, and it will not be deployed in a separate container.

matanyahu
2016-09-23 19:47
what would be an alternative to this command and would someone decide not to use it? I've seen people on slack avoiding chaincodedev switch for no apparent reason

silliman
2016-09-23 19:50
@matanyahu I think a main purpose of the --peer-chaincodedev option is for when you are in chaincode development mode and you'd like to debug your chaincode without having to worry about Docker.

silliman
2016-09-23 19:51
@matanyahu The alternative is to simply not use the switch- in which case your chaincode will be in its own Docker container.

matanyahu
2016-09-23 19:59
which means I would have to log in to each container to see an output instead of seeing it in a verbose form on my vagrant host?

silliman
2016-09-23 20:11
@matanyahu log in or alternatively use the command *docker logs -f _containerName_* to view the log output... so --peer-chaincodedev saves you from that hassle

matanyahu
2016-09-23 20:24
thanks

matanyahu
2016-09-23 21:33
I am looking for instructions that would allow me to deploy example2 chaincode within a pbft-driven network. I launched docker-compose with the use of docker-compose-4-consensus-batch-1-byzantine.yml and then I did CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 ./chaincode_example02 just to receive the following error

matanyahu
2016-09-23 21:34
23:30:07.485 [shim] ERRO : Error trying to connect to local peer: grpc: timed out when dialing Error starting Simple chaincode: Error trying to connect to local peer: grpc: timed out when dialingvagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1history

matanyahu
2016-09-23 21:35
I assume this is related to a network port

matanyahu
2016-09-23 21:35
I did not make any modifications to the docker-compose-4-consensus-batch-1-byzantine.yml

matanyahu
2016-09-23 21:38
tried port 2375 as well, same result

silliman
2016-09-23 21:50
@matanyahu Here's my guess at what's going on- your docker-compose has launched 5 Docker containers- the 4 peers and 1 membersrvc. So your peer code is running in the 4 Docker containers. And I'm guessing that your command was done from your host, so the 0.0.0.0:7051 would refer to your host and not the containers where your peer is running. Try changing 0.0.0.0 to the IP address of one of your peer Docker containers

matanyahu
2016-09-23 21:55
my peers are assigned an address such as 172.17.0.x:7051 but whenever I try to invoke it, I receive an information that connection is refused: vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-3cfaeb5:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer$ curl -X POST -d@id.json http://172.17.0.1:7051/registrar

matanyahu
2016-09-23 21:55
curl: (7) Failed to connect to 172.17.0.1 port 7051: Connection refused

matanyahu
2016-09-23 21:56
a fragment of vp communication:

matanyahu
2016-09-23 21:56
vp1_1 | 23:50:46.865 [peer] SendMessage -> DEBU 310b Sending message to stream of type: DISC_PEERS vp2_1 | 23:50:47.682 [peer] ensureConnected -> DEBU 3108 Touch service indicates no dropped connections vp2_1 | 23:50:47.682 [peer] ensureConnected -> DEBU 3109 Connected to: [172.17.0.5:7051 172.17.0.3:7051 172.17.0.4:7051] vp2_1 | 23:50:47.682 [peer] ensureConnected -> DEBU 310a Discovery knows about: [172.17.0.3:7051 172.17.0.4:7051 172.17.0.5:7051]

silliman
2016-09-23 22:01
@matanyahu chances are 172.17.0.1 is your host's IP address- when you installed Docker, Docker automatically sets up its internal network for you. 172.17.0.1 is probably your host's IP. you need to use one of the IP addresses of your peer- it will either be 172.17.0.2 , .3 , .4, .5 or .6 (one of these will be your membersrvcs). So use one of those peer IPs and not from your host

matanyahu
2016-09-23 22:11
(I set up my environment with vagrant) @hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-3cfaeb5:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer$ curl -X POST -d@id.json http://172.17.0.2:7051/registrar curl: (7) Failed to connect to 172.17.0.2 port 7051: Connection refused vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-3cfaeb5:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer$ curl -X POST -d@id.json http://172.17.0.3:7051/registrar curl: (56) Recv failure: Connection reset by peer ▒▒vagrant@hyperledger- vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-3cfaeb5:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer$ curl -X POST -d@id.json http://172.17.0.4:7051/registrar curl: (56) Recv failure: Connection reset by peer ▒▒vagrant@hyperledger- vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-3cfaeb5:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer$ vagrant

silliman
2016-09-23 22:25
@matanyahu are you certain that 172.17.0.2 is not your membersrvcs container? You can run *docker inspect _containerName_* and you'll see the container's IP address in the output

matanyahu
2016-09-23 22:34
@matanyahu uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/matanyahu/F2FEB1U49/membersrvcs_container.txt

matanyahu
2016-09-23 22:36
vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-3cfaeb5:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer$ curl -X POST -d@id.json http://172.17.0.2:7054/registrar curl: (56) Recv failure: Connection reset by peer

silliman
2016-09-23 22:39
@matanyahu so it looks like that is your membersrvcs container- you have to send your curl request to one of the peers

silliman
2016-09-23 22:40
@matanyahu oh, and this is key... you need to send your request to the REST port which is port 7050

silliman
2016-09-23 22:41
here is a nice place where the ports are listed... https://github.com/hyperledger-archives/fabric/pull/2286

matanyahu
2016-09-23 22:47
▒vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-3cfaeb5:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer$ curl -X POST -d@id.json http://172.17.0.37050/registrar {"OK":"Login successful for user 'jim'."}

matanyahu

matanyahu
2016-09-23 23:00
but invoke works fine

matanyahu
2016-09-23 23:01

matanyahu
2016-09-23 23:01

silliman
2016-09-23 23:07
@matanyahu what are the contents of trans2.json and inv.json? Also, FYI the 'OK" from your second command, assuming it was an invoke, is just an indication that the invoke transaction was received, but something can (and probably did here) go awry

matanyahu
2016-09-23 23:09
@matanyahu uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/matanyahu/F2FE8E14N/trans2_json.txt

matanyahu
2016-09-23 23:10
@matanyahu uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/matanyahu/F2FCT4P7V/inv_json.txt

matanyahu
2016-09-23 23:10
@matanyahu uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/matanyahu/F2FE8KHBQ/query_json.txt

silliman
2016-09-23 23:16
@matanyahu ... hmmm ok I'm not certain of this but it's worth a try- I think re trans2.json, the issue may be that with the REST API you cannot do a deploy without specifying a path...and when using --peer-chaincodedev you have set up a *name* not a *path*. It is possible you may have to use the CLI to deploy it, like this *CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.3:7051 ./peer chaincode deploy -n mycc -c '{"Args": ["init","a","100","b","200"]}'* (in my example I ran this command from the directory where the peer executable lives ... .../build/bin )

silliman
2016-09-23 23:19
@matanyahu then, if you get past this....in your inv.json .... it is possible that instead of "function":"invoke" you'll need to put the function name as the first argument, i.e. "args":["invoke", "a", "b", "10"] .... then, you may have to do the same in your query.json, i.e. "args":["query", "a"]

matanyahu
2016-09-23 23:20
will do that

silliman
2016-09-23 23:41
@matanyahu I tried the advice I just gave you and it didn't work...then I looked at the latest doc http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Chaincode-setup/#chaincode-deploy-via-cli-and-rest and it looks like you should be able to deploy with REST...so I probably haven't nailed it yet.... also I see in the examples they are using "function" : "invoke", "args" : ["init", "a", "100", "b", "200" ]}' but I had thought that the function name was moved into the first argument.... I could be wrong or the doc could be out of date

silliman
2016-09-23 23:42
I meant "function" : "invoke", "args" : [ "a", "100", "b", "200" ]}' (no "init" )

silliman
2016-09-24 00:00
@matanyahu I have another theory that you may wish to investigate-- earlier you mentioned that you used *docker-compose-4-batch-1-byzantine.yml* to start up your network....but you are trying to work in --chaincode-dev mode. That YAML does not start the peer in --chaincode-dev mode. I suggest you try using *docker-compose-1-devmode.yml* which starts the peer with --chaincode-dev

matanyahu
2016-09-24 04:26
That is true, I did not deploy the network with --chaincode-dev mode but that was my express intention because docker-compose-4-batch-1-byzantine.yml allows me to run a network with characteristics I am looking for (PBFT, 4 nodes, membership services and so on)

matanyahu
2016-09-24 04:27
should I use another chaincode to test such conditions instead?

matanyahu
2016-09-24 04:29
I should be capable of deploying it because it is possible on bluemix

cbf
2016-09-24 11:11
@matanyahu the REST API is deprecated, and not in the mainstream of testing. Suggest that you use the Node SDK to interact with the peer network (deploying, invoking, querying chaincode) or use the 'peer chaincode’ CLI commands.

matanyahu
2016-09-24 18:11
Quick question: when I run "peer node start --peer-chaincodedev", a practical effect is an execution of a single VP with NOOPS consensus?

yacovm
2016-09-24 18:12
I think it depends on your config

matanyahu
2016-09-24 18:13

yacovm
2016-09-24 18:15
I'm not familiar with the --peer-chancodedev (haven't seen in in the code, it was added at some point I think) but the consensus algorithm and others are determined via the config file, core.yaml

yacovm
2016-09-24 18:16
there you can specify whats the algorithm. at least that's what was a few months ago, unless it has changed

matanyahu
2016-09-24 18:17
although I reconfigured core.yaml to launch pbft consensus, the abovementioned command only launches a single peer which obviously selects noops as default

matanyahu
2016-09-24 18:18
that's my logical understanding of things

yacovm
2016-09-24 18:18
why? N=1, f=0

yacovm
2016-09-24 18:18
the conditions for PBFT is N >= 3f+1

yacovm
2016-09-24 18:19
you can verify in the logs

yacovm
2016-09-24 18:19
it says what algorithm it selected when the peer starts

muralisr
2016-09-24 18:57
@matanyahu devmode defaults to noops

garisingh
2016-09-25 11:08
@matanyahu - things worked for me. One step needed when doing `CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.3:7051 peer network login admin`

garisingh
2016-09-25 11:08
you need to run `mkdir /var/hyperledger/production` first

matanyahu
2016-09-25 12:59
will try it at once on a fresh new vagrant VM will following steps

matanyahu
2016-09-25 13:01
(1) docker-compose -f docker-compose-4-consensus-batch.yml (I find no reason to edit core.yaml and/or membersrvc.yaml files since all settings are enforced through docker-compose[...]yml files)

matanyahu
2016-09-25 13:02
(2) mkdir /var/hyperledger/production

matanyahu
2016-09-25 13:02
(3) CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.3:7051 peer network login admin

matanyahu
2016-09-25 13:03
(4) peer chaincode deploy -u admin -p http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02 -c '{"Function":"init", "Args": ["a","100", "b", "200"]}'

matanyahu
2016-09-25 13:57
@garisingh : it works!

matanyahu
2016-09-25 13:57
I just had to modify peer chaincode deploy command

matanyahu
2016-09-25 13:57
vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-3cfaeb5:~$ CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.3:7051 peer chaincode deploy -u admin -p http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02 -c '{"Function":"init", "Args": ["a","100", "b", "200"]}' Deploy chaincode: ee5b24a1f17c356dd5f6e37307922e39ddba12e5d2e203ed93401d7d05eb0dd194fb9070549c5dc31eb63f4e654dbd5a1d86cbb30c48e3ab1812590cd0f78539

pushpalatha
2016-09-26 06:42
Hi All, Is there a way we get the information of which node initiated a particular transaction?

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 12:58
has joined #fabric-dev-env

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 13:07
Hey all, does anyone know how you;d go about finding the name of the user whose made a chaincode invocation in v0.6? (v0.5 had it in the transaction certs but that no longer is the case)

sheehan
2016-09-27 00:45
@tom.appleyard try asking in the #membership-services channel. You’ll likely need to use a tcert attribute

tom.appleyard
2016-09-27 08:07
@sheehan I'll give them a go - maybe but that seems a bit of a strange move given we've previously had a field (common name) specifically for this data :confused:

g_alexander
2016-09-27 09:13
has joined #fabric-dev-env

cbf
2016-09-27 12:16
@tom.appleyard one of the use cases is transactions in a network where the transactors wish to remain anonymous in the context of the transaction

cbf
2016-09-27 12:18
in other words, if you and I wanted to make a trade, yet we are known to be in this channel with 173 others, but we don’t want the other 173 members to know it was us who made the trade, yet the facts of the trade need to be known to all - in that case you want to obscure who made the trade

andreaturli
2016-09-27 14:51
has joined #fabric-dev-env

sbrakev
2016-09-27 18:39
has joined #fabric-dev-env

wil.pannell

has joined #fabric-dev-env

lenh
2016-09-29 10:47
@ghaskins - quick question - I see by default the devenv VM runs on IP 10.0.2.15 - are the various ports forwarded on that IP such that from another VM one should be able to "curl 10.0.2.15:5070/chain" and get a response?

yacovm
2016-09-29 10:59
no, it's a private network between the host and the guest

lenh
2016-09-29 11:00
aha - ok - is there a way to do what's described above?

lenh
2016-09-29 11:02
essentially what I'm asking is there a way to run devenv VM with membersrvc and peer running such that one can connect to the various ports from another VM...

yacovm
2016-09-29 11:14
I have a deja voo

ghaskins
2016-09-29 11:41
@lenh the “fabric supported” way to do this would be to use the port forwards that we have set up

ghaskins
2016-09-29 11:41
that is, ports 7050-7054 are forwarded from your host to the devenv, so you cna use your host IP for other nodes to reach

ghaskins
2016-09-29 11:42
that said, if you wanted to you could modify the Vagrantfile to add a public interface

lenh
2016-09-29 11:42
ok thanks

ghaskins
2016-09-29 11:43
this would be a local change that you wouldnt want to push back upstream,

lenh
2016-09-29 11:43
sure

ghaskins
2016-09-29 11:44
@ghaskins uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F2HDZPASX/-.rb and commented: @lenh here is a Vagrantfile from a different project I am working on that does something like you are asking about

ghaskins
2016-09-29 11:44
see line 15

lenh
2016-09-29 11:45
thanks will give that a bash

shannon_wie
2016-09-30 05:55
has joined #fabric-dev-env

lenh
2016-09-30 14:15
is there a reason why ```make membersrvc``` reverts with ```make: Nothing to be done for `membersrvc'.```

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:24
@lenh the makefile tries to be smart about knowing if it needs to rebuild something

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:24
in this case, it thinks membersrvc is up to date

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:24
do you have a reason to believe it needs to be rebuilt?

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:24
its always possible there is a bug

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:25
for instance, if you edited any of the .go files, it should trigger a rebuild

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:27
if you find that you have edited files and it stays says “Nothing to be done”, there is a big

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:27
bug

yacovm
2016-09-30 14:28
how can he have edited files? he's not developing the fabric, he's playing with it, IIUC

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:30
I didn’t say he did….im saying that its normal for “make membersrvc” to say “Nothing to be done” if it believes there is nothing to be done

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:31
his question implied it was unexpected for it to do this

yacovm
2016-09-30 14:31
my guess is that the binary isn't found (by him) and his make isn't working

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:31
and indeed, if he edited files, it would be unexpected for it to do this

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:32
seems unlikely, but I am always open minded

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:32
@lenh you can check in ./build/bin

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:32
im guessing you will find you already have ./build/bin/membersrvc

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:35
also note, if you are working in the devenv, the ./build/bin directory should already be in your $PATH

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:36
so you can do things like “which membersrvc” or simply “membersrvc"

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:37
@lenh also apologies for dropping the ball on the request to update your fabric, was just reminded of this when reviewing the history

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:38
this is def a downside to having so many slack channels…easy to get distracted and then forget, heh

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:38
are you all set now or do you still need to get to the latest stuff?

that is why the “make” says “nothing to do"

lenh
2016-09-30 14:47

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:47

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:47
yeah, more recent versions of membersrvc are disturbingly silent

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:47
but this is in fact normal

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:48
i was tripped up by this myself a few weeks ago

lenh
2016-09-30 14:48

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:48
thought it was busted, spent 10 minutes chasing it down

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:48
i think you can modify the logging levels if you want the old behavior

lenh
2016-09-30 14:48
make behave also gives...

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:48
but I havent tried this, i just accepted that it was FAD and moved on

lenh
2016-09-30 14:49
``` When requesting "/chain" from "vp0" # None Then I should get a JSON response with "height" = "3" # None 14:36:11 - context.failed = True Failing scenarios: java_shim.feature:121 Java TableExample chaincode single peer 4 features passed, 1 failed, 3 skipped 39 scenarios passed, 1 failed, 9 skipped 549 steps passed, 1 failed, 270 skipped, 0 undefined Took 18m53.530s make: *** [behave] Error 1 ```

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:50
unless you changed the code, i wouldn’t worry about behave failing _too_ much…there were some flaky tests in behave so it was removed from the CI verification process until it can be fixed

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:50
this means two things

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:50
1) theres been a long history of flaky tests, this could be one of them

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:50
2) because its no longer verified by CI, its highly likely that new failing tests have been introduced

lenh
2016-09-30 14:50
ok which means the docs are behind

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:50
yes

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:51
its good to be aware of in general, as we need to get it fixed again

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:52
but jfyi, its currently flaky and thus you can expect some failures if you run it

ghaskins
2016-09-30 14:52
its not necessarily an indication that your environment is messed up

lenh

2016-09-30 15:35

2016-09-30 15:35

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:35
ok, cool

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:36
since im not sure of your familiarity with git concepts, ill start basic but just tell me if you want to fast forward

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:36
in a nutshell, one of the most confusing things for people new to git is the notion that each “clone” is essentially a full copy of the repo, history and all

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:37
therefore, there are two classes of commands

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:37
ones that operate just on your local clone, and ones that are meant to synchronize between clones

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:37
“git commit” falls into the former category, but this often catches people by surprise since “commit” sounds all official

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:38
it just means its commited to your local copy

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:38
and you dont need permissions (or even an active internet connection) to do this

lenh
2016-09-30 15:38
i've used git locally only for my own needs - never pushing to a "master"

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:38
ok, cool

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:38
so, the next level then is the pushing/pulling

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:39
now, for normal git, you typically can push patches right to some remote repo, assuming you have write permissions

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:40
you can do this various ways, but one way might look something like “git push origin HEAD:my-new-branch"

lenh
2016-09-30 15:40
i've found git to be a rather confusing "young lady"....

lenh
2016-09-30 15:40
ok...

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:40
that says push my current tree (“HEAD” to a remote branch called “my-new-branch"

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:40
(on the repo “origin"

lenh
2016-09-30 15:41
sure - but issued from what dir?

lenh
2016-09-30 15:41
and in this case... we set cmd line args?

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:41
but we have this thing in the middle (gerrit) which acts as a gate for submissions..you cant write to the tree directly

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:41
generally, from anywhere in the tree where your repo is

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:41
though i tend to do most operations from the root of the project

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:42
some commands, like git ls-files can be context specific

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:42
that said, I think “git push” isnt

lenh
2016-09-30 15:42
so help me here - i cloned the repo - it's on my local and mapped to my VM

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:42
but I just make a habit of being in the root

lenh
2016-09-30 15:42
so now I wanna make a change to the doc...

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:42
yep, and technically you could do these operations from either your host or the VM

lenh
2016-09-30 15:42
how?

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:43
but I would advise you do them from the host

lenh
2016-09-30 15:43
ok...

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:43
it will have your editor, etc

lenh
2016-09-30 15:43
ok i get it... pull the doc from gerrit

lenh
2016-09-30 15:43
branch it

lenh
2016-09-30 15:43
push it?

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:43
so, as you probably know from the past experience, edit the doc locally

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:44
yep, the branching is up to you

yacovm
2016-09-30 15:44
when you commit don't forget to add `Signed-off-by: your name <email address>`

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:44
but you would generally be doing pull -> edit -> commit -> push

lenh
2016-09-30 15:44
ok so one thing - how do i pull just that doc?

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:44
yes, good point @yacovm , there are several requirements for the commit message you attache

lenh
2016-09-30 15:44
sorry guys real noob to this

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:45
@lenh there might be ways to pull just the file, but that is not what I would do

lenh
2016-09-30 15:45
yes - saw that - will read the guidelines

yacovm
2016-09-30 15:45
you don't pull just the doc, you just change the doc and then git knows what're the changes and paints them red/green

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:45
just work with the entire tree

lenh
2016-09-30 15:45
ok but guys where on my local is the doc? that's my question

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:46
right, as @yacovm mentioned, git will know you only changed N files

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:46
oh, i see

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:46
i think its in one of the .md files, but we’d have to search for it

lenh
2016-09-30 15:46
ok /docs

yacovm
2016-09-30 15:46
I think there is a wiki repo which is different from the fabric

yacovm
2016-09-30 15:46
if he needs to change there

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:47
i think in this case its an .md change

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:47
in the fabric.git

lenh
2016-09-30 15:47
ok slowwwwwly getting it

lenh
2016-09-30 15:47
in /hyperldeger/docs

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:48
yeah, its likely in there

lenh
2016-09-30 15:48
make the change then "git push origin HEAD:my-new-branch"

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:48
so you just edit the .md file to taste, and when its ready git-commit and then git-push it to gerrit

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:48
well, almost

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:48
gerrit is a little weird

lenh
2016-09-30 15:49
to gerrit?

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:49
you dont have direct write access to the tree, you need to make a proposal

lenh
2016-09-30 15:49
ok

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:49
to do that, you basically do “git push origin HEAD:refs/for/$branch"

yacovm
2016-09-30 15:50
or... you can just install git-review and it'll do the dirty work for you

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:50
where $branch is the upstream branch you are proposing to modify, like “master” or “v0.6"

yacovm
2016-09-30 15:50
and then you can just "git-review" and that's it

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:50
ill defer to @yacovm on git-review, i dont use it so I cant offer any advice there

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:51
but I know plenty of folks do

lenh
2016-09-30 15:51
ok better - so git push origin HEAD:refs/for/git-review?

yacovm
2016-09-30 15:51
you can read here, if you want. https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Gerrit/git-review

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:51
no, i think it would be something like "git push origin HEAD:refs/for/master”, or you can alternatively use git-review instead of manually managing the push

yacovm
2016-09-30 15:52
it also does a rebase for you, by the way

lenh
2016-09-30 15:52
ok - no probs - will dive into this and see what's what...

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:52
now, once you do that, if everything is formatted correctly, your proposal will show up in the UI here: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/q/status:open

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:52
there are a couple of things though to note

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:52
your commit message has several requirements

yacovm
2016-09-30 15:53
@ghaskins , do you do non-environmental CRs?

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:53
@yacovm already mentioned the SIgned-off-by

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:54
You will also need a ChangeId, which you can read about here https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/Documentation/user-upload.html#push_create

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:55
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/Documentation/user-changeid.html

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:55
there is a local git hook you can install which is detailed in those instructions which will generate this for you

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:55
and lastly, i think we limit line length to something like 70 characters

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:56
but assuming all of that looks good, it will show up in the UI for others to review

lenh
2016-09-30 15:56
ok - will go on this side mission to figure out how to use git / gerrit properly - never envisaged getting involved at this level but all good...

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:57
its totally up to you, but we appreciate the contribution if you decide to

lenh
2016-09-30 15:57
guess that's what makes community :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:57
its a slight PITA to deal with gerrit, but once you get it its not that hard to use

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:58
@yacovm I am not even sure what “non-environmental CRs” are, so I am guessing the answer is “no” :wink:

yacovm
2016-09-30 15:59

yacovm
2016-09-30 15:59
like ledger code, peer code, etc. etc.

ghaskins
2016-09-30 15:59

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:00

yacovm
2016-09-30 16:00
not urgent, was just asking for general knowledge

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:00

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:01
but I hope to get back into fabric dev more over the next few months

lenh
2016-09-30 16:01

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:01

lenh
2016-09-30 16:01
something that can guide people coming from the outside to ease their way into HL

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:02
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:02
@lenh yeah, point taken…i know we are trying to get our wiki setup which will help with that

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:03
also, the guides as you mention

lenh
2016-09-30 16:03
there are so many moving parts (apart from the fact HL is in incubation) that it makes it frustrating to navigate the landscape

yacovm
2016-09-30 16:03
cool

lenh
2016-09-30 16:03
of course when V1.0 happens and we get to LTS things will settle down.,...

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:04
@lenh yeah, and I think you are entering at a particularly tumultuous time…things are being refactored etc…a lot of the doc was w.r.t. the v0.5 design and a lot of it is changing in the features/convergence branch

lenh
2016-09-30 16:04
100%

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:04
so people that are coming in are getting caught in the middle of the two

lenh
2016-09-30 16:04
and unless you are "inside" it leaves one in a vacuum...

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:05
yeah, and even when you are “inside” its not always easy to follow the rapidly evolving code base

lenh
2016-09-30 16:05
along with the "strange" design decisions like dumping the REST API

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:06
heh, well, that makes more sense when you know the history

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:06
it was the presence of the API itself that was perhaps “strange"

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:06
:wink:

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:06
i can explain that statement, though

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:07
but suffice to say, it was a non-inuitive architectural detail that caused great confusion

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:07
so, it going away is part of the effort to straighten that out

lenh
2016-09-30 16:07
I just find it odd that we have the 3 layers - core -chaincode and whatever else and the whatever else layer which should be "open" is being pushed to Node

lenh
2016-09-30 16:08
unless i'm missing something (which is quite likely through lack of knowledge..)

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:08
the basic issue is that the “peer” codebase was designed to be used in two distinct different contexts…and the API was exposing one of those contexts

lenh
2016-09-30 16:09
ah....

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:09
but because it was attached to one “process”, the lines became blurred

yacovm
2016-09-30 16:09
if you think that's odd you're in for a treat for future releases...

lenh
2016-09-30 16:10
ok.... but i would think we would want to make it "easy" from the outer ring inwards...

lenh
2016-09-30 16:10
so web apps - build in whatever - here's the API

lenh
2016-09-30 16:10
chaincode - go / java

lenh
2016-09-30 16:10
core - it's specifics

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:10
thats exactly the intention

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:11
before, part of the “webapp” stack was integrated into the peer when running in NVP mode

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:11
the REST interface served to connect the front end and backend in this capacity

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:11
but in doing so, it required a very unatural relationship to security details

lenh
2016-09-30 16:11
I also get that codebases are being merged and that in itself is no mean feat

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:12
so, those aspects are being broken out so that the portions that were handled by “client NVP” are integrated into the SDK that runs coresident with the app

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:12
which is much more natural from a security perspective…and also, should help to reduce process sprawl

lenh
2016-09-30 16:13
sure - cbf suggested possibly something like -> https://github.com/grpc-ecosystem/grpc-gateway

lenh
2016-09-30 16:13
as an abstraction

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:13
this isnt to indict REST apis vs something else…but rather, the REST API that was implemented served the front-end/back-end interface for this client NVP thing

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:14
and since the client NVP thing is going away, the REST API is too

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:14
if that makes sense

lenh
2016-09-30 16:15
I guess what I'm getting it is REST is "easy" for web-app dev's to wrap their heads wound...

lenh
2016-09-30 16:15
which would go a long way to getting community adoption

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:15
yeah, understood…the problem is the crypto, etc, are not trivial

lenh
2016-09-30 16:15
yes 100%

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:16
so, it was felt it could be expressed more precisely with GRPC schema than, say, swagger, and then that can be the integration point

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:16
(its probably more important to “pick one” than “pick X"

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:16
but GRPC was the decision

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:17
anyway, the intetion is that your typically webapp would interface to say a nodejs backend, and that would inteface to the SDK which manages the GRPC for you

lenh
2016-09-30 16:17
I am sure the decision re gRPC was correct but the idea of a gRPC/JSON proxy on the face of it sounds like a viable solution

lenh
2016-09-30 16:17
but hey what the hell do I know

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:17
yes, i agree..I think that is the intention

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:17
you would have to replicate the crypto protocols, etc, but it should be possible

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:18
but this is exactly what we are seeing now…we have proposals for SDKs in node, python, java

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:18
coded to the GRPC “standard"

lenh
2016-09-30 16:18
but coudn't the node sdk be proxied?

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:18
yes, it was designed for this

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:19
for instance, the notion of “registrar” is precisely to deal with proxy scenarios

lenh
2016-09-30 16:19
i tried to find the .proto files in the node sdk (HFC node install)...

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:19
look in fabric.git…they are mostly under ./protos and copied to the SDK during compilation

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:20
not sure where they end up in the NPM package

ghaskins
2016-09-30 16:20
ok, kid to bus now…bbiab

lenh
2016-09-30 16:20
yeah I saw those but for the life of me it made no sense - but also I'm no kick-ass developer

lenh
2016-09-30 16:20
later bud

yacovm
2016-09-30 16:21

2016-09-30 16:58

yacovm
2016-09-30 16:58

2016-09-30 16:59

yacovm
2016-09-30 17:00

ghaskins
2016-09-30 17:00

ghaskins
2016-09-30 17:00

ghaskins
2016-09-30 17:01

ghaskins
2016-09-30 17:01

ghaskins

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-09-30 17:04

ghaskins
2016-09-30 17:05

ghaskins
2016-09-30 17:05

yacovm

yacovm
2016-09-30 17:05

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-10-03 12:53
@yacovm I started to prepare the next update to baseimage which includes 1.7, but its not released yet

yacovm
2016-10-03 12:54
huh? I saw something was merged

ghaskins
2016-10-03 12:54
yes, a patch was merged to fabric-baseimage.git, but this is not the same as cutting a release

ghaskins
2016-10-03 12:55
two extra steps have to happen….a new image is pushed to dockerhub/atlas, and fabric.git is updated to point to it

ghaskins
2016-10-03 12:55
I’m still working on some kinks in a patch that updates from 14.04 to 16.04

ghaskins
2016-10-03 12:55
once that is done, ill likely propose a new release

yacovm
2016-10-03 12:56

2016-10-03 13:01

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:01
everything seems to work exactly like it does in 1.6, except the version number is different

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:01
ah, cool…i didnt look that deep

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:02
only made sure build/unit-test/behave worked

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:04
@yacovm anyway, to answer your question: monitor this file

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:04
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/.baseimage-release

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:04
that will tell you when it changes

yacovm
2016-10-03 13:05
that was the one i incremented to 1.1 and then it was reverted to 1.0?

yacovm
2016-10-03 13:05
0.1.1

yacovm
2016-10-03 13:05
oh no

yacovm
2016-10-03 13:05
that was in a different path

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:06
no, the history has been 0.0.9->0.0.10->0.0.11->0.1.0

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:07
but I do have a 0.1.1-snapshot in the baseimage.git tree, perhaps that is what you saw

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:07
but like I said, that isnt released yet

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:08
(the only real difference between 0.0.11 and 0.1.0 is the method in which it was built

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:08
0.0.x was built manually by me on a local machine and pushed out, whereas 0.1.0 was built by jenkins

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:09
from there, changes to the baseimage go through gerrit/jenkins, as we saw the recent patches for things like 1.7

yacovm
2016-10-03 13:11
what does that mean if someone gives me +1 on gerrit and not +2?

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:36
+1 means “LGTM, but someone else needs to approve"

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:36
note that non-maintainers can only give -1/0/+1

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:36
maintainers can chose -2-+2

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:37
so if it was a maintainer +1, they probably felt as though an SME should chime in

ghaskins
2016-10-03 13:39
(related: -1 means “this cant go in until some changes are made, and -2 means “this shouldn’t go in at all"

yacovm
2016-10-03 13:52
SME?

silliman
2016-10-03 14:11
@yacovm SME == Subject Matter Expert

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:43
@ghaskins sorry if this question has been asked before, I saw “hyperledger/fabric-baseimage-sandbox” is now published to docker hub, it’s a great enhancement! solves a long-time gnarly error when trying to use docker to set up a network outside of vagrant, where the “network” mode doesn’t work when you try to deploy chaincode, because the hyperledger/fabric-baseimage is missing a bunch of content.

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:43

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:44

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:45

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:45

ghaskins

ghaskins

ghaskins

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:45

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:46

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:46
is the plan to have fabric-baseimage itself be fully built?

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:46
(read through your google doc proposal, thought that was the plan…)

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:46
(just confirming…)

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:46
well, the plan is that “baseimage” will become what it was always intended: a build-time optimization and not a runtime resource

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:47
right now, its kind of both

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:47
which, as you have discovered, is a problem

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:47
going forward, no runtime references to “baseimage” anything will be made

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:48
ok, so then for the runtime resource, where peer needs a base image to spin up instances for running chaincode, it’ll ask for a different image?

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:48
historically, the primary issue is that chaincode deployment depended on baseimage:latest being present

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:48
yep

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:48
yes, exactly

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:48
ok

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:48
so hyperledger/fabric-ccenv will primarily fill this role

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:48
ah

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:48
but we arent publishing it yet, so it acts kind of like baseimage:latest does

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:48
that is, it only works if you build fabric locally

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:49
we will be fixing this

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:49
i see

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:49
theres a new templating engine that is in master

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:49
you can get a sense of the direction if you study this:

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:49
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/peer/core.yaml#L285

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:50
do you have the FAB # for track this handy?

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:50
that allows us to, for example, pin the ccenv to the same release as the peer

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:50
ok will take a look

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:50
its actually pretty close to ready at this point, we just arent pushing the images out yet

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:50
I cant recall if there is a FAB, there might be

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:50
got it

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:50
(sorry, too many balls in the air right now)

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:51

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:51

jzhang

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:51

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:51

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:52
long story short, right now things only work if you build locally first (unless you hand massage the system)

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:52
but soon, it will work in a pure docker flow

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:52

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:52

jzhang

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:53

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:53
yes, though I think all you should really need is “make images” from fabric.git

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:54
but i need vagrant for that right?

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:54
baseimage building should only be necessary if you are changing the baseimage, or are wanting to support non-x86

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:54
you dont need vagrant per se, just an environment capable of supporting the fabric build

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:55
if i can run “make images” from fabric without vagrant then i’d definitely do that

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:55
remember, fabric.git::master doesnt use baseimage at runtime

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:55
ok

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:55
but you do need to make sure you have fabric-ccenv

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:55
which, building “make images” will get you that

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:56
cool

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:56
plus building the baseimage is sloooooowww

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:56
:wink:

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:56
so youll be happy to avoid that

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:56
(yes very slow)

jzhang
2016-10-03 19:56
thanks for all this, very nice work!

ghaskins
2016-10-03 19:57
ty, ill hopefully have something that satisfies your usecase soon

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:01
@jzhang btw: vagrant is much lighter weight to stand up now

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:01
not sure why you are avoiding it, but if it was because the provisioning was slow, that is fixed in master

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:01
it takes about 60-90 seconds to stand up

yacovm
2016-10-03 20:01
what?! you serious?

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:02
yeah

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:02
try it :slightly_smiling_face:

yacovm
2016-10-03 20:02
what did you do?

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:02
bunch of stuff, the biggest was that I moved almost everything into the baseimage

yacovm
2016-10-03 20:02
you wanna tell me i do git clone and then vagrant up and it takes 90 sec? not a chance

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:02
so its all installed already before you even type “vagrant up"

yacovm
2016-10-03 20:02
sounds sci-fi

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:02
it does for me, and I am on a 2011 laptop

yacovm
2016-10-03 20:03
I'm on a 2017

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:03
nice!

yacovm
2016-10-03 20:03
I'll try and check

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:03
one caveat, the baseimage.box has to be downloaded the first time

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:03
so first boot will be slightly slower

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:03
depending on your internet speed

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:04
so 60-90 is assuming you have the image already

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:04
but it gets cached, so its pretty good for subsequent builds

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:07
just ran one

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:08
real 1m37.301s user 0m5.094s sys 0m2.481s

jzhang
2016-10-03 20:18
@ghaskins good to know about the vagrant speed up, I’m sure it’ll help many peer contributors. from my standpoint, I have two hats: 1) node.js SDK contributor, 2) advocate for good experience for application (including chaincode and app dev) developers. for both of my roles, I’d like to avoid vagrant since a docker-based set up is more standard in the node.js world

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:23
yeah, though I am not convinced a docker based flow is good for peer/ca development

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:23
it goes against the grain on docker to use it that way

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:23
i think it makes a ton of sense for _runtime_ though

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:24
e.g. I just want to “docker run …-peer” to stand it up

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:24
as far as having all the tooling you need to compile it, etc, not sure it makes as much sense, and vagrant is a good fit there

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:25
so, i see both as continuing to have a role going forward

jzhang
2016-10-03 20:25
yes, we are agreeing. i was also saying vagrant is good for peer/ca contributors.

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:25
right ok

jzhang
2016-10-03 20:26
node.js SDK is now a standalone project, separated from fabric

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:26
is that completed now?

ghaskins
2016-10-03 20:26
i saw it was being broken out

ghaskins

ghaskins

ghaskins

hfeeki
2016-10-06 03:57
Hi, guys, Morning!

hfeeki
2016-10-06 04:19
I think fabric v1’s write-set have some problem. In the document, is said write-set will like this: ``` <TxReadWriteSet> <NsReadWriteSet name="chaincode1"> <read-set> <read key="K1", version="1"> <read key="K2", version="1"> </read-set> <write-set> <write key="K1", value="V1”> <write key="K3", value="V2”> <write key="K4", isDelete="true”> </write-set> </NsReadWriteSet> <TxReadWriteSet> ``` But , this will cause can just update once for a specific key in one batch transactions, in one batch txs just can write once for a key, that means in a one chaincode1's instance 1: ``` <TxReadWriteSet> <NsReadWriteSet name="chaincode1"> <write-set> <write key="K1", value=“150”> </write-set> </NsReadWriteSet> <TxReadWriteSet> ``` chaincode1's instance 2: ``` <TxReadWriteSet> <NsReadWriteSet name="chaincode1"> <write-set> <write key="K1", value=“200”> </write-set> </NsReadWriteSet> <TxReadWriteSet> ``` The same chaincode's two instance can not execute in one batch, but if it change like next: ``` <TxReadWriteSet> <NsReadWriteSet name="chaincode1"> <write-set> <write key="K1", version=“1”, action=“+100”> </write-set> </NsReadWriteSet> <TxReadWriteSet> ``` and next: ``` <TxReadWriteSet> <NsReadWriteSet name="chaincode1"> <write-set> <write key="K1", version=“1”, action=“-10”> </write-set> </NsReadWriteSet> <TxReadWriteSet> ``` it will be ok.

hfeeki
2016-10-06 04:20
and it will more security because add version field

cca
2016-10-06 07:24
has joined #fabric-dev-env

2016-10-15 19:35

yacovm

muralisr
2016-10-15 19:49
duck programming ? :slightly_smiling_face:

jonathanlevi
2016-10-15 19:49
https://unspace.ca/dev/2012/duck-programming ?

jonathanlevi
2016-10-15 19:50
"Duck Programming is any configuration that defines or controls mission-critical behaviour of a software system that is thought to be “not programming” because it doesn’t appear to involve programmers, programming languages, or programming tools."

jonathanlevi
2016-10-15 19:51
@yacovm is that what you meant?

yacovm
2016-10-15 19:51
no, I meant: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rubber_duck_debugging

yacovm
2016-10-15 19:51
TLDR: you think out loud

muralisr
2016-10-15 19:52
pretty effective as long as noones around you :slightly_smiling_face:

yacovm
2016-10-15 20:21
@muralisr Still doesn't work, I copied the chaincode pem and key files and I get: ` 2016/10/15 20:20:04 grpc: Server.Serve failed to complete security handshake from "172.17.0.5:55340": remote error: bad certificate `

muralisr
2016-10-15 20:25
can you try with CORE_PEER_TLS_SERVERHOSTOVERRIDE=dummy (the value used in chaincodetest.yaml) ?

yacovm
2016-10-15 20:25
yeah

muralisr
2016-10-15 20:27
need to leave but can wait for 5 more mins :slightly_smiling_face:

yacovm
2016-10-15 20:32

muralisr
2016-10-15 20:33
great

yacovm
2016-10-15 20:34
why am i still getting ` ESC[33mvp0_1 | ESC[0mESC[36m20:32:55.933 [crypto] Debug -> DEBU 01aESC[0m [validator.test_vp0] TLS disabled... ` ?

yacovm
2016-10-15 20:34
I made it - CORE_PEER_TLS_ENABLED=true

yacovm
2016-10-15 20:35
aha!!!!

yacovm
2016-10-15 20:35
ok it works

yacovm
2016-10-15 20:35
many thanks

muralisr
2016-10-15 20:36
ok, good luck :slightly_smiling_face:

garisingh
2016-10-16 01:18
@vrgl - you need to install gnu-tar and make it the default. The tar binary which ships with OSX is not compatible with Linux gnu tar in this case

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-10-30 13:04

2016-10-30 14:08

http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/orderer/atomicbroadcast.BroadcastResponse composite literal uses unkeyed fields orderer/solo/broadcast.go:177: http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/orderer/atomicbroadcast.BroadcastResponse composite literal uses unkeyed fields orderer/solo/broadcast.go:182: cbf
2016-11-02 18:54
@dave.enyeart port 5984 for CouchDB is exposed in the vagrant environment. However, if the developer has CouchDB running natively, the ports conflict

cbf
2016-11-02 18:54
so, for instance, I cannot launch the vagrant environment any longer

cbf
2016-11-02 18:56

cbf
2016-11-02 18:56
thoughts?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 12:40
@tom.appleyard in the current build, it is possible to build both a native peer binary and a docker-based binary….however, theres a dependency on docker in general regardless of which method you choose because the peer uses docker to contain chainccode instances

ghaskins
2016-11-03 12:41
that said, I agree with @yacovm: it looks like you have some kind of networking problem

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:17
which means you should have also had the updated vendor/protobuf library, which would have been used to compile protoc-gen-go

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:18

jyellick
2016-11-03 15:18

yacovm
2016-11-03 15:19
from what I know- the pb.go files that are outputted are effected by the protobuf in the vendor folder.

yacovm
2016-11-03 15:19
it works like this: protoc looks for a file called `protoc-gen-go`

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:19
@yacovm yes, I believe that is true

yacovm
2016-11-03 15:19
you can "control" the protobuff version that is outputted by manipulating your PATH

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:19
one interesting side note, I think @yacovm did the work to update the vendor lib _before_ 3.1.0 came out

yacovm
2016-11-03 15:20

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:20

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:20
yes, I believe we did

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:20

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:20

jyellick
2016-11-03 15:21

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:21
we updated from v3.0.2 to v3.1.0 to support Z, but I dont think vendor was also updated

yacovm
2016-11-03 15:21

2016-11-03 15:21
is that bad?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:21

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:22

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:36
as a high level comment, I would say format produced from devenv is authoritative over produced by native tooling

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:36
all else being equal, and barring bugs (e.g. FAB-947)

yacovm
2016-11-03 15:36
of course...

yacovm
2016-11-03 15:36
the devenv defines what should be inside

ghaskins
2016-11-03 15:37
so, if in doubt, recompile from devenv tooling ahead of your .proto updating patch, and we can get that in there

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:04
@ghaskins want to follow up on the topic in #fabric-maintainers that @cbf brought up regarding publishing the v1.0 docker images. the SDK teams (node.js, java, python) would greatly benefit from this because it allows them to do development in the native host environment without vagrant

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:05
well, independent from that, we are also working on making the development environment vagrant free

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:05
would that be helpful?

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:06
an even bigger benefit is it allows the test prep to be done automatically so the test bucket can run in the local host environment without requiring manually setting up the target network.

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:06
which?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:07
sorry, which provides that benefit?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:07
(the image publication or the eradication of vagrant) ?

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:08
image publication will enable me to set up the target network without vagrant

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:08
with the patch queue I am preparing, any docker compatible host (linux, docker-for-mac, docker-for-win) can just clone fabric && make

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:09
that’s very useful, however I think for SDK contributors in most cases a daily published images are sufficient

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:10
so they don’t need to always stay on the latest fabric code and build locally

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:10
I have concerns about the published image model though

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:10
really? isn’t that what we’ve been doing though?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:11
sorry, i mean -snapshot publication

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:11
not releases

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:11
those are fine

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:11
oh...

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:11
there would be a few issues to sort out, and a few issues that really cant be sorted out with that model

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:12
for one thing, today we build every snapshot with a unique hash in the name

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:12
so you would have no deterministic target to pull from

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:12
we can mitigate that with :latest or similar, but that has problems with repeatability

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:13
and then there is the question of abuse of the storage on dockerhub as a more minor concern

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:14
to be clear: I am not saying I am voting against this: I just have some concerns

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:14
i’d say having a :latest and a :sprint-end is sufficient

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:14
yes, but :latest what?

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:14
even just :latest

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:15
fabric-peer:latest ? what is that? x86_64 or s390x? v0.6:latest or v1.0:latest, etc

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:15
can we use a naming scheme with v1.0 in the name?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:15
we could have fabric-peer:s390x-1.0.0-snapshot

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:16
i remember that now

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:16
that would get you closer…but its still impacts repeatability

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:16
it may work today, but not tomorrow

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:17
right now I am of the mindset that we are better to reduce the friction of producing the artifacts and let those environments link that way

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:17
"still impacts repeatability” - can you elaborate?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:17
well, say todays image “works” and tomorrows image “doesnt"

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:17
you could have a test that you run today…touch nothing, and get a different result tomorrow

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:17
thus, its not a repeatable operation

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:18
generally this should be avoided

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:18
i’d say having “fabric-peer:x86_64-1.0.0-latest” is going to make a number of use cases happy (local tests, CI jobs)

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:18
well, “happy” != “deterministic” or “reliable” :wink:

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:19
i understand what you are after, i just have concerns with the model

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:19
"a test that you run today…touch nothing, and get a different result tomorrow” - why would that be?

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:20
you mean the fabric-peer has progressed and updated and now doesn’t work with my SDK code because the peer broke in the latest build?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:20
ok, say todays "s390x-1.0.0-snapshot” works flawlessly and tomorrows is a repackaged /bin/true

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:20
you could have an SDK workflow that is non deterministic even if nothing locally changes

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:21
tomorrows release doesn’t open its GRPC port, or anything else

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:21
thats all I am getting at: its not guaranteed to be repeatable

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:22
in that case I value staying up-to-date over determinism, i’d rather be told “SDK doesn’t work with latest peer” and go investigate who’s broken, rather than “everything’s still good” when it’s not

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:23
there are other ways to stay up to date that don’t introduce reliability concerns though

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:23
what is the friction point we are trying to address?

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:24
so first of all, trying to get rid of vagrant so the changeset that you are working on would help with that (big thanks!)

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:25
even after that, i’d still have to download fabric and build it (thought it’ll be better now that it’s done in macOS)

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:26
and we would set up SDK’s CI job to pull down the latest fabric and build the images

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:26
so, if we assume for a second that bandwidth/compute is unlimited and you could pull any version of fabric.git and get the corresponding docker images instantaneously, would that satisfy your itch?

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:26
yes

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:27
ok…obviously “instant” is impossible, but I think we can get this pretty low friction, especially after its been done once before

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:27
plus i don’t have to explain to newcomers to the SDK project how they set up the target network

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:27
“just use this docker-compose”, that’s it

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:28
right…to be clear: i have no problem with that model for releases

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:28
its the -snapshot/latest stuff that gives me heartburn

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:28
“newcomers” as early adopters or contributors

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:28
sure

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:28
users or contributors, doesnt matter

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:29
want it to be as smooth and painless as possible

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:29
right

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:29
ok, well let me finish up this POC and we can go from there

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:29
it might be that its trivial to get what you want based on it

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:30
ok, i think i advocated for my case, please give it some thought. in the meanwhile i can’t wait to be able to build the images natively on Mac

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:30
ok will do

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:30
thanks Greg

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:30
one note: right now I am leaning towards only supporting docker-for-mac (rather than the older docker-machine/boot2docker)

jzhang
2016-11-03 19:31
works for me, it’s infinitely more convenient than docker-machine anyway :wink:

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:31
there are limitations on the older stuff

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:31
i agree

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:31
i have a 2009 macpro desktop that can only run docker-machine :disappointed:

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:31
but my macbook-pro is new enough to run docker-for-mac and its quite awesome

jyellick
2016-11-03 19:44
@ghaskins I'm looking at organizing our proto files into directories per some discussion with @muralisr and others. The plan is to have a `protos/common` for things which the orderer and the peer need to understand (like the block format) and then a `protos/orderer` for the orderer service definitions. Apparently, if you want to import proto files across directories in a sane way, you need to specify the proto root as a base directory, and then reference them by 'canonical name'. https://github.com/google/protobuf/issues/723 <- this has more information if you are curious I'm looking at modifying the `devenv/compile_protos.sh`, which today compiles all protos only in the context of their current directory. I was looking to modify this, and was wondering if you had an opinion as to a clean way to do so? The obvious way is to exclude the `fabric/protos` dir and add a separate compilation step for it, but that seems a little messy to me. Do you have a better idea?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:45
i pretty much have to wrap my head around it each time I need to work with protoc

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:46
the only comment I have atm is that @yacovm and I worked on a patch that dynamically compiled protos (rather than committed .pb.go files) which cleaned some of this up

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:46
we ultimately abandoned the patch because not having the .pb.go files commited breaks some workflows

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:47
however, there might be a few nuggets of improvement buried in that patch you could borrow

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:47
ill see if I can find it

jyellick
2016-11-03 19:47
Thanks!

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:49
hmm, maybe it wasnt @yacovm

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:49
or maybe it wasnt abandoned yet, let me look in open patches

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:53
hmm, having trouble finding it

jyellick
2016-11-03 19:55
I always prefer to steal, but no need to waste your time looking for it. I can hack something up pretty quickly, was just hoping there was some silver bullet I was unaware of

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:56
found it

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:56
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/789/

ghaskins
2016-11-03 19:57
not sure its entirely helpful…i just remember wrestling with protoc :wink:

jyellick
2016-11-03 19:58
Thanks! I'll take a look

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:33
that *was* me

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:44
@jyellick what's wrong with the compile protos script? why would you have it exclude something?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:44
yeah, sorry, i was struggling to find the patch when searching by your name, thats why I questioned my memory

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:45
it turns out, it was because that was the one I had re-issued so it showed up under my LFID

jyellick
2016-11-03 20:45
@yacovm Essentially, the proto compilation today assumes every proto's root is the directory it resides in. If you want to have proto imports work across directories, this doesn't work

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:47
what do you mean across dirs? you can only "go up a level" and then go down levels but you can't for instance- go up 2 levels, etc?

jyellick
2016-11-03 20:48
So, for my particular application, I want to have two dirs (eventually more). `protos/common` which contains the block definition and some other stuff, and `protos/orderer` which contains the atomicbroadcast service definitions etc.

jyellick
2016-11-03 20:49
The `protos/orderer/ab.proto` file needs to reference the block structure, so, I could say something like `import common.proto`, but of course, `common.proto` is not in the same directory, so this resolution fails

jyellick
2016-11-03 20:49
Proto also doesn't support relative path resolution, so `../common/common.proto` is out

jyellick
2016-11-03 20:50
So my first stab, was to basically pass the list of the directories which contain protos in as directories to be included for searching. This works, to an extent, in so far as the protos compile. However, the resulting go code does not.

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:50
oh, right! so the script assumes everything is in each local dir

jyellick
2016-11-03 20:50
Right

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:51
I remember now... I was editing that script and made it into a makefile with @ghaskins 's crazy (in a good way) Makefile DSL tips

jyellick
2016-11-03 20:51
So, apparently the 'right' way to do this, is to run the protoc command from a common parent directory, to use for the canonical root in naming, so I am working on doing this cleanly

jyellick
2016-11-03 20:52
And @ghaskins remembered that there had been some work done around cleaning up the proto generation (yours) and thought it might be helpful

jyellick
2016-11-03 20:52
I think it actually turns out that there's not a ton of overlap, especially if the decision to move it into make got veto-ed

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:52
thing is- I had a commit that removed the pb.go files and made them autogenerate

jyellick
2016-11-03 20:52
Yep

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:53
this is the same commit we are referring to

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:53
it passed CI and all

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:53
was merged and then broke some people's builds

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:53
no one knows why

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:53
i actually like the idea

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:53
i know why

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:53
I was on a business trip to greece, couldn't take care of it at that time :disappointed:

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:53
its because, well, to put it bluntly, golang is a little limited sometimes, heh

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:54
there is also a small... security flaw in our current aproach

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:54
I assume if someone changes a .proto file and uploads pb.go files, no one reviews the pb.go files, right?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:54
yes, this is why I like your approach, if we could make it work with the other issues

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:54
you can easy put there some backdoor or something

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:55
we could mitigate this by having CI check the pb.go files as part of the linter run if this were a concern though

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:55
yep, that's a great idea.

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:55
make it generate and do diff

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:55
right

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:55
that'll also solve problems such as someone having an old protoc

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:55
i think thats about as good as we can get with the current limitations

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:56
(the issue is that things that have go deps dont understand what protoc is

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:57
so, for instance, if you do “import http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/chaincode/shim” in a chaincode app, it has no idea what a .proto is

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:57
but the missing .pb.go will mean it doesnt compile

jyellick
2016-11-03 20:58
+1 on generating the protos in the CI build and making sure there is no diff

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:58
so it works when you have something like a makefile based build, but not so much elsewhere

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:58
I don't understand the chaincode example

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:58
ok, ignore chaincode…say you have two golang projects

yacovm
2016-11-03 20:59
why would you want to import pb.go files when you write chaincode

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:59
one is a library that uses protobufs

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:59
another is an app that imports the library

ghaskins
2016-11-03 20:59
when you write the app, the golang toolchain manages all the deps stuff for you

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:00
so the app just says “import foo” and golang goes and downloads foo.git and compiles it into your app

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:00
you never get to interject and say “wait! I need to compile .proto -> .pb.go first"

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:00
it just does it all in one fell swoop

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:00
oh I see what you mean now

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:00
so you won't get *.pb.go

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:00
so, therefore, the library has to have the .pb.go checked in

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:00
if they're auto-generated

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:01
right

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:01
and we were hitting this on the shim

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:01
but why does this fit to our use case?

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:01
the shim is a part of the fabric

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:01
basically things like the SDK and the shim were interacting in a manner similar to how I described

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:01
no, the shim is a library that gets embedded into chaincode

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:01
its _related_ to fabric, sure

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:01
but its not part of the peer proper

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:02
its part of the chaincode proper

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:02
yeah it runs "outside"

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:02
oh I see

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:02
you need the pb.go files from the fabric to compile the shim

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:02
bingo

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:02
thats what broke

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:02
that's what was broken in my changeset that time?

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:02
yep

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:03
oh cool. Thanks for the explanation

ghaskins
2016-11-03 21:03
not your fault…i didnt pick up on it either until we got more testing on it

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:04
basically if that was C or java

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:04
you could have compiled the shim into a .o file or something

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:04
and added that to the chaincode

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:06
maybe there is something like that in go? an object file?

yacovm
2016-11-03 21:16
http://stackoverflow.com/a/30488222 ? maybe we can create a shared object for the shim?

yacovm
2016-11-03 23:37
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2237/

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:26

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:26

jzhang
2016-11-04 17:26

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:27
the issue is that OSX ships with bsdtar but almost everything else in the flow is using/expecting gnutar and there is an incongruence in the format

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:27
i fixed it on my system by installing gnutar with homebrew

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:27
@ghaskins uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F2Z7JJ33R/-.txt and commented: ymmv

jzhang
2016-11-04 17:28
ah ok, i suspected it’s something like that but couldn’t nail down what the error means exactly

jzhang
2016-11-04 17:28
cool

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:28
that will eclipse “tar” with the one from the gnutar package

jzhang
2016-11-04 17:28
will give this a try

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:28
do note, if you already have it installed, it might not install the alias

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:28
you might have to do a reinstall or uninstall/install cycle

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:28
@cbf ran into that particular snafu

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:29
not sure what the best long term solution is

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:29
worst case, we “FAQ” that fix

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:29
but would be nice to be a little more slick

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:30
as an aside, note that the “images” target will likely go away in this patch series

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:30
mainline has things like “peer” and “peer-image”, but that doesnt make sense in the new build

ghaskins
2016-11-04 17:31
so I collapsed them into just the undecorated names e.g. “make peer” will spit out the peer docker image

jzhang
2016-11-04 17:31

@ghaskins @jzhang I think @garisingh has a patch for fixing OSX build https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2255/

cbf
2016-11-04 19:07
I actually had gnutar installed but had to create symlink for /usr/local/bin/tar

jyellick
2016-11-04 19:36
@ghaskins I tagged you in the changeset, but https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2257/2/devenv/compile_protos.sh is what I came up with for allowing the proto compilation to support dependent directories. Essentially, if there is a `.protoroot` file in one of the directories in a proto's path, then this is used as the root for the proto compilation, otherwise the root is inferred to be the directory which contains the proto.

cbf
2016-11-04 19:50
@jyellick why in /devenv and not /scripts?

jyellick
2016-11-04 19:53
@cbf That's just where I found it, seems like it probably belongs in `scripts`

jyellick
2016-11-04 20:05
Moved to scripts and added some additional comments https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2257/3/scripts/compile_protos.sh

ghaskins
2016-11-04 20:08
its probably a vestige from when we only had devenv and not scripts dir

ghaskins
2016-11-04 20:08
I agree scripts is more appropriate

cbf
2016-11-04 20:14
+1 cool thanks;-)

jyellick
2016-11-09 15:41
@ghaskins It looks like the move to localize the go tools into the fabric dir creates files such as `gotools/build/gopath/src/github.com/golang/protobuf/protoc-gen-go/testdata/extension_base.proto` so when I run a `make protos` I am getting a compile error. Am I good to submit a patch which excludes this path?

ghaskins
2016-11-09 15:50

ghaskins

ghaskins

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-11-09 16:21

ghaskins
2016-11-09 16:22

ghaskins
2016-11-09 16:22
but the basic concept is independent

yacovm

yes

yacovm
2016-11-09 16:32
and then *you* (I mean literally you) have control over the image

yacovm
2016-11-09 16:32
so you control the version of the protobuff compiler, etc

ghaskins
2016-11-09 16:32
heh, not really, but ok

ghaskins
2016-11-09 16:33
right now, protoc comes from baseimage (which is more "me" than normal, yes), and protoc-gen-go comes from fabric.git/vendor (which has little to do with me in general)

ghaskins
2016-11-09 16:33
but either way, the environment would be controlled by commits in git, which is a good thing

ghaskins
2016-11-09 16:34
of course, anyone can submit CRs to baseimage as well

ghaskins
2016-11-09 16:34
just not many do

grapebaba
2016-11-17 05:18
guys, now do I still use 'make checks' for validation?

grapebaba
2016-11-17 05:40
@grapebaba uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/grapebaba/F33L9J63V/-.py

grapebaba
2016-11-17 05:40
always get a behave test error

rickr
2016-11-17 12:10
Seems the pin is invalid for the weekly call

ghaskins
2016-11-17 13:23
@grapebaba "make checks" is still the general target to select all validations...but note that the behave check has frequently returned unreliable results and is thus disabled in V+1 voting in jenkins. Therefore, if all the other checks pass and it doesn't look like behave is failing in a way related to your change, you are probably good to go

ghaskins
2016-11-17 13:23
since its not officially checked in the pipeline right now, you have to use judgement

ghaskins
2016-11-17 13:24
if unsure, you can re-run just behave with "make behave"

grapebaba
2016-11-17 13:49
@ghaskins: got it.

rickr
2016-11-17 18:13
I just noticed on the V 1.0 spec that peers have a name. Is this something we expect the end user to set ? If not, how is it derived? Also it appears Orderer does not have name. Seems to be an imbalance.

pmullaney
2016-11-18 01:43
seeing this deploying chaincode from peer command: "vp1_1 | 01:41:42.880 [peer] beforePeers -> DEBU 8c3 Received PeersMessage with Peers: peers:<ID:<name:"vp1" > address:"172.17.0.4:7051" type:VALIDATOR > vp0_1 | 01:41:43.117 [dockercontroller] deployImage -> ERRO b15 Error building images: Tag x86_64-0.7.0-snapshot-8c2064e not found in repository http://docker.io/hyperledger/fabric-ccenv vp0_1 | 01:41:43.117 [dockercontroller] deployImage -> ERRO b16 Image Output: "

pmullaney
2016-11-18 01:45
