ghaskins
2016-11-18 01:58
@pmullaney I think I know

ghaskins
2016-11-18 01:58
try a "make clean" first, and then rebuild your setup

ghaskins
2016-11-18 01:58
I need to address this problem

ghaskins
2016-11-18 01:59
it has to do with the fact that the makefile is satisfied by ./build/images/ccenv/.dummy but the git sha can change if you commit more stuff

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:00
fyi: got some errors on "make clean"

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:00
so, make thinks the docker image is built, but the docker image that was built was a different sha and thus unreacable

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:00
Error response from daemon: No such image: e84da3e0f63c:latest Makefile:239: recipe for target 'orderer-image-clean' failed make: [orderer-image-clean] Error 123 (ignored)

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:00
thats fine (thats why its "ignored"

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:00
its an optimistic delete, cant tell if theres anything there to delete until it tries

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:01
wish there was a better way to output that though

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:01
its the same as doing "rm *", there might not be any files

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:02
right

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:02
I suppose I could re-work it so it gathers the list of targets first or something

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:02
would be less confusing to users if that output wasnt there

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:02
is it in the makefile?

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:02
yeah, see the "clean" target

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:03
I thought you could nix the output for things like that - its been awhile :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:03
maybe...i know I tell it to expect/ignore failures

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:03
thats why it doesnt bail, but keeps running

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:03
im sure I could snarf output too

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:04
ok I did a "make clean;make peer;make images" and now:

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:05
@pmullaney uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/pmullaney/F34AJ9QUV/-.txt

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:05
ive seen that on rare occasion, but I am not sure what causes it

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:06
nor how I got past it

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:06
I think I saw this earlier today too

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:06
hmm, i do remember it was something weird though

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:06
I ended up bailing and trying the latest fabric :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:07
oh i remember!

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:07
its a docker compose thing

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:07
make sure you "docker-compose down" that thing

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:07
oh ok

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:08
if you run "docker-compose ps" (IIRC) the containers dont "go away" after the up stops

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:08
its like "docker run" without the "--rm" option

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:08
the containers persist after they stop running

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:09
and, depending on whatever malarky you may be up to (like building new ccenv:snapshots) it gives that error sometimes

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:09
some kind of bad juju between the container that is still there and the fact that you deleted it with the "make clean", I would guess

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:09
totally stupid..i wish compose had a --rm option for up

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:10
as a matter of fact, I have started launching my tests like "docker-compose up && docker-compose down" for this reason

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:10
not bullet proof, but largely mitigates the phenomenon

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:11
docker-compose ps returned nothing

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:11
try "-a"

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:11
or maybe "docker-compose status"

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:12
i dont recall exactly, but the problem is the containers are still there

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:12
ok, docker ps shows them

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:12
now try "docker-compose down" and I think they will go away

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:12
im pretty sure there is a docker-compose subcommand that will show them though

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:13
just not remembering which one

yaoguo
2016-11-18 02:14
@ghaskins thanks for help. the error was triggered by legacy files. after clean these files 'make protos' run normally. But it will change fileDescriptor0 of every *.pb.go.

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:14
I manually removed them with docker vs docker-compose

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:15
@yaoguo this might be normal, or it might be a discrepancy with the environment you are trying to run the "make protos" in vs what the last person did

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:15
fwiw, I am working on a fix that will normalize this so its the same environment for all

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:15
@ghaskins : thanks looking good

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:15
but today, it is assuming some coherence in the execution environment

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:16
@yaoguo can I ask if you are running within vagrant?

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:16
in theory, if everyone runs in the same vagrant, that should have coherence

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:16
but, not everyone runs vagrant, and even those who do, the revlevel is not guarnateed

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:16
and the chaincode deploys - thanks again

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:16
@pmullaney awesome

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:17
@pmullaney could you do me a favor and file a jira related to the "cant find snapshot-xxxxx" error

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:17
i know what that is, and know how to improve it

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:17
just need to remember to actually fix it :wink:

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:17
sure np

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:18
feel free to assign to me

yaoguo
2016-11-18 02:18
@ghaskins no, on my computer. it depends on something in os?

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:19
yes... it depends to a degree on the version of protoc you are running (we use v3.1.0 currently) and _very_ much depends on the version of protoc-gen-go you have

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:19
if you use the devenv, this is somewhat controlled for you, but if you build your own environment, that could be anything

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:19
and any variance may result in .pb.go churn

yaoguo
2016-11-18 02:22
my protoc is v3.1.0. and protoc-gen-go is cloned and built from https://github.com/golang/tools. maybe i should check the version of protoc-gen-go.

pmullaney
2016-11-18 02:23
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1145

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:27
@yaoguo yeah, that is most likely the problem

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:27
what you should do is run "make gotools"

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:27
that will build, amoung other things, protoc-gen-go from fabric.git/vendor

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:27
then you can be sure you are running the same one that was bundled with the code

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:30
@yaoguo also note, that I think in master, "make gotools" will output the binary to $GOPATH/bin

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:30
so, you will need to ensure that is in your $PATH and also that its not eclipsed by the other install you have

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:30
it might go to ./build/bin, alternatively

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:31
i cant recall as its changed over time

ghaskins
2016-11-18 02:31
short answer, whereever it goes, make sure you are picking it up :wink:

yaoguo
2016-11-18 02:38
@ghaskins thanks. I'll try to clean gotools/build dir and run "make gotools" again.

jzhang
2016-11-22 00:36
@ghaskins @jonathanlevi it looks like the new peer image doesn’t have the fabric source tree any longer, is that right? I remember Greg’s comment on a @aso changeset that mentioned something similar to this

jzhang
2016-11-22 00:37
is the peer process then looking somewhere else for the “peer-config.json” file to load the ecert?

ghaskins
2016-11-22 00:38
@jzhang thats correct, the latest builds do not include the source

ghaskins
2016-11-22 00:39
the configuration is now under /etc/hyperledger/fabric

jzhang
2016-11-22 00:39
ok thanks for confirming that and the pointer on the new location

ghaskins
2016-11-22 00:39
for instance, /etc/hyperledger/fabric/msp/peer-config.json

jzhang
2016-11-22 00:39
ah ok i remember seeing this on the orderer dockerfile

jzhang
2016-11-22 00:39
ok got it

ghaskins
2016-11-22 00:39
FWIW, we also set an environment variable

jzhang
2016-11-22 00:39
this makes better sense btw

ghaskins
2016-11-22 00:39
PEER_CFG_PATH and ORDERER_CFG_PATH respectively

jzhang
2016-11-22 00:40
nice

ghaskins
2016-11-22 00:40
only on master, fyi

ghaskins
2016-11-22 00:40
v0.6 still does it the old way, with full source

jzhang
2016-11-22 00:40
yes i only roll with master :wink:

ghaskins
2016-11-22 00:40
same

ghaskins
2016-11-22 00:42
in case you are ever curious, the docker images are formed from Dockerfiles stored under ./images

ghaskins
2016-11-22 00:42
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/tree/master/images

ghaskins
2016-11-22 00:42
for instance: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/images/peer/Dockerfile.in

jzhang
2016-11-22 00:59
yes saw that earlier when debugging an orderer problem

bretharrison
2016-11-22 14:30
has joined #fabric-dev-env

yacovm
2016-11-27 15:13
I encounter a weird behavior in the output of the unit tests: The chaincode test passes but it outputs to the jenkins console, but tests that pass shouldn't output to the console, only if they fail. https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-verify-x86_64/3326/console Can anyone explain this?

muralisr
2016-11-27 15:18
@yacovm assuming you are referring to the logs from before the start of the actual unit test - that’s a “pre unit-test” check using docker compose that @ghaskins added I believe…. I gathered that its work in progress (given orderer is not started in that test) and does not affect CI in anyway.

yacovm
2016-11-27 15:19
yeah I think that's the case, thanks

ghaskins
2016-11-27 15:28
Yeah we switched to using compose and the side effect is the peer log is now visible

ghaskins
2016-11-27 15:28
It used to get buried

yacovm
2016-11-27 15:30
why use compose? because you need 2 node "types"?

yacovm
2016-11-27 15:30
(orderer/peer)

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:04
No, we always needed a peer historically, but we launched it manually with docker-run

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:05
As such, we were driving compose-isms manually in a script, such as during cleanup

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:05
As the system grew more complex, we needed other compose-isms like IP linking

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:06
So, we had a choice: we could continue to add manual compose-isms or just switch to compose

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:06
I chose the latter

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:07
It seemed to be the logical choice. Is there a reason this should be reconsidered?

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:08
That said, we may need to, in fact, support launching both peer and orderer going forward, which only further makes the argument that it should be a composition

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:09
Today the UT interaction with the peer is minimal so I think we can get away with a partial environment

yacovm
2016-11-27 16:10
What I meant to ask is

yacovm
2016-11-27 16:10
previously you have a peer

yacovm
2016-11-27 16:10
*had

yacovm
2016-11-27 16:10
and you ran in docker

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:10
Yep

yacovm
2016-11-27 16:10
why are you running now in compose? do you have *another* component which needs to run?

yacovm
2016-11-27 16:11
ip linking implies there are 2 or more participants

yacovm
2016-11-27 16:11
oh, the orderer

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:11
See above: primary drivers are a) coupled lifecycle (peer stops when UT stops) and b) IP linking (UTs can discover peer)

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:12
Both are natural constructs of a composition

yacovm
2016-11-27 16:12
that's all I wanted to ask- whether everything is for the orderer, although I don't understand why it runs in a separate process? Why not embed an orderer in the relevant unit test?

yacovm
2016-11-27 16:13
but forget it I don't want to disturb you on Sunday :wink:

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:24
It had nothing to do with the orderer (at least at the time)

ghaskins
2016-11-27 16:25
Though it may prove useful for integrating the orderer going forward

ghaskins
2016-11-27 18:01
Not sure this is clear, but the unit tests run in a docker context now too. That is the "2 participants" you were wondering about

yacovm
2016-11-27 18:38
thanks, that was indeed missing. Now I can recompile all the sentences in my head :wink:

hsukhwa
2016-11-28 00:41
has joined #fabric-dev-env

anton
2016-11-29 15:07
has joined #fabric-dev-env

vibhu
2016-11-29 17:16
has joined #fabric-dev-env

vibhu
2016-11-29 17:16
hey guys - i am using v0.6 for fabric and running the vagrant vm. I have built the peer but when i try make membersrvc, i get an error as below: vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.2.1-af0cd3e:~$ make membersrvc make: *** No rule to make target 'membersrvc'. Stop. Please hel

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:22
@vibhu two comments

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:23
1) devenv v0.2.1 is associated with mainline: I would suggest you exit, vagrant destroy, vagrant up within v0.6 branch to ensure maximum compatiblity

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:23
2) it looks like you are in the home dir

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:23
try "cd $GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric" before the make, and I suspect you will have better luck

vibhu
2016-11-29 17:24
@ghaskins thanks for the tips - i tried comment #2 and got he following: vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.2.1-af0cd3e:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric$ make membersrvc make: *** No rule to make target 'membersrvc'. Stop.

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:25
df ?

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:25
also: ls ?

vibhu
2016-11-29 17:26

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:42
yeah, I think I know what that issue is

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:43
whats happening is that the code is assuming you are working from a git tree...it should be fixed, but as a work around you can fake it

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:43
in the place that you unpacked the tarball: git init && git add . && git commit -a

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:44
then, cd devenv && vagrant destroy && vagrant up

vibhu
2016-11-29 17:44

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:44
whereever you downloaded it

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:44
er, unpacked it, i should say

ghaskins
2016-11-29 17:45
IIUC, this is /src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric-0.6 for you, so run the git commands from that top-level dir

2016-11-30 11:49

lesterpig
2016-12-03 17:15
has joined #fabric-dev-env

ghaskins
2016-12-03 18:08
@adc: the most common reason I see for that is that you dont have virtualbox properly installed

ghaskins
2016-12-03 18:08
so, vagrant can't find a match for whatever providers you have available

ghaskins
2016-12-03 18:09
the other reason is network access

ghaskins
2016-12-03 18:09
sometimes related to HTTP_PROXY

ghaskins
2016-12-03 18:09
could either of those apply?

ghaskins
2016-12-03 18:09
as an aside, you dont really need vagrant any more on master

ghaskins
2016-12-03 18:09
(except to run behave, I still havent ported that

then start the peer

jdockter
2016-12-07 20:37
Trying to follow the v1 skeletal environment, which was working before, and now I'm getting the following error when trying to make peer in vagrant

jdockter
2016-12-07 20:37
Step 3 : ADD payload/goshim.tar.bz2 $GOPATH/src/ Error processing tar file(exit status 1): link /github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/chaincode/shim/java/build/classes/main/org/hyperledger/java/shim/ChaincodeBase.class /github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/chaincode/shim/java/build/classes/main/org/hyperledger/java/shim/ChaincodeBase.class: no such file or directory Makefile:195: recipe for target 'build/image/ccenv/.dummy-x86_64-0.7.0-snapshot-5c9fcc3' failed make: *** [build/image/ccenv/.dummy-x86_64-0.7.0-snapshot-5c9fcc3] Error 1

ghaskins
2016-12-07 23:01
@jdockter usually I see that when there is a file that hasnt been added/removed from git

ghaskins
2016-12-07 23:02
the issue is that the makefile uses "git ls-files" to determine which files to evaluate, and if you happen to be adding/removing files to the tree, depending on how you do it, you can make git ls-files a liar :wink:

ghaskins
2016-12-07 23:03
so, first question is; are you in the middle of knowingly adding/removing files?

jdockter
2016-12-07 23:50
@ghaskins the only thing I did was copy a docker-compose file into the fabric root directory...I removed just to be safe, did a git pull to make sure I had the latest copy of master.....did a vagrant destroy then tried vagrant up again...same error while running make peer... @klorenz was getting the same error, so don't think it's just me

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:16
like I said before, I am open to any devops platform that improves the $distro neutrality, with a proclivity to puppet being that I know it best

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:17
or are you talking about something else?

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 14:17
I'll pick up puppet ansible *can* do the same things, but it's really focused on multi-server provisioning.

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:18
ok...if you are new to puppet, note that there are two ways to use it

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:18
the more obvious way is the distributed client/server model, where the server dishes out manifests

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:18
but there is also the ability to run completely standalone

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:18
where you can just process a manifest file locally

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:19
i am thinking that is the model we would want (the local option, no server)

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 14:19
agreed. I guess we could do some fancy setup where we have one control flow across all the docker container steps

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 14:19
aka ssh into each docker container and perform the steps

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 14:19
while that would make things easier to follow, I don't think it would be worth it.

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:20
give it some thought, I am open minded

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:20
clear/simple/reliable is the goal, though

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 14:21
I'd want to use ansible at that point. Quick look says puppet is a bit harder to learn and debug, of course ansible just loves to make little functionality changes between versions, which is annoying

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 14:21
like with_fileglob dropped support for multiple wild cards this minor revison, but might get it back the next.

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:21
fortunately, the vast majority of "distro install" stuff happens in the baseimage

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:21
and that is just one image

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:22
anyway, I am OTP so I should get back to it

ghaskins
2016-12-09 14:22
we can chat more later

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 14:22
ack

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:32
@cbf: the goal, as I understand it, is to try to normalize out the $distro

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:32
so, to take something like this: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-baseimage/blob/master/scripts/common/setup.sh

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:32
and clean up / doc the process in general.

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:33
and rather than it being bash directives specific to ubuntu/debian, it could be higher order directives like "install protobuf"

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:33
but leveraging the devops frameworks so we are not reinventing the wheel

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:33
I only made really small mods to get it working on centos, mostly find replace apt with yum, so you've done a good job with this bash and we might keep some of it but use ansilbe to clean up the messy parts.

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:34
e.g. something like puppet or ansible already understand the packaging differences between RPM and DEB, Ubuntu, vs Suse, etc

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:34
I thought I would be fine with puppet this morning, but did some research, looks a little painful compared to ansible. I'll go with whatever if you feel strongly though.

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:34
no, please make suggestions, i am open

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:34
rather have it be "good" than "easy"

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:35
I can learn new tricks :wink:

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:35
by easy I am referring to my learning curve, of course

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:35
i hope whatever we come up with is easy for everyone to consume :wink:

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:35
ansible is a lot easier to read and maintain, but it's also faster moving right now, so minor versions break some things, usually not major, think double wild cards on a fileglob going away one minor version and being back the next

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:36
puppet is more stable it looks like but also much harder to just pick up.

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:36
ok...i suggest a POC

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:36
re-write that script above in ansible and present it so we can review

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:36
that's pretty much the plan rightn ow

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:36
(or even just one aspect of it

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:36
now*

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:36
ok, thats perfect

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:36
I was going to do docker components only if that's ok?

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:37
part of the goal of this is that vagrant won't be needed because $distro agnostic

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:37
yeah, vagrant is already largely unnecessary now anyway

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:38
i still need to port behave over to the new build stuff and then we can largely remove vagrant

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:38
but I digress

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:38
the baseimage stuff remains for docker, so that can be the focus for $distro neutral efforts

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:38
things that would be interesting to highlight in a POC:

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:39
install distro packages (of course)

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:39
install from tarball

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:39
install from non-standard repo

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:39
If the story for devops framework X were solid on those three points, I would be very much in favor of dropping the bash-based setup

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:40
nods

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:43
also good to highlight what it looks like to support conditionals

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:43
e.g. if $arch, if $distro, etc

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:43
because im sure exceptions will come up

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:44
for example, the P/Z teams currently insist on overriding the platform JVM with ibmjava

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:45
that's fine, there will probably end up being a few text files with lists of dependencies for $distro where adding distro is the same as adding the dependency list and then passing that distro as an argument.

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:45
the problem with platform agnostic package managers is that they tend to get confused with obscure packages

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:45
apache, fine, libobscure2-devel

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:45
nope

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:46
i have no problem with finer grained structure

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:46
e.g. ubuntu.ansible, redhat.ansible, etc

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:47
but I loath DRY violations, so ideally can be expressed in terms of the delta :wink:

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:48
I expect the most we change is a task that is "go isntall x distro dependencies"

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:49
so if it were something like packages/protoc/common.ansible, packages/jre/ubuntu.ansible, packages/jre/centos.ansible etc that is fine

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:49
then a few things like sudo -i in some spots and adding to path in others that aren't *required* on any distro but one but are just there for all of them.

ghaskins
2016-12-09 18:49
right, ok

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:52
hmm distro + arch conditionals, that will be interesting to see if I can avoid the ubuntu + power pc situation by seperating platform issues and distro issues.

jkilpatr
2016-12-09 18:52
otherwise the number of combinations is in no one's favor.

walker
2016-12-09 19:53
has joined #fabric-dev-env

jonathanlevi

thojest
2016-12-12 17:06

ghaskins
2016-12-12 17:09
@harrijk @srirama_sharma https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3229/

ghaskins
2016-12-12 17:10
once this is merged, P/Z jobs can at least be enabled as an advisory vote, as discussed

thojest
2016-12-12 17:13
is it possible that someone has to approve my key i uploaded to gerrit?

thojest
2016-12-12 17:14
i try to clone with 'git clone '

harrijk
2016-12-12 17:40
@ghaskins so the jobs will not actually run for p and z, but will at least be integrated into the verify process in terms of jenkins setup, etc. just like behave, correct?

harrijk
2016-12-12 17:42
until around xmas time when the 0.2.2 "cut" (pulling in all CRs, etc) is made and then the jobs will run, if i understand correctly.

ghaskins
2016-12-12 17:43
to be clear, someone (probably not me) would have to write the JJB for it, but the suggestion is that P/Z -verify type jobs can be added after CR 3229 is merged, but that their vote should be advisory (like behave)

ghaskins
2016-12-12 17:43
this is because some CRs will not be rebased on CR 3229 and we wouldnt want to block their V+1

ghaskins
2016-12-12 17:44
so, the proposal is jobs will run but their vote wont count

ghaskins
2016-12-12 17:44
until such time that we draw the line

harrijk
2016-12-12 18:23
ok. and if there are failures on p or z, and for now, we'll take manual action to get with the developer to correct the issue. i assume that this will still not prevent the merge from happening, but it's the next best thing.

harrijk
2016-12-12 18:31
@ghaskins ^ (sorry forgot to prefix your id)

ghaskins
2016-12-12 18:32
Correct

harrijk
2016-12-12 18:44
tnx!

pd93
2016-12-13 13:48
@thojest Vagrant isn't really needed. Especially if you're not developing fabric itself. If you're developing chaincode or an application, you're better off just using docker.

thojest
2016-12-13 13:49
@pd93 wow thanks, to be honest there seems to be a bug is this possible? running 'make peer' on the vagrant ssh machine always shuts down the vm

thojest
2016-12-13 13:50
so in fact it is docker pulling the fabric images which shuts down the vm just before the process is finished

thojest
2016-12-13 13:50
i had a similar problem using docker in windows, there it was the oracle virtualbox version which has to be 5.1 but in ubuntu changing the vb version doesnt help either

thojest
2016-12-13 13:52
but since i want to develop chaincode im fine with that

pd93
2016-12-13 13:55
@thojest If working with Ubuntu directly, I'd just install docker, pull the images you need and use docker-compose to run them in whatever configuration you need. If you really need to, then you can clone fabric (which you need for chaincode dev anyway), adjust the configuration and make your own images

pd93

NOOPS, when I run invoke, one of the peer execute the chaincode invoke twice, resulting the state for ex. b=220 for that peer, but the other three has b=210. query seem run on random peer, so executing it multiple times return inconsistent result (b=220) when you hit that peer. 4 peers seems to generate this behaviours 100%, but you can also reproduce it with 2 peers, only you have to run invoke multiple times. sk
2016-12-14 07:11
@brendanb look like you don't have rocksdb installed on your linux. It required to compile peer/membersrvc. Look at setup.sh on devenv folder (if you use vagrant the provision build it automatically)

brendanb
2016-12-14 07:15
@sk apparently we HF is moving away from vagrant. I'm currently just trying this is base ubuntu. So far I've tried installing gorocksdb with `go get -v -tags=embed http://github.com/tecbot/gorocksdb` as per the gorocksdb docs, unfortunately this gives a compile error `../../tecbot/gorocksdb/options.go:436: cannot use C.double(value) (type C.double) as type C.int in argument to _Cfunc_rocksdb_options_set_max_bytes_for_level_multiplier` . I see that on master branch rocksdb has been removed as a dependency, so it's unfortunate that I can't get this to work on master

sk
2016-12-14 07:21
@brendanb gorocksdb is wrapper for rocksdb, so technically you still need rocksdb itself if you use that. I haven't yet playing with master branch, but as far as I know on v0.6 I need to use v4.1 of rocksdb as the latest rocksdb not working. I did use vagrant devenv for compiling peer binary only and move it to plain linux, and I have to install rocksdb separately.

brendanb
2016-12-14 07:22
@sk thanks, will do that next

sk
2016-12-14 07:24
@brendand sudo apt-get install build-essential git clone -bv4.1 https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb cd rocksdb make shared_lib sudo make install-shared cd .. rm -rf rocksdb # and you need this to run peer sudo mkdir -p /var/hyperledger sudo chown -R $USER:$USER /var/hyperledger

brendanb
2016-12-14 07:34
@sk `make install-shared_lib` make: *** No rule to make target 'install-shared_lib'.

sk
2016-12-14 07:35
@brendand sorry typo, try "sudo make install-shared"

sk
2016-12-14 07:36
by the way rocksdb v4.1 is for fabric v0.6, I'm not sure the req. for master.

brendanb
2016-12-14 07:38

2016-12-14 13:27

2016-12-14 13:27

thojest
2016-12-14 13:34
so behave seems to be a python programm for test ?

brendanb
2016-12-14 13:35
I don't know what default make does, I only did make peer

thojest
2016-12-14 13:36
about the problem with GOPATH. I had to run `sudo make GOPATH= yourgopath`

thojest
2016-12-14 14:15
so can someone tell me what is the difference between `sudo make` and `sudo make peer`

thojest
2016-12-14 15:04
so running `sudo make behave` how many days does this take ^^

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:07
@thojest: "make" is implicitly "make all" which if you look at the rule for "all" in the makefile, builds everything and runs all tests

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:07
whereas "make peer" will only build the native peer binary and anything that it depends on

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:08
it will not run any tests, and it will not build anything not strictly related to the peer

thojest
2016-12-14 16:11
@ghaskins thx a lot so i understood that right. is it possible that after make all i have to set my PATH because the peer command does not work

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:11
i assume you are not in the vagrant environment?

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:11
if you are in vagrant, it should already have build/bin in the $PATH

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:11
if not, you'd have to manage this yourself

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:13
(fyi, things are still really structured around building/running from within vagrant...we will be improving the installability and generality of the development requirements moving forward, but we are not quite there yet

thojest
2016-12-14 16:13
@ghaskins yes im on ubuntu bare metal and i included it in the PATH now. now when running `peer node start` i get CORE_PBFT unsupported config type

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:14
are you in mainline or v0.6?

thojest
2016-12-14 16:14
v0.6

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:14
ok, v0.6 is slightly more complicated because there are multiple configuration files

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:15
this was condensed in master to one file, which makes things slightly easier

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:15
but the problem is that the peer is looking for the configuration in ... (standby)

thojest
2016-12-14 16:16
so basically would it be better to `rm -rf *` and git clone the master branch ?

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:16
well, it depends on what you want

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:16
v0.6 is stable, master is newer, more advanced, and still in development

thojest
2016-12-14 16:17
so my intention is to learn a bit about chaincode and maybe write a very simple smart contract

thojest
2016-12-14 16:17
@ghashkins thx a lot btw

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:18
@ghaskins uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3FDEPZML/-.c and commented: This is an excerpt from a script I have that is setting up a v0.6 peer

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:18
its not quite turnkey to solve the problem you are mentioning, but its related

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:19
in a nutshell, those are the files needed to spin up a v0.6 membersrvc/peer combo, and you will see that error if the peer cannot resolve them

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:19
usually, if you are running from a system with src installed, the easiest thing to do is ensure you run the peer with your $GOPATH set appropriately

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:19
this will auto-resolve to the configuration in the tree

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:20
otherwise, it ends up installing these in places like /etc/hyperledger/fabric

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:20
in this case, the error you are seeing is basically because its not finding consensus/pbft/config.yaml, which would have defined CORE_PBFT

thojest
2016-12-14 16:21
thx a lot

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:21
np

thojest
2016-12-14 16:22
i noticed that for some permission-denied reason i have to `sudo peer node start`

thojest
2016-12-14 16:22
and typing `sudo go env` i see my GOPATH is not set

thojest
2016-12-14 16:22
that might be the problem

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:22
yeah, that is your problem

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:22
if the GOPATH is set, those configuration files would be auto-resolved to the tree

thojest
2016-12-14 16:23
thats wonderful :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:23
you generally only need to muck around with the configuration files for when the binaries are installed without source

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:23
i am not sure why you need to launch the peer with sudo

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:24
its probably a peripheral issue (like the perms on the binary, or the perms on /var/hyperledger

thojest
2016-12-14 16:24
maybe i have to chown something ?

thojest
2016-12-14 16:24

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:24
yes, that is def true

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:25
the ledger is written there

kamo
2016-12-14 16:25
has joined #fabric-dev-env

thojest
2016-12-14 16:27
omg it is working :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:27
cool

thojest
2016-12-14 16:28
make sure to RECURSIVELY chown so: `sudo chown -R $USER:$USER /var/hyperledger` did it

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:28
makes sense

thojest
2016-12-14 16:28
@ghaskins again thanks for your indepth help

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:28
any time

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:29
fwiw, this is greatly simplified in master

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:29
(but, like I said, its still in development)

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:30
in v0.6 we really don't officially support anything except vagrant builds

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:31
in master, we are pretty close to being able to build anywhere, or run from docker binaries in dockerhub

ghaskins
2016-12-14 16:32
(this isnt to say it cant be done, its just a little more manual, as you have found)

ghaskins

ghaskins

kamo
2016-12-14 17:00
Hello, im new here and i may have a stupid question.. How can i use the community docker membersrvc image with my own membersrvc,yaml ? (Regarding v0.6)

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:06
@kamo I should point out first that despite the fact that docker images are published for v0.6, the support for running from anything but a source build is a little weak right now (see https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-678).

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:07
that said, if you wanted to do this

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:07
I think you could effect the change you want by a) installing a new membersrvc.yaml file somewhere (say /etc/hyperledger/fabric) and then setting the WORKDIR to the same

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:07
because the v0.6 membersrvc will look for its config in the CWD

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:08
I _think_

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:08
heh

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:08
im reasonably confident this would work, but not 100%

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:08
(I should say this: I know it would look for its config in $CWD, but I am not sure which will take precedence)

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:09
alternatively, note that you can override any .yaml setting with envvars

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:10
fwiw, this is all much more straight forward in master: we map the configs to /etc/hyperledger/fabric in the container, so you could just override this dir with new config and its straight forward

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:11
v0.6 is still a little hacky, it has the full $GOPATH tree and pulls the config from that

kamo
2016-12-14 17:11
First of all thank you for your immediate answer

kamo
2016-12-14 17:11
overwriting the yaml settings with envvars is how i do it at the moment, but its not that userfriendly

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:12
ok, and I understand. Just wanted to make sure you knew about that option since in most circumstances, that is easier

kamo
2016-12-14 17:12
yes thank you, another question is: is there still a membersrvc.yaml in master?

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:12
long story short, i think you can do this in v0.6 but its going to be a little ugly

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:12
good point, membersrvc is gone in master

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:13
though this general approach is taken with the other containers

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:13
(at least for peer+orderer)

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:13
not sure what fabric-cop container looks like, as I didnt work on that one

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:14
long story short: v0.6 config override is a little ugly, master override is better supported

kamo
2016-12-14 17:14
okay then i will try this approach, one last question: is the orderer taking the tasks of the membersrvc ? or what does the orderer do?

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:15
no, and I am certainly not an expert here: but my understanding is orderer is a teasing out of the peer consensus function, membersrvc is now in its own repo (and renamed to "COP")

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:15
so see fabric-cop.git

kamo
2016-12-14 17:16
okay good, i understood it in the same way

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:16
so, ["peer" -> "peer + orderer", "membersrvc" -> "cop"] if you need a v0.6 -> master dictionary

kamo
2016-12-14 17:16
okay nice!

kamo
2016-12-14 17:17
no i dont need v0.6 the only thing i wanna do at the moment is getting the asset-management-with-roles example to work

ghaskins
2016-12-14 17:17
gotcha

kamo
2016-12-14 17:18

kamo
2016-12-14 17:19

ghaskins

@kamo the doc is still more or less structured for the v0.6 flow currently

muralisr

you also get other design docs for v1.0 there

ghaskins

baohua
2016-12-15 12:14

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:14
yes, that is what this is essentially

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:14
basically all you need is a handful of things: make, git, golang v1.6+, docker

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:14
and you can build fabric baremetal

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:15
at least on linux and OSX

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:15
i am not sure if windows is that easy

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:15
do note, however, that running the full suite (like unit-tests) may only work with docker-for-mac, not the older docker-machine

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:15
(the build will work with either, but the unit tests need the newer docker setup)

baohua

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:24
ok, thats probably a makefile bug of some kind

baohua
2016-12-15 12:24
i may suggest we decouple the image building from comping a native binary like peer/orderer.

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:24
if you can file as much detail as possible in a JIRA, appreciated

baohua
2016-12-15 12:25
don’t think there’s reason to combine them building together :disappointed:

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:25
well, the coupling was created intentionally

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:25
ccenv must exist for peer to run, but I suppose we could provide the option

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:26
to your point, its not actually needed to build peer, but it is needed to run peer so I wanted to ensure "peer xxx" was ready to run when the command finished

baohua
2016-12-15 12:26
yes, and if so we may let developers know that explicitly in the docs, instead of hiding into scripts. sometimes, we just wanna build out a binary locally or just build a image.

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:26
i suspect removing the coupling will make things more error prone for users

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:27
s/users/devs

baohua
2016-12-15 12:27
i guess this follows linux style? make each piece focus, while combine as users like to?

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:27
i guess...but a counter point is: whatever you are stumbling on is a bug

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:28
we can paper over it by getting rid of the ccenv step, but really we should just fix the underlying issue

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:28
normally, ccenv would build, it would be cached, and then youd never have to deal with it again

baohua
2016-12-15 12:28
yes, and now it seems a little hard to dig it out as lots of things are comping together. However i will create an issue at the jira and let u know. thanks greg!

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:29
ok

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:29
ill give the decoupling more thought, but I think that would cause more problems

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:29
i understand your point though

baohua
2016-12-15 12:29
yes, let me dig more on the makefile first. see can find what hint for the error :slightly_smiling_face:

rickr
2016-12-15 17:23
Really wanted to run native

rickr
2016-12-15 17:23
did the make locally

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:23
@ghaskins uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3EKLRZUY/-.sh and commented: @rickr something is not kosher with your ccenv image

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:24
did you do anything custom to generate it, or was this simply what came out of a normal build?

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:24
@kamo ah, yes, the answer is simple

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:25
OSX ships with bsdtar, but the build expects switches that are gnutar specific

rickr
2016-12-15 17:25
Well I went back to running in vagrant. I run the same sdk test and it worked

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:25
what most of us have done is used homebrew to replace bsdtar with gnutar...i can guide if that is acceptable to you

kamo
2016-12-15 17:25
yes sure, that would be nice

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:26
@kamo ok, let me look it up, standby

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:27
@kamo i think you want "brew install gnu-tar --with-default-names"

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:27
the last option makes it install it as /usr/local/bin/tar rather than /usr/local/bin/gtar

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:27
so, as long as /usr/local/bin eclipses your default OSX bsdtar, that should do it

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:28
@rickr ok, I am not sure what went wrong, but your ccenv image seems to be corrupt somehow

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:28
but glad you can work around it in the vagrant setup for now

rickr
2016-12-15 17:28
ok thx a bunch ...

kamo
2016-12-15 17:33
@ghaskins thanks alot, the make process was successful now!

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:34
we need to get that in a wiki/faq somewhere

ghaskins
2016-12-15 17:34
@cbf any thoughts as to best placement of the bsdtar/gnutar thing for OSX?

cbf
2016-12-15 18:47
you mean in the docs?

cbf
2016-12-15 18:53

ghaskins
2016-12-16 13:29

jkilpatr
2016-12-16 13:30

ghaskins
2016-12-16 13:30

ghaskins
2016-12-16 13:31

ghaskins
2016-12-16 13:31
and certainly faster than needing to compile librocksdb :wink:

jkilpatr
2016-12-16 20:14
is there a reason we pull from google for go instead of installing golang-1.7 from the package manager?

jkilpatr
2016-12-16 20:14
other than unsupported platforms like arm or IBM Z or whatever potato chip someone is using.

ghaskins
2016-12-16 20:39
1.7 wasn't available packaged at the time

ghaskins
2016-12-16 20:39
If it is now, I am not against using it

jkilpatr
2016-12-16 20:43
ghaskins let me push what I have now and talk it over with you real quick

jkilpatr
2016-12-16 20:45
@ghaskins https://github.com/jkilpatr/fabric-baseimage-2.0

jkilpatr
2016-12-16 20:45
so the idea is we have a playbook, which calls roles, which each perform a specific section of the build process then overwrite the docker image "fabric-baseimage-in-progress" in the local docker repo

jkilpatr
2016-12-16 20:46
this makes the same sort of docker pipeline as before, but in a way where each part is clean and seperate

jkilpatr
2016-12-16 20:47
if you need some special arch or whatever you could create a role ibm-java and in that handle installing ibm java in the container, the only bit I haven't figured out is if you use the role ibm-java how do we not install java back in the install-deps phase without adding disto + platform conditionals, which mean N distros * P platforms number of combinations to handle.

baohua
2016-12-17 01:23

ghaskins
2016-12-21 14:03

ghaskins
2016-12-21 14:05
Yeah I blow the whole thing away

ghaskins
2016-12-21 14:06
Yw

ghaskins
2016-12-21 14:07
Part of the problem is that the chaincode redeploys _too_ deterministically. So you get the identical hash/id each time

ghaskins
2016-12-21 14:07
And thus, same state

ghaskins
2016-12-21 14:07
What needs to happen is nonce needs to be used

2016-12-21 14:08

thojest
2016-12-21 16:45

2016-12-21 16:46

thojest
2017-01-03 08:53
hey i have a question. running a peer node with `--peer-chaincodedev` what exactly is it doing?

thojest
2017-01-03 08:53
i have read somewhere that this way the chaincode is not executed in a docker container?

thojest
2017-01-03 08:54
does this mean that in normal mode the chaincode is run in a docker container although im running my peer node locally? this somehow does not make sense to me. would be thankful for any comment

thojest
2017-01-03 11:24
as far as i understand when you start a peer node `peer node start` it uses the core.yaml file

thojest
2017-01-03 11:24
is there any possibility to pass a different yaml-file to the peer node for configuartion?

thojest
2017-01-03 11:26
same question for memberservice using membersrvc.yaml

samsmith
2017-01-03 12:12
has joined #fabric-dev-env

garisingh
2017-01-03 12:24
@thosjest - first question: When running in "normal" mode, chaincodes are ALWAYS deployed as Docker containers (this provides isolation between multiple chaincodes). When running in "dev" mode ( `--peer-chaincodedev` ) you are able to more quickly "test" your chaincode as in this case you actual simply compile and run the chaincode (passing the correct parameters for it to connect to the peer) second question: in V1 there is an environment variable (`PEER_CFG_PATH`) you can set to specify a custom location for `core.yaml` (but the filename is always `core.yaml`) but in v0.6 the file location is more or less "fixed" but of course you can change the contents of the file. You can also override most of the `core.yaml` settings by passing in environment variables. If you look at any of the Docker compose files you'll see the naming convention

thojest
2017-01-03 13:12
@garisingh thx a lot

garisingh
2017-01-03 17:31
BTW - for folks working on Fabric development, you might be interested in this recently merged build feature: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3555/ See the commit for details, but basically it allows you to run unit-tests for a list of packages rather than running the whole suite. It's nice as a pre-test before submitting to quickly ensure that your tests will pass in the CI environment without having to run all the unit-tests for all packages

sukrit
2017-01-03 20:58
has joined #fabric-dev-env

tzipih
2017-01-04 04:24
has joined #fabric-dev-env

karnn
2017-01-04 09:57
@garisingh hey, quick question. when i build for fabric, at the end of the behave tests, do i need to ctrl+c out of it because it hangs with the following message:

karnn
2017-01-04 09:57
@karnn uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/karnn/F3M4ARAHY/-.txt

garisingh
2017-01-04 10:30
Hi @karnn - if you just want to build the Docker images locally, you can just run `make docker` if you are making changes to the Fabric code and want to test locally, just run `make unit-tests` I never run `make all` locally as I'm pretty sure the BDD tests still fail these days

karnn
2017-01-04 10:34
@garisingh i should do make docker within vagrant as well? when i make all locally i get this. : https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/karnn/F3KF02D7A/building_fabric_without_vagrant.txt

karnn
2017-01-04 10:34
@karnn mentioned a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/karnn/F3KF02D7A/building_fabric_without_vagrant.txt.

karnn
2017-01-04 10:34
@garisingh so i should make docker locally instead of make all

garisingh
2017-01-04 10:37
yeah - I would not go with `make all` for now. I believe the error you are getting locally is because you are running a downlevel of Go - for V1.0 we require Golang 1.7 and higher

karnn
2017-01-04 10:47
@garisingh you're right. it's 1.6. thanks so much. one quick question, i've used sawtooth in the past and was wondering if it was as easy to set up a marketplace with fabric as with sawtooth.

garisingh
2017-01-04 10:52
@karnn - fabric does not currently have the concept of a marketplace. I hesitate to say if there is a "equivalent" capability, but basically one you get the hang of writing chaincode it's pretty easy to add your own types of transactions / processing logic to the fabric

bkimminich
2017-01-09 16:08
Hi all! I'm trying to get the Vagrant `devenv` running while sitting behind a corporate web proxy. I configured Vagrant for that proxy, but run into this error after all: ``` Step 14 : RUN core/chaincode/shim/java/javabuild.sh ---> Running in 5d80a4f1513b FAILURE: Build failed with an exception. * Where: Build file '/root/core/chaincode/shim/java/build.gradle' line: 30 * What went wrong: Error resolving plugin [id: 'com.google.protobuf', version: '0.8.0'] > Could not GET 'https://plugins.gradle.org/api/gradle/2.12/plugin/use/com.google.protobuf/0.8.0'. > Connect to {my proxy}:443 [{my proxy}/{ip}] failed: Connection timed out (Connection timed out) * Try: Run with --stacktrace option to get the stack trace. Run with --info or --debug option to get more log output. The command '/bin/sh -c core/chaincode/shim/java/javabuild.sh' returned a non-zero code: 1 Makefile:196: recipe for target 'build/image/javaenv/.dummy-x86_64-0.7.0-snapshot-a5b12f2' failed ``` Any hint is welcome... Adding http://gradle.org to my SSH-config didn't work out...

Note: Recompile with -Xlint:unchecked for details. cp: cannot create directory '/root/': Permission denied ```

ghaskins
2017-01-10 15:53

ghaskins
2017-01-10 15:53

ghaskins
2017-01-10 15:53
if there is a pre-release version of a library, I agree we should endeavor to upgrade to released versions minimally

ghaskins
2017-01-10 15:54

divyank-sk
2017-01-10 17:18

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:09
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3827/ @ghaskins This fixes `make protos` (See https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1468 for which you are assigned)

ghaskins
2017-01-10 18:29
@jyellick you are a gentleman, ty

ghaskins
2017-01-10 18:31
(and sorry for the neglect)

ghaskins
2017-01-10 18:31
we really need to get that check added to the -verify CI task

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:32
No problem, I should have just put this changeset together a week ago when I noticed... would have saved myself some time in retrospect.

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:33
+1 to including it in the -verify CI task, seems too often I run `make protos` and unrelated proto files end up changing.

ghaskins
2017-01-10 18:39
yeah, now that the protoc task is normalized inside docker, I would think it could be deterministic enough to rely on that

yacovm
2017-01-10 18:44
why did `make protos` not work but `./scripts/compile_protos.sh` did?

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:45
Because `./scripts/compile_protos.sh` ends up trying to write `test.pb.go` into `$GOPATH` which is not writable inside docker

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:45
(The `go_package` directive tells `protoc` where to dump the output in `$GOPATH`)

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:46
When there's no dependency between proto packages, it's mostly innocuous not to specify the `go_package` and simply run the `protoc` in the same directory as the `.proto` file. But, when you have dependencies between different proto packages, this breaks.

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:47
`./scripts/compile_protos.sh` has to support the proto packages with external dependencies, so, it runs from `$GOPATH`

yacovm
2017-01-10 18:50
Isn't ` "http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/comm/testdata/grpc";` also in `$GOPATH` ?

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:51
So, `$GOPATH/src` is not writable, but `$GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric` is writable

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:52
Basically, when you run `./scripts/compile_protos.sh` locally, you are putting a random `test.pb.go` somewhere in your `$GOPATH`

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:52
Try a: ``` find "$GOPATH" -name 'test.pb.go' ```

yacovm
2017-01-10 18:53
what's so special about that package? the `core/comm/testdata/grpc`?

yacovm
2017-01-10 18:53
(will boot the laptop in a few minutes)

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:55
I don't think there's anything special? I think the `test.proto` was compiled manually when it was checked in, so the missing `go_package` did not have any negative effect (for the generated file). However, it broke `make protos` as a side effect (because it does not have `go_package` set and tries to write to a read only path)

jyellick
2017-01-10 18:57
The only place I found it referenced was ``` core/comm/server_test.go 36- "http://google.golang.org/grpc/credentials" 37- 38- "http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/comm" 39: testpb "http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/comm/testdata/grpc" 40-) 41- 42-//Embedded certificates for testing ``` Which, is overriding the import name regardless, so I don't expect any compilation problems.

yacovm
2017-01-10 18:58
yes I remember that, I think it's the configurable gRPC server commit

yacovm
2017-01-10 18:59
What I still fail to understand is - *why* would compiling that file would output not under `http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric` without the directive

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:01
Ah, so, you can actually blame me for that. You can see in `compile_protos.sh` ``` for dir in $ROOTLESS_PROTO_DIRS $PROTO_ROOT_DIRS; do echo Working on dir $dir # As this is a proto root, and there may be subdirectories with protos, compile the protos for each sub-directory which contains them for protos in $(find "$dir" -name '*.proto' -exec dirname {} \; | sort | uniq) ; do protoc --proto_path="$dir" --go_out=plugins=grpc:$GOPATH/src "$protos"/*.proto done done ``` Note the: `--go_out=plugins=grpc:$GOPATH/src`. `protoc` takes that path, adds the `go_package` path to it, and writes the file there. I guess the idea is that you don't have to litter your go path with proto definitions if you do not want.

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:02
This was the only way I could figure out to make `protoc` handle proto files in different directories which depended on eachother

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:03
In this case, there are `fabric/protos/orderer` and `fabric/protos/peer` which depends on `fabric/protos/common` (and possibly others)

ghaskins
2017-01-10 19:03
I just realized I wasnt even aware of FAB-1468, i think the proximity to the holidays contributed to me missing the email

ghaskins
2017-01-10 19:04
out of curiosity, what path is it actually trying to write to?

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:04
`$GOPATH/src/test.pb.go`

ghaskins
2017-01-10 19:04
in most contexts, I volume mount /opt/gopath/src

ghaskins
2017-01-10 19:04
ah, ok, I probably actually am too precise then

ghaskins
2017-01-10 19:04
i think I mount /opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:05
That seems like the right choice to me

ghaskins
2017-01-10 19:05
yeah, though not in this case :wink:

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:05
(Helps us catch bugs, like this one)

ghaskins
2017-01-10 19:05
true

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:05
Probably better than silently not updating the generated file.

ghaskins
2017-01-10 19:05
right

ghaskins
2017-01-10 19:05
i agree

ghaskins
2017-01-10 19:05
i was mostly wondering if I neglected to consistently set the volume mount for the proto context

ghaskins
2017-01-10 19:05
but I understand now

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:06
@yacovm If you can find a cleaner/better way to get the generated `.pb.go` files to link to eachother while also supporting protos which neglect to specify `go_package` you have my +2, but it was beyond me.

yacovm
2017-01-10 19:07
can't we somehow cd to the directory, and use the `--include-imports` flag with the common?

yacovm
2017-01-10 19:08
Didn't think of it for too long, or try this of course

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:09
It's all been paged out of my head, so can't say for certain that that won't work, but I tried for a few hours to not generate them this way with no luck.

yacovm
2017-01-10 19:09
yeah, I assume you tried enough stuff when you updated the script

yacovm
2017-01-10 19:10
just - what did you mean by saying "adds the `go_package` path to it," ?

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:10
As I said, please prove me wrong, I'm not a big fan of the way things ended up, but it was the only way that worked for me.

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:11
Concatenates that `$GOPATH/src` string from `﻿⁠⁠⁠⁠--go_out=plugins=grpc:$GOPATH/src` with the value of `go_package` to determine where to write the file

yacovm
2017-01-10 19:11
oh so the value of go_package is taken and concatenated!

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:11
Yep

yacovm
2017-01-10 19:11
that's why it's a relative path there

yacovm
2017-01-10 19:11
got it, thanks a lot for the step-by-step

jyellick
2017-01-10 19:12
No problem

kostas
2017-01-11 04:12
has joined #fabric-dev-env

kostas
2017-01-12 17:32
Theoretically, is there any reason why `make dist-clean` followed by `make docker` can fail?

ghaskins
2017-01-12 17:36
@kostas are you seeing a failure?

ghaskins
2017-01-12 17:36

kostas
2017-01-12 17:37
I do, but upon further inspection it seems it's related to Gari's observation about some Unix applications not playing nicely on macOS.

kostas
2017-01-12 17:37
```Step 3 : ADD payload/goshim.tar.bz2 $GOPATH/src/ Error processing tar file(bzip2 data invalid: bad magic value in continuation file): make: *** [build/image/ccenv/.dummy-x86_64-0.7.0-snapshot-48942d73] Error 1```

kostas
2017-01-12 17:37
So, I'll get on to fix that.

ghaskins
2017-01-12 17:38
search stackoverflow for that answer

ghaskins
2017-01-12 17:38
i posted it there

ghaskins
2017-01-12 17:38

fbenhamo
2017-01-12 20:56

ghaskins

ghaskins
2017-01-13 15:59

ghaskins
2017-01-13 15:59
take a look at ./test/docker-compose.yml

ghaskins
2017-01-13 15:59
in particular: CORE_PEER_ADDRESSAUTODETECT=true

ghaskins
2017-01-13 15:59
that instructs the peer to dynamically discover its IP

ghaskins
2017-01-13 15:59
you are running the peer in docker?

fbenhamo
2017-01-13 15:59

fbenhamo
2017-01-13 16:00

ghaskins
2017-01-13 16:00
so peer=native

ghaskins
2017-01-13 16:00
ok

ghaskins
2017-01-13 16:00
then just set that in the environment for the peer

ghaskins
2017-01-13 16:00
OSX docker is slightly different: 0.0.0.0 wont work like it does in Linux

ghaskins
2017-01-13 16:01
so, the defaults will work if the peer is running natively on linux, but not OSX

ghaskins
2017-01-13 16:01
OSX requires the AUTODETECT

fbenhamo
2017-01-13 16:01
ok, I'm trying this

ghaskins
2017-01-13 16:01
what I expect to see is the chaincode will now be given a specific IP to connect to

kostas
2017-01-18 20:46
@ghaskins or anyone else who knows the mechanics behind this: I'd like to pick your brain about `DOCKER_TAG` a bit.

kostas
2017-01-18 20:47
If there's documentation for this, let me know so I can read it first. (Not urgent BTW.)

garisingh
2017-01-18 20:53
@kostas - where do you see DOCKER_TAG?

kostas
2017-01-18 20:55
@garisingh: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3923/

kostas
2017-01-18 20:56
(And @harrijk, who's involved in that changeset, suggested that @ghaskins is whom should I be getting in touch with, to find out more about how `DOCKER_TAG` works.)

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:00
I was hoping this was what you were asking about - but just wanted to check

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:00
I'll assume you know about tagging Docker images?

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:00
:wink:

kostas
2017-01-18 21:01
(I do :grin:)

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:03
The missing pieces of the puzzle: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/Makefile#L42 https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/Makefile#L72 https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/docker-env.mk#L56

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:03
(the last file is where the DOCKER_TAG is defined)

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:04
so this is what basically creates the unique tag names for the images each time you create a new build

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:04
unless they set the release flag in the makefile at which time we don't include the extra version stuff

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:04
(or maybe you wanted more detail than that?)

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:05
it's also the reason that if you don't clean between builds you end up with a ton of tagged images

kostas
2017-01-18 21:05
First of all, thanks for these pointers.

kostas
2017-01-18 21:06
Question, where is the logic that picks up the `ARCH` you're on?

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:06
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/Makefile#L50

kostas
2017-01-18 21:06
Ah.

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:06
(sadly I have become intimate with this stuff)

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:07
I asked myself all of these questions

kostas
2017-01-18 21:09
Neat, I get it know. That'll be all then, thanks!

kostas
2017-01-18 21:09
(I was imagining a much more complex mechanism behind this.)

kostas
2017-01-18 21:09
(I wish all of my exchanges were this short.)

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:27
I hear ya

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:28
I thought there was some magic myself - but no - just basic stuff (no offense @ghaskins ) :wink:

ghaskins
2017-01-18 21:30
None taken.

ghaskins
2017-01-18 21:32
Fwiw: I didn't advocate for the SHA to be part of the tag

ghaskins
2017-01-18 21:32
I would have just used -snapshot

ghaskins
2017-01-18 21:33
Which would mitigate the proliferation of images during dev

ghaskins
2017-01-18 21:34
Personally, I think this is good enough and is accepted practice in other similar scenarios (see maven coordinates for instance)

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:35
it works really well

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:35
especially with the clean using rmi -f

garisingh
2017-01-18 21:35
I just sometime forget to do it

ghaskins
2017-01-18 21:36
Yeah

cbf
2017-01-19 21:24
having the sha as part of the tag will be important as we move to doing FIT and other integration testing (performance, scale etc) as we will want to be working of specific tagged builds

ghaskins
2017-01-20 02:00
I can see the argument there, though I would typically handle that use case with something like either a build-no or applying the sha as part of the CI pipeline

ghaskins
2017-01-20 02:01
my main point is that as a pure developer flow, I think -sandbox is easier to use with (and has precedent) than the extra metatag

ghaskins
2017-01-20 02:02
i dont really have a strong opinion about it though

ry
2017-01-25 22:50
I hope? it's interesting. Flickr came out of an attempt to re-invent chat - it was like irc with pictures attached. People loved the picture sharing and the chat died off. Those guys left Yahoo gazillionaires and started Slack to... reinvent chat

ry
2017-01-25 22:51
so what makes it to startup 3 for the same team?

jzhang
2017-01-26 15:19

jzhang
2017-01-26 15:19

ry
2017-01-26 15:26

ry
2017-01-26 15:27

ry
2017-01-26 15:28

jzhang
2017-01-26 15:38
I think it’s preferable to publish this from an account owned by the hyperledger org

kostas
2017-01-26 16:00
ry: So, Flickr came out of the chat component of GNE (Game Never Ending), a game that these guys were building. When they left Yahoo!, they went back to finishing that game, and they did. But they never released it --tests showed it wasn't gaining any traction, plus the market was turning away from Flash because of iPhones-- and they were about to dismantle the company, when they realized that this little tool that they had built on the sidelines to help with the development of GNE _could_ be useful to other teams for communications. And ta-da, Slack was born.

ry
2017-01-26 16:01
ah ha! sorry

ry
2017-01-26 16:02
yes, I agree. Earlier you had asked for credentials; I had forgotten that hfc 0.6 was published directly

ry
2017-01-26 16:03
is @ramesh working on this in the /sandbox/?

ramesh
2017-01-26 16:04
@ry: no

kostas
2017-01-26 16:04
(The founder is --naturally-- a pretty sharp guy. This is worth a listen if you're into these sorts of interviews: http://www.stitcher.com/podcast/panoply/the-ezra-klein-show/e/stewart-butterfield-on-creating-slack-learning-from-games-and-46235774 I liked his thoughts on company culture, and what's next in store for Slack.)

arnaud
2017-01-29 19:04
@matanyahu to test that your build gave you something that works as expected. Sorry if I'm missing the meaning of your question

arnaud
2017-01-29 19:06
Some tests typically fail just because of timeouts not well suited for your env though

arnaud
2017-01-29 19:06
So don't get too hung up if sonne of those fail

matanyahu
2017-01-29 19:49
@arnaud : thanks!

Hi, In car lease demo, is the validation of transaction being contribute by all,i.e as all are involved under single transaction or not?

jeffgarratt
2017-01-31 15:12
@matanyahu the purpose of the behave tests is to perform more of an overall system test. It actually launches networks and then acts on the network, verifying results

jeffgarratt
2017-01-31 15:12
it can also be used to boostrap a network rapidly and use if for development purposes (fabric development)

matanyahu
2017-01-31 19:21
thanks @jeffgarratt

jeffgarratt
2017-01-31 19:24
yw

smfaizalkhan
2017-02-01 12:28
Hi Guys ,Started to get my hands dirty with HyperLedger

smfaizalkhan
2017-02-01 12:29
I have three questions on the Technical aspect of HyperLedger. 1) ChainCode Registraton 2) Member Registration 3) ChainCode in JAVA ChainCode Registration I followed the docs at https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io and installed fabric on Ubuntu. and was succesful in registering the chaincode with one Validating peer and one memberservice. I tried to add three more VP to ahceive consensus. So now i spun all the containers using docker-compose.yml(PFA) and in the shipyard i saw all the containers are started . Then i registered the CC using the below command "CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=cscc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 ./goods_inspection" Got a success response as below "14:50:11.937 [shim] INFO : error with chaincode log level: logger: invalid log level level= 14:50:11.937 [shim] DEBU : peerAddress at return point0.0.0.0:8051 14:50:11.937 [shim] DEBU : Peer address is: 0.0.0.0:8051 14:50:11.937 [shim] DEBU : peerAddress is not null0.0.0.0:8051 14:50:11.938 [shim] DEBU : os.Args returns: [./goods_inspection] 14:50:11.938 [shim] DEBU : Registering.. sending REGISTER 14:50:11.941 [shim] DEBU : []Received message REGISTERED from shim 14:50:11.943 [shim] DEBU : []Handling ChaincodeMessage of type: REGISTERED(state:created) 14:50:11.943 [shim] DEBU : Received REGISTERED, ready for invocations" Then i deployed the Chaincode in the Shipyard vp0's console using the CLI command “peer chaincode deploy –l go –u jim -n cscc -c '{"Args": ["init", "a","100", "b", "200"]}'” I got the success response and expected it to be replicated across other VP’s To check it we did the query command on another VP as VP1,VP2 “peer chaincode query –l java –u jim -n cscc -c '{"Args": ["query", "b"]}'” But I got error “LedgerError - R esourceNotFound: ledger: resource not found”. So to check if transaction is deployed on other peers(VP1,VP2) ,we check it using curl command and postman from chrome like curl http://172.16.0.11:7050/chain. Count is increased, but when tried to query the same the same error as “LedgerError - R esourceNotFound: ledger: resource not found”. But when i register the chaincode in two nodes and register it using the below command. "CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=cscc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 ./goods_inspection" "CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=cscc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:8051 ./goods_inspection" and mapping ports in docker-compose.yaml as - "7051:7051" for vp0 - "8051:7051" for vp1

smfaizalkhan
2017-02-01 12:29
I noted the chaincode registration is done on two VP's and able to query the same .I dont get the "Resource not found Error"

smfaizalkhan
2017-02-01 12:29
Please clarify

smfaizalkhan
2017-02-01 12:31
I have three questions on the Technical aspect of HyperLedger. 1) ChainCode Registraton 2) Member Registration 3) ChainCode in JAVA ChainCode Registration I followed the docs at https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io and installed fabric on Ubuntu. and was succesful in registering the chaincode with one Validating peer and one memberservice. I tried to add three more VP to ahceive consensus. So now i spun all the containers using docker-compose.yml(PFA) and in the shipyard i saw all the containers are started . Then i registered the CC using the below command "CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=cscc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 ./goods_inspection" Got a success response as below "14:50:11.937 [shim] INFO : error with chaincode log level: logger: invalid log level level= 14:50:11.937 [shim] DEBU : peerAddress at return point0.0.0.0:8051 14:50:11.937 [shim] DEBU : Peer address is: 0.0.0.0:8051 14:50:11.937 [shim] DEBU : peerAddress is not null0.0.0.0:8051 14:50:11.938 [shim] DEBU : os.Args returns: [./goods_inspection] 14:50:11.938 [shim] DEBU : Registering.. sending REGISTER 14:50:11.941 [shim] DEBU : []Received message REGISTERED from shim 14:50:11.943 [shim] DEBU : []Handling ChaincodeMessage of type: REGISTERED(state:created) 14:50:11.943 [shim] DEBU : Received REGISTERED, ready for invocations" Then i deployed the Chaincode in the Shipyard vp0's console using the CLI command “peer chaincode deploy –l go –u jim -n cscc -c '{"Args": ["init", "a","100", "b", "200"]}'” I got the success response and expected it to be replicated across other VP’s To check it we did the query command on another VP as VP1,VP2 “peer chaincode query –l java –u jim -n cscc -c '{"Args": ["query", "b"]}'” But I got error “LedgerError - R esourceNotFound: ledger: resource not found”. So to check if transaction is deployed on other peers(VP1,VP2) ,we check it using curl command and postman from chrome like curl http://172.16.0.11:7050/chain. Count is increased, but when tried to query the same the same error as “LedgerError - R esourceNotFound: ledger: resource not found”. But when i register the chaincode in two nodes and register it using the below command. "CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=cscc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 ./goods_inspection" "CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=cscc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:8051 ./goods_inspection" and mapping ports in docker-compose.yaml as - "7051:7051" for vp0 - "8051:7051" for vp1

2017-02-01 12:32
docker-compose.yamlmembersrvc: image: hyperledger/fabric-membersrvc ports: - "7054:7054" command: membersrvc vp0: image: hyperledger/fabric-peer ports: - "7051:7051" environment: - CORE_PEER_ADDRESSAUTODETECT=true - CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=unix:///var/run/docker.sock - CORE_LOGGING_LEVEL=INFO - CORE_PEER_ID=vp0 - CORE_PEER_PKI_ECA_PADDR=membersrvc:7054 - CORE_PEER_PKI_TCA_PADDR=membersrvc:7054 - CORE_PEER_PKI_TLSCA_PADDR=membersrvc:7054 - CORE_SECURITY_ENABLED=true - CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLID=test_vp0 - CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLSECRET=MwYpmSRjupbT links: - membersrvc command: sh -c "sleep 5; peer node start --peer-chaincodedev" vp1: image: hyperledger/fabric-peer ports: - "8051:7051" environment: - CORE_PEER_ADDRESSAUTODETECT=true - CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=unix:///var/run/docker.sock - CORE_LOGGING_LEVEL=DEBUG - CORE_PEER_ID=vp1 - DEPLOY_MODE=dev - CORE_PEER_PKI_ECA_PADDR=membersrvc:7054 - CORE_PEER_PKI_TCA_PADDR=membersrvc:7054 - CORE_PEER_PKI_TLSCA_PADDR=membersrvc:7054 - CORE_SECURITY_ENABLED=true - CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLID=test_vp1 - CORE_PEER_DISCOVERY_ROOTNODE=vp0:7051 - CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLSECRET=5wgHK9qqYaPy links: - membersrvc - vp0 command: sh -c "sleep 5; peer node start --peer-chaincodedev"
